Title: Melons
Artwork Description: Melons was painted during Hartley's travels in the south of France suggesting the style of Cezanne. Shape and color are the primary elements used in this work. An almost monochromatic color scheme is separated across the center by a white sheet of piled fabric creating a horizontally balanced design. The fabric calls to mind a mountainous landscape. Planes of color stack in horizontal registers interrupted by the two melons. Brush strokes are apparent and run parallel to each other. Forms are flat, simplified and abstract with rugged outlines. Hartley does not show much depth or perspective in this composition. "I would rather be sure that I had placed two colors in true relationship to each other than to have exposed a wealth of emotionalism gone wrong in the name of richness of personal expression." From Marsden's writing titled Art and the Personal Life; written one year after Melons was painted.
Artist Biography: Born January 4, 1877 at Lewiston, Maine; died September 2, 1943 at Ellsworth, Maine. 1896: Received his initial art training in Cleveland, OH with John Semon, a local painter. 1898-9: Studied at the Cleveland Institute of Art and the Chase School in New York. 1900-04: At the age of 22, Hartley won a scholarship to study at the National Academy of Design in New York. 1909: First solo exhibition, at the prominent 291 Gallery, which was managed by famous photographer and Modern Art predicator, Alfred Stieglitz. At 291, Hartley connected with American avant-garde artists like Georgia O'Keefe and John Marin. Hartley's continuous travels were an important aspect of his life and influence on his work. 1912: Hartley went to Paris and met Gertrude Stein who had paintings by Cezanne, Matisse and Picasso hanging in her home, which inspired Hartley's work at the time. 1913: Traveled to Berlin, where he met Wassily Kandinsky and Franz Marc. 1925-1929: Painted in Vence and Aix-en-Provence, France using the style of Cezanne. Also traveled to Bermuda, Nova Scotia, Bavaria, Gloucester and Mexico. Consistently returned to his American roots working in the Southwestern United States and New England. 1937-1943: Held a deep love for Maine and painted there until his death. Was associated with the Modernists. Subjects include the figure, still life, coastal sea themes, mountain landscapes, military motifs, soldiers and American Indian themes. Early work exhibited influences of Impressionism and Neo-Impressionism. Later Hartley was inspired by Post-Impressionism, Cubism, Fauvism, European Modernism, German Expressionism; also, photography and mysticism.
Tour Guidance: Color: Discuss Hartley's use of color in this piece. Which other artists featured in the IMA make use of idealized, imaginary or exotic color: Modern, Pont Avon...? Contrast with dark muted colors as in the Munich paintings of the Hoosier Group and Courbet. Food in Art: Include in a tour with other paintings featuring food as the primary subject. Talk about different foods that appear in our galleries. Why is food an interesting subject for painters? How is food depicted? Abstract? Realistic? Connect to food containers in the African and Asian galleries. Also connect to food appearing as embellishment on decorative objects. Dutch still life: Make connection to Dutch still life paintings. Contrast the abstracted simplified forms in Hartley's painting to the optical realism and rendering skill of the Dutch.
Connections: Jimson Weed – Georgia O'Keefe. O'Keefe was married to photographer Alfred Stieglitz who ran the avant-garde gallery in New York, called 291. Stieglitz was a fan and supporter of Hartley. Hartley's first one man exhibition was at 291 Gallery. He worked in the American southwest as did O'Keefe. You could loosely connect to the Native American collection. Hurricane – John Marin. Hartley met John Marin at 291 Gallery. They were both from Maine and shared a great love for the area. Waves in Hurricane relate to waves of fabric in Melons. House in Provence – Paul Cezanne. Cezanne was born in Aix-en-Provence. Marsden lived and worked there for a period. Hartley was inspired by the work of Cezanne. Connect paint stroke, color, structure and geometric forms. Compare mountains in House in Provence with fabric in Melons. Show examples of Cezanne's still life paintings with fruit. Mountains and Valleys – Victor Higgins. Compare mountainous forms, horizontal registers, brush stroke. Still Life with Profile of Laval – Paul Gauguin. Make connection to Pont-Aven School. Idealized use of color, flat simplified forms. Pablo Picasso. Hartley and Picasso were contemporaries and Hartley was exposed to Picasso's work via Gertrude Stein.

http://www.imamuseum.org/explore/artwork/1478?
Grove Dictionary of Artists, Volume #14, Edited by Jane Turner, 1996
Marsden Hartley, "Art and the Personal Life", 1928: http://www.artchive.com/artchive/H/hartley.html
http://www.nga.gov/fcgi-bin/timage_f?object=61446&image=15819&c=
Micro Summary: American modernist Marsden Hartley (1877-1943) was a well-traveled artist who studied in Paris, Berlin, and throughout Europe, developing connections with avant-garde figures like Georgia O'Keeffe, Gertrude Stein, and Wassily Kandinsky. Painted around 1927 during his time in southern France, "Melons" reflects Cézanne's influence through its simplified forms, monochromatic color scheme, and geometric composition. The work exemplifies Hartley's mature style, emphasizing formal relationships of color and shape over emotional expression, representing his significant contribution to American Modernism during the interwar period.

Title: The Young Artist
Artwork Description: The Young Artist was meant to appeal to the Boston public in many ways. It was humorous, and its moral tone was defined and clarified by the verse that accompanied it, which read, "Fair lady, turn not by in scorn, At talent to the pencil born, Genius knows naught of age or clime, 'Tis God's own mind – 'tis all divine." The painting appealed to abolitionists in its quiet depiction of America's children, the country's future, putting aside issues of race to play together. The painting embodies the prevailing philosophy of America at the time as a young nation full of youthful energy and fun, where everyone can enjoy the fruits of honest labor and still have time for leisure.
Artist Biography: After completing some informal art training, Boston-born Thomas Mickell Burnham made his first trip abroad. When he returned, he took up sign painting and then opened a portrait studio, since portraiture was a lucrative practice. Success at this profession allowed Burnham to travel to Scotland in 1839. Upon his return, he began concentrating on genre and landscape painting in addition to portraiture. In the mid-nineteenth century, Burnham painted his most famous work The Lewis and Clark Expedition mostly from his imagination.

Micro Summary: "The Young Artist" by Thomas Mickell Burnham was created to appeal to Boston audiences through its humorous tone and moral message about recognizing talent regardless of age or background. The painting quietly promoted abolitionist ideals by depicting children of different races playing together harmoniously. It embodied America's self-image as a youthful, energetic nation where hard work and leisure could coexist, accompanied by a verse encouraging viewers not to scorn young artistic talent as divine genius.

Title: Portrait of Robert Louis Stevenson
Artwork Description: Gaudens was taken by the work of Robert Louis Stevenson and said, "…if Stevenson ever crossed to this side of the water I should consider it an honor if he would allow me to make his portrait." Stevenson came to America in 1887 and sat for Saint-Gaudens at the Hotel Albert in New York. This portrait relief became Saint-Gaudens' most widely produced work. To avoid the effect of mass production in the numerous castings, Saint-Gaudens varied details of the portrait and its size. The sculptor shows the popular Scottish author reclining in bed, weakened by tuberculosis, a manuscript in one hand and a cigarette in the other. Typical of Saint-Gaudens' reliefs are the lively variety of naturalist details, such as the contrast between the smooth pillowcase and the rougher blanket and bedclothes.
Artist Biography: Dublin-native Augustus Saint-Gaudens was raised in New York City after his Irish mother and French father immigrated to America, when he was six months old. He took classes at the Cooper Union and the National Academy of Design before traveling to Paris, where he studied at the École des Beaux Arts. He also studied art and architecture in Rome. Upon his return to the United States, Saint-Gaudens received critical acclaim for his monuments commemorating heroes of the American Civil War and his numerous funerary monuments and busts. His colossal Standing Lincoln in Lincoln Park, Chicago, is considered one of the finest portrait statues in America. It was followed by a seated statue of the president in Chicago's Grant Park, a copy of which was placed by Lincoln's tomb. Saint-Gaudens was an important teacher, tutoring privately and at the Art Students League of New York. He is also known for his portrait medallions and coin designs. Later in life, he founded the Cornish Colony in New Hampshire, which attracted numerous painters, architects, and sculptors, including Paul Manship, Thomas Wilmer Dewing, and the illustrator Maxfield Parrish. His house and gardens are preserved as Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site.

Micro Summary: Augustus Saint-Gaudens created this portrait relief of Scottish author Robert Louis Stevenson in 1887 when the writer visited New York and sat for the sculptor at the Hotel Albert. The work depicts Stevenson reclining in bed, weakened by tuberculosis, holding a manuscript in one hand and a cigarette in the other. This became Saint-Gaudens' most widely produced work, though he varied details and sizes in different castings to avoid a mass-produced appearance. The relief showcases the artist's naturalistic style through contrasting textures like the smooth pillowcase against the rougher bedclothes.

Title: Frog Fountain
Artwork Description: This nude figure of a child surrounded by a base of frogs was inspired by children Scudder observed in Italy. Scudder was one of the premier artists of garden sculpture of her era. Frog Fountain is Scudder's best-known work. As a young artist in France, Scudder persuaded the successful American sculptor Frederick MacMonnies to break his rule against taking students. Scudder incorporated MacMonnies lively naturalistic modeling into Frog Fountain. She said that this bronze was inspired by children she observed in Italy, a country renowned for its fountain sculpture. The chubby little boy, his hair garlanded with flowers, dances between three nervous frogs. Frog Fountain is Scudder's best known work, and this bronze is one of many replicas.
Artist Biography: Determined to be an artist, Scudder left Terre Haute, Indiana in her teens to study at the Academy of Art in Cincinnati. By age 20 she was one of Lorado Taft's "white rabbits," the female assistants who aided him in his many sculpture projects for the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago. In 1894 she sought training in France, where she eventually established her home and studio. Active beyond her work as a sculptor, Scudder participated in the women's suffrage movement in the United States, wrote an autobiography entitled Modelling My Life, and was honored by France as a Chevalier de la Légion d'Honneur. Scudder came back to the United States nearly every year to seek fountain projects from landscape architects. During the early 20th century a wide-spread American demand for garden sculpture provided Scudder with many commissions, earning her the title "Woman of the Fountains."

Sources/Bibliography: Judith Vale Newton and Carol Ann Weiss. Skirting the Issue: Stories of Indiana's Historical Women Artists, Indianapolis: Indiana Historical Society, 2004. ISBN-13: 978-0871951779
Micro Summary: "Frog Fountain" by Janet Scudder features a nude child figure surrounded by frogs at the base, inspired by children the artist observed in Italy. Scudder was a premier garden sculpture artist who trained under Frederick MacMonnies in France, incorporating his naturalistic modeling style into her work. The bronze depicts a chubby boy with a flower garland in his hair dancing between three frogs. This piece is Scudder's best-known work and exists in multiple bronze replicas.

Title: Washington Street, Indianapolis at Dusk
Artwork Description: Groll's methods are not certain but it is believed he used photographs extensively. Several separate areas of interest in this painting suggest Groll took several photographs, small oil studies or sketches back to Dusseldorf, then combined these into this larger panoramic view. Notable distortion of State House location to street can be attributed to this method, or artistic license. This cityscape features the State House, Park Theatre, and research leads us to believe the other recognizable buildings are a market stall, a bustling saloon, the Hoosier Drugstore, and a large furniture store, all which once existed along the busy commercial life of West Washington Street. Tower of the old Marion County Courthouse can be seen in background. Soldiers' & Sailors' Monument not dedicated until 1902 so is not in painting. Aside from the State House's location being too close to the street, it is suspected that the painting is generally accurate despite the sunset appearing to be in the northeast. All buildings in the painting have been destroyed except the State House so this painting is the sole known visual recording of some of these buildings. In central foreground the Blake Street trolley is hailed by a well-dressed, bearded gentleman who is probably Jacob Metzger, a resident of Indianapolis and Groll's uncle's brother-in-law. Groll belonged to the School of Dusseldorf painters of Italian scenes, along with Otto Achenbach and Albert Flamm, and exhibits an intimacy and finesse of observation, especially of architectural forms. Groll known for "subtle" paintings in which architecture often plays a major role. Groll exhibited this painting at the Berlin Art Exhibition in 1895.
Artist Biography: Born in Dusseldorf Feb. 9, 1857, died in Dusseldorf April 13, 1913. Groll was first a student at the Berlin Academy of Architecture, but turned from architecture to painting as a student of Kasper Scheuren. Later he made extensive study trips to Venice and Verona, Italy. Groll came to America in 1892 to judge the German paintings at the 1893 Chicago World's Fair then spent time visiting relatives in Indianapolis; he remained in Indianapolis until 1895. Groll's father married Laura Lieber of Dusseldorf. Laura's brother Herman Lieber lived in Indianapolis, was a patron of T.C. Steele, and operated an important gallery, Lieber's Art Emporium at 33 Southern Meridian St. Primarily a landscape and architectural artist.
Tour Guidance: Discuss what is happening in the world and Indianapolis and how it is affecting art, the economy, socio-economics of Indianapolis, etc. Discuss the subject matter Groll chose – architectural landscape with several different areas of interest, city marketing, saloon, entertainment (theatre), trolley travel, commerce. Discuss the style or technique used in painting the picture. Discuss the visual elements of art—line, shape, color, texture, space. Discuss Indianapolis history. Park Theatre, being considered the "most elegant theater in the West", burned in 1897. Take separate sections (trolley, street scene, buildings) and discuss detail of architecture and people. Discuss then and now – current view from Senate St. west on Washington Street – what's there now? (Westin, Marriott, Schuler's, Simons' Bldg, IRT, State House, horse & carriages as pleasure rides)
Connections: Works of art with Indiana connections, T. C. Steele, Pleasant Run; Gruelle, The Canal—Morning Effect. Painting and Poetry: The landscape, add a Hoosier poem (James Whitcomb Riley). VTS – Visual Thinking Strategies – take each section of the painting and discuss what is going on in the bustle of the street, market, people, trolleys, animals, children, adults, saloon, drugstore. Connect to other Indiana landscapes and Indiana subject matters
Sources/Bibliography: Garmel, M. S. (1973) 'Washington Street In 1890's Captured', The Indianapolis News, 3 May, p. 20. Stout Library: Theodor Groll file. Unknown (1973) 'Just Like Downtown', Star Magazine, Sunday April 29 pp. cover, 54, 59. Unknown, Unknown, 'Views of Indianapolis: Artistic Perspectives' Unknown, Unknown. (article in Groll file in Stout Library).
Micro Summary: Theodor Groll's "Washington Street, Indianapolis at Dusk" depicts a bustling commercial street scene featuring the State House, Park Theatre, and various businesses including a market stall, saloon, drugstore, and furniture store that once lined West Washington Street. The German artist likely combined multiple photographs or sketches to create this panoramic cityscape, resulting in some spatial distortions like the State House appearing too close to the street. This painting serves as the sole visual record of many of these buildings, all of which have been destroyed except the State House. The foreground shows a Blake Street trolley being hailed by a well-dressed gentleman believed to be Jacob Metzger, who had family connections to the artist. Groll exhibited this architecturally-focused work at the Berlin Art Exhibition in 1895, demonstrating his characteristic attention to built environments.

Title: Seated Nude
Artwork Description: In his sculpture, Rubins sought harmonious proportions and a pensive quality that exhibits his knowledge of classical sculpture and his skill at modeling the figure. Rubins studied at the American Academy in Rome before joining the faculty at the Herron Art School in Indianapolis. In his figural sculpture, Rubins usually sought harmonious proportions and a pensive quality, preferring rounded, ideal forms to the angular or distorted. The balance and feminine grace of this bronze figure recall early twentieth-century French sculpture by artists such as Aristide Mailllol.
Artist Biography: David Rubins was born in Minneapolis and received his education at Dartmouth College. He then traveled to Europe to continue his studies at the Ecole des Beaux Arts and Académie Julian. Rubins was also a fellow in sculpture at the American Academy in Rome. His sculpture was primarily figurative and included a monument of Abraham Lincoln as a young man for the Indiana State Capitol and the bronze cherub that was on the clock during Christmas season at L. S. Ayres and Company in downtown Indianapolis. Rubins is also known for his busts of prominent people, including the architect Evans Woolen, President William Henry Harrison and Indianapolis Governor Henry Schricker. Rubins taught sculpture and anatomy at the Herron School of Art in Indianapolis.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: David K. Rubins. The Human Figure: An Anatomy for Artists, New York: Penquin Group, 1975. ISBN-13: 978-0140042436
Micro Summary: David K. Rubins' "Seated Nude" is a bronze sculpture that demonstrates his classical training at the American Academy in Rome and his expertise in figure modeling. The work features harmonious proportions and a contemplative quality, emphasizing rounded, idealized forms rather than angular or distorted elements. The sculpture's balance and feminine grace echo the style of early twentieth-century French sculptors like Aristide Maillol. Rubins, who later taught at Indianapolis's Herron Art School, consistently pursued this aesthetic of classical beauty and pensive tranquility in his figural works.

Title: Portrait of Reginald Marsh
Artwork Description: Brook's paintings, which are consistently realistic, include portraits, still-life subjects, landscapes, and nude female figures. His color is subtle and reserved. A deep respect for human personality characterizes much of his work, often with overtones of wry humor or irony. Marsh kept his overcoat on to protect him from the cold studio and because Brook wanted to make an interesting pose and composition. An innate tenderness and fineness of texture distinguishes his paintings. He created vital, rich, emotional paintings from a low-key, almost drab palette. The mood of his paintings could be lonely, contemplative, sad, lyrical, whimsical, and even humorous. Source: Santa Fe East Galleries. His subject-matter and his attitude toward it are a highly personal response to the intimate life about him. His canvases are particularly free of any hint of the bombastic or the obviously monumental.
Artist Biography: Alexander Brook was born in Brooklyn, New York, in 1898, to Russian parents. At the age of 12, Brook lost the use of his legs for several months from polio. He asked for some paints. He got them and a gentleman instructor, who specialized in painting people's deceased relatives from photographs. Brook attended Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, but was asked to leave when caught carrying a bucket of beer into the school. He wanted to paint the beer. At age17, he enrolled in the Art Students League. For four years, he studied under Kenneth Hayes Miller. He met other artists: Louis Bouche, Yasuo Kuniyoshi, and Reginald Marsh. He was later on the faculty. Brook is considered a key figure in the American Realist movement of the 20s and 30s. He is associated with the Fourteenth Street Group, which included Kenneth Hays Miller, Reginald Marsh, and Isabel Bishop. He painted his immediate environment -- his studio and visiting friends. He was primarily a studio painter in the realist tradition. His success began in 1929 when he won a $2,500 prize at the Art Institute of Chicago. He was successful because he organized his life on his own and on no one else's terms. At this point in 1929, he had sold 100 paintings. Source: Harry Salpeter, October 1936 Esquire. In 1920, Brook married Peggy Bacon, who was a printmaker, illustrator, poet, etcher, and caricaturist. Their daughter, Belinda, at age 15 showed promise as an artist. Their son, Sandy, was a model for his dad and became a naval aviator. Portraits of him are in the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Whitney. In 1940 Life Magazine, called Brook 'one of America's best painters.' It was said he had more one-man shows than any living American artist. In 1945, he did his first magazine cover. It was for The Saturday Evening Post and was a portrait of the daughter of a New York broker. She's sitting in an upholstered chair holding a straw hat. When the realistic movement declined in the 50s, Brook isolated himself and became reclusive. He died in 1980.
Tour Guidance: American gallery tour. Hat theme tour: use the bowler hat on the back of the chair. Normally a portrait would not make a good VTS piece, but in Portrait of Reginald Marsh, there are some interesting features to discuss. It could almost be genre piece.
Connections: In Brook's portrait of Reginald Marsh, we see the painter of Hauptmann Must Die. Portraits in the American gallery such as Portrait of James Whitcomb Riley by John Singer Sargent.
Sources/Bibliography: Collections information on the IMA website. Ernest Brace article. Keeping Posted, a newspaper column. Life Magazine. Santa Fe Galleries catalog. Location: 200 Old Santa Fe Trail. TIME Magazine, August 3, 1962. Stout Library files: Miscellaneous articles without a source or date of publication. http://www.askart.com/askart/b/alexander_brook/alexander_brook.aspx
Micro Summary: Alexander Brook's realistic portrait depicts fellow artist Reginald Marsh wearing an overcoat in the cold studio, creating an interesting compositional pose. Brook's characteristic subtle, reserved color palette and low-key tones produce a vital, emotionally rich painting despite its almost drab hues. The work exemplifies Brook's deep respect for human personality and his intimate, personal approach to portraiture. His innate tenderness and fine texture technique create a mood that is simultaneously contemplative and quietly compelling, free from any bombastic or overtly monumental qualities.

Title: Summer, Lake Ontario
Artwork Description: Summer, Lake Ontario was painted in England for the series of chromolithographs by E. Gambert and Company after Cropsey's work. The painting was inspired directly by Frederic Church's New England Scenery, 1851. Crospey depicted America as a new Eden where settlers carve out a pastoral paradise from the wilderness while living in harmony with nature. The serene sunset acts as a sign of God's blessing on the land.
Artist Biography: Born on Staten Island, New York, Cropsey trained to be an architect. His teacher encouraged him to enhance his architectural drawings with landscapes scenes, resulting in Cropsey's change in focus from architecture to landscape painting. Cropsey opened a studio in southeastern New York State. When he married in 1849, he and his wife took a two-year European honeymoon, traveling to England and Italy where he worked in the studio of Thomas Cole, founder of the Hudson River School. After returning to America, Cropsey began painting full-time. In 1856, the Cropseys again traveled to Europe, spending seven years in London, England. During his stay he fulfilled commissions from Americans wanting European subjects and European commissions for American scenes. Cropsey was commissioned by the English lithographic house of E. Gambert and Company to create a series of thirty-six paintings of American subjects. Although the series was never completed, at least eight were published in American Scenery, a portfolio of full size chromolithographs of these paintings.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Nancy Hall-Duncan. A Man for All Seasons: Jasper Francis Cropsey, Stamford, Ct.: Bruce Museum, 1988. ASIN: B00071PA4I
Micro Summary: Jasper Francis Cropsey's "Summer, Lake Ontario" was painted in England as part of a chromolithograph series, directly inspired by Frederic Church's "New England Scenery" from 1851. The work depicts America as a new Eden, where settlers create a pastoral paradise from the wilderness while maintaining harmony with nature. A serene sunset dominates the composition, symbolizing God's divine blessing upon the American landscape. The painting reflects the 19th-century American ideal of westward expansion and manifest destiny through a romanticized lens.

Title: Study of a Young Woman
Artwork Description: There is no evidence to support the traditional title A Spanish Girl or the date 1896, when Chase paid his third visit to Spain. In fact, the dress was common in the United States during the 1880s. Moreover, the style is typical of Chase's work from around the middle of that decade, which was influenced by the dark tonalities of his Munich period. The canvas is painted in broad, straight brushstrokes, which have the panache, but lack the subtlety of his mature technique. The painting nevertheless has the liveliness of his best informal portraits.
Artist Biography: A native of Indiana, Chase studied first in Indianapolis and then in Munich, where he shared a studio with Frank Duveneck. Like Duveneck, he outgrew the limitations of the Leibl School in the 1880s, but retained an allegiance to the black tones of Frans Hals and Édouard Manet. Much of his work from this period consists of casual studies. Like many other American artists of the period, Chase was at his best painting young women, whose beauty he captured and even flattered with his technique. Curiously enough, he endowed most of them, including this sitter, with the features of his wife, who provided his ideal of femininity that lasted unabated until his death.

Sources/Bibliography: Pisano, Ronald G. William Merritt Chase: The Complete Catalogue of Known and Documents Work by William Merritt Chase (1849-1916), Vol. 2: Portraits in Oil. New Haven Connecticut: Yale University Press, 2007.
Micro Summary: "Study of a Young Woman" by William Merritt Chase depicts a female subject wearing 1880s American dress, contradicting the traditional but unsupported title "A Spanish Girl" and date of 1896. The painting exemplifies Chase's mid-1880s style, influenced by the dark tonal qualities from his Munich training period. Executed with bold, straight brushstrokes that demonstrate panache while lacking his later technical subtlety, the work captures the energetic quality characteristic of Chase's finest informal portraits.

Title: Louisa Fletcher
Artwork Description: 1912, oil on canvas. Louisa seems assured, engaging model in fashionable empire-cut gown. Louisa daughter of Indianapolis banker Stoughton Fletcher and wife of Hoosier author Booth Tarkington, whom she divorced 1911. Artist and Louisa were friends with mutual interest in art. Signed and dated L.R.: Mary Green Blumenschein 1912. Gift of Miss Sally Reahard.
Artist Biography: Mary Shepard Greene Blumenschein, American (1869-1958). Accomplished artist, studied New York City and Paris. Won awards at Paris Salon and St. Louis Exposition. 1905 married Ernest Blumenschein, returned to New York. Taught at Pratt Institute, provided illustrations for Century, McClure's and American magazines. 1913 moved to Taos. Continued painting and teaching.
Sources/Bibliography: Hassrick, Peter H. and Elizabeth J. Cunningham. In Contemporary Rhythm: The Art of Ernest L. Blumenschein. Norman, Oklahoma: University of Oklahoma Press, 2008.
Micro Summary: Mary Shepard Greene Blumenschein (1869-1958), accomplished American artist trained in New York and Paris, painted this portrait of Louisa Fletcher in 1912, depicting the daughter of Indianapolis banker Stoughton Fletcher and former wife of Hoosier author Booth Tarkington (divorced 1911). Blumenschein, who studied at Pratt Institute and won awards at the Paris Salon and St. Louis Exposition, presents Louisa as an assured, engaging figure in a fashionable empire-cut gown, reflecting the friendship and mutual interest in art shared between artist and subject. The work demonstrates Blumenschein's professional accomplishment during a period when she taught at Pratt Institute and provided illustrations for major magazines including Century, McClure's, and American, before moving to New Mexico in 1913 with her sculptor husband Ernest Blumenschein.

Title: The Seiner (The Net)
Artwork Description: Otto Stark is the only one of the Hoosier Group to study in Paris, Academie Julian. He is at his most Impressionist in The Seiner. His work screams French, not like those from Munich. This is an unusual style for him with its glaring color and broken brushstroke. The Seiner is among the most experimental productions of the Indiana artists. Stark is the only one of the Hoosier Group to remain devoted to figure painting, and he found a way to do it economically. He found models among his family, friends, and whomever he could cajole to pose for him. Stark's figures are well and carefully drawn, more solidly rendered than their surrounding scenery. This is a local boy, F. Rusterholz, fishing in the shallows of the Whitewater River, according to Stark family documents. The Seiner remained unexhibited until after the artist's death, although a more conservative watercolor entitled Fisherboy was widely exhibited.
Artist Biography: Born 1859 - Indianapolis, Died 1926. "Impressionism to me means retaining the first impression which nature makes upon us and rendering this impression to the exclusion of details not so essential and vital." quote Otto Stark. Unlike the French counterparts - American Impressionists did not dissolve forms purely into color and light, but maintained a close attachment to the subject matter. The oldest of seven children, he was born into a family of Old World craftsmen. He studied in Cincinnati and moved to New York City in 1879 to further his education. While there he worked under the direction of William Merritt Chase on landscapes, portraits, and figures. Otto Stark was the only one of the Hoosier Group to study in Paris. Paris in 1885 was awhirl with the dancing light of Impressionism. However, the official schools were intent upon the preservation of traditional art within narrow aesthetic bounds. He attended the Academie Julian as it was a haven for students concerned with the restrictions of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts, the cost, or unable to pass the entrance examination. While in Paris he studied with Lefebvre, Boulanger, and Cormon. In 1886 he married Marie Nitschelm. After three years in Paris, he and Marie and their one year old son moved to New York City. By 1891 they were the parents of four children. Marie died that same year and Stark brought his children to Indianapolis for his father and sister to care for. He opened a studio in 1894 in Indianapolis where he taught classes in oil and watercolor. In 1894 the Exhibit of Summer Work at the Art Association of Indianapolis by Otto Stark, T. C. Steele, William Forsyth, R.B. Gruelle and Ottis Adams was renamed Five Hoosier Painters and moved to Chicago. The Chicago art critics were warmly receptive to these artists and praised them for their individuality, vitality, and freshness of approach. Consistent with his Impressionistic emphasis on subject matter, Stark's work had been drawn from his everyday experiences of sleeping babies and playing children. Otto Stark was a member of the Manual Training School faculty and later taught at John Herron Art Institute, mostly a Saturday school at that time. He instructed his students to keep drawing paper handy at all times and draw everything - their homes, families, and friends. "Most people of Indiana don't realize what he did for the art world of Indiana. He inspired all of us to go to New York. He kept abreast of New York, Chicago, and Paris. He had an independent reputation on the East coast." quote by Elmer Taflinger, an Indianapolis artist. Only Otto Stark of the Hoosier Group remained devoted to figure painting and he found a way to do it economically. In 1913 he was commissioned to paint two large murals at IPS #60 (9' by 12'). In 1914 he was hired to paint murals at Indianapolis City Hospital - along with Forsyth, Steele, Adams, and others. These artists worked for house painters' wages. It was generally felt their best work was before 1905. They were better painters when working together. His paintings can be found at the Indiana State House, University of Kansas, and Cincinnati Art Museum.
Tour Guidance: Learning to Look or Highlights: Visual elements of art - line, light and color, and texture. Does the picture tell a story? Weather or Not: What time of year is it? What time of day is it? What sounds do you hear? Let's go on vacation: Travel to the country. American History Tour: Influence of Impressionism.
Connections: Winslow Homer, The Boat Builders - The shape of the hat, the fact the face is hidden, use of everyday people. The other Hoosier Group works - Use of color, subject matter, style.
Sources/Bibliography: Krause, Martin, The Passage Return of Indiana painters from Germany 1880 - 1905. Newton, Judith, The Hoosier Group. Warkel, Harriet, Martin Krause, and S.L. Berry, The Herron Chronicle.
Micro Summary: "The Seiner" by Otto Stark showcases the artist's most Impressionist style, featuring bold colors and broken brushstrokes that reflect his unique training at Paris's Academie Julian rather than the typical Munich influence of his Hoosier Group contemporaries. The painting depicts a local boy, F. Rusterholz, fishing in Indiana's Whitewater River, demonstrating Stark's commitment to figure painting using family and friends as economical models. This experimental work remained unexhibited during Stark's lifetime, making it one of the most adventurous productions among Indiana artists of the period.

Title: Diana
Artwork Description: Diana was designed to be a weathervane placed atop Stanford White's new Madison Square Garden in New York. The monumental gilt bronze figure became a popular success and the sculptor made many smaller-scale copies. The IMA's version shows the graceful, idealized lines and naturalistic forms of the Beaux-Arts style that Saint-Gaudens employed for his only nude female figure. The original eighteen-foot figure of Diana was much too cumbersome and unbalanced to remain as a weathervane. A smaller thirteen-foot version was made and placed on the building, where it remained until the structure was demolished and the statue acquired by the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
Artist Biography: Dublin-native Augustus Saint-Gaudens was raised in New York City after his Irish mother and French father immigrated to America when he was six months old. He took classes at the Cooper Union and the National Academy of Design before traveling to Paris, where he studied at the École des Beaux Arts. He also studied art and architecture in Rome. Upon his return to the United States, Saint-Gaudens received critical acclaim for his monuments commemorating heroes of the American Civil War and his numerous funerary monuments and busts. His colossal Standing Lincoln in Lincoln Park, Chicago, is considered one of the finest portrait statues in America. It was followed by a seated statue of the president in Chicago's Grant Park, a copy of which was placed by Lincoln's tomb. Saint-Gaudens was an important teacher, tutoring privately and at the Art Students League of New York. He is also known for his portrait medallions and coin designs. Later in life, he founded the Cornish Colony in New Hampshire, which attracted numerous painters, architects, and sculptors, including Paul Manship, Thomas Wilmer Dewing, and the illustrator Maxfield Parrish. His house and gardens are preserved as Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Dryfhout, John H. The Work of Augustus Saint-Gaudens. Lebanon, New Hampshire: University Press of New England, 2008.
Micro Summary: Augustus Saint-Gaudens created "Diana" as a weathervane for Stanford White's Madison Square Garden in New York. The monumental gilt bronze figure exemplifies the graceful, idealized lines of the Beaux-Arts style and was Saint-Gaudens' only nude female sculpture. The original eighteen-foot version proved too cumbersome for its intended purpose, so a smaller thirteen-foot version replaced it on the building. The sculpture became widely popular, leading Saint-Gaudens to create many smaller-scale copies like the one in the IMA's collection.

Title: Girl Sweeping
Artwork Description: Artist shows his subject in a domestic setting as a maid. Paxton's fine brushstrokes and refined style are evident in this small painting. Our painting is a smaller version with the same title as one Paxton completed in 1911 (40x30), oil on canvas. The room setting is slightly different. The IMA held a retrospective of Paxton's work in 1979. These works were included in the show. The catalogue for the exhibit was written by Ellen W. Lee of the IMA staff with remarks by Martin Krause. The artist admired the Dutch School of painters who often chose servants as their subject.
Artist Biography: Paxton was born in Baltimore, Maryland but grew up outside Boston. He set out for Paris when he was only age 20. He studied under the master painter Gerome while in Europe. Upon his return to New England he attended the Boston School and became associated with Tarbell and Benson. Paxton soon became a prominent member of the group. In 1906 Paxton became an Instructor at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. He admired such artists as Velasquez, Vermeer and Inges. He also taught his wife Okie Paxton and together they changed the art scene forever. Paxton is known for depicting genteel New England women in well appointed parlors. Writers in the early 20th century admired his technique, the clever brushwork, and the good taste of the group known as the "Tarbellites. They deplored the emphasis upon elegant accessories, referring to the paintings as "parlor pictures." Our painting Girl Sweeping is an exception from this theory since it shows a domestic servant. However it clearly shows very expensive articles around the room of the owner. Paxton passed away in 1941.
Tour Guidance: Discuss how this compares to the Dutch School in subject matter. Compare Paxton and his style with his fellow colleagues Tarbell and Benson.
Connections: Subject matter in the Ash Can School. Compare the girl with the broom in Rockwell's illustration The Love Song. Discuss how the artist was influenced by Vermeer. Compare with Millet for subject matter. Compare with English/American portraits for subject. Compare with Dutch Baroque pieces for treatment of light. Compare with Pont Aven women with Breton hats.
Sources/Bibliography: IMA collection information. Ellen W. Lee exhibition catalogue, 1979.
Micro Summary: Girl Sweeping depicts a domestic servant in an elegant interior, showcasing Paxton's fine brushwork and Boston School style. This smaller version of his 1911 painting reflects his admiration for Dutch masters who painted servants. The work stands apart from typical Paxton parlor pictures while still displaying the expensive surroundings that characterized his oeuvre.

Title: New York, New Haven and Hartford
Lake Shawangunk
Artwork Description: This panoramic view captures the atmosphere and luminous colors of the Catskills in autumn. The light-filled sky reflected in the water may be a metaphor for spiritual and physical harmony. A tiny image of a boat in the center of the lake leaves a trail of ripples in the water. In 1863, Whittredge painted several works, including Lake Shawangunk, which revealed Gifford's influence in their panoramic scope and luminous colors. This canvas captures the crisp atmosphere and color of the Catskills in autumn. It also suggests the Hudson River School's response to pantheism, the belief that the deity is present in every detail of creation. The light-filled sky and its reflection in the smooth river could be viewed as a metaphor of spiritual and physical harmony. In this context, the canoe, poised at the apex of an arrow-shaped wake, may represent man's spiritual aspirations.
Artist Biography: Worthington Whittredge, as he called himself after 1855, was born on a farm in Springfield, Ohio. He moved to Cincinnati in 1837, worked with his brother-in-law as a house painter, and taught himself to paint portraits and landscapes. He experimented with daguerreotypes in Indianapolis, opened a portrait studio in Charlestown, West Virginia, and then returned to Cincinnati. From 1843 on, he devoted himself to landscapes. Through the efforts of wealthy Cincinnati art patron Nicholas Longworth, Whittredge was able to study for five years in Düsseldorf, Germany. He also spent five years in Rome before returning to the United States in 1859. Whittredge settled in New York City, where he opened a studio. He experienced some difficulty adapting his European skills to the American scene. The quality of light seemed different to Whittredge, who was accustomed to the frequently overcast skies of central Germany. His search for an American style was aided by the example of Sanford Gifford, whom he had known in Düsseldorf and Rome.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Cheryl A. Cibulka. Quiet Places: The American Landscapes of Worthington Whittredge, Washington, D. C.: Adams Davidson Galleries, Inc., 1982. ASIN: B000KBJREO
Micro Summary: "Lake Shawangunk" by American artist Worthington Whittredge presents a panoramic autumn view of the Catskills, characterized by luminous colors and crisp atmospheric effects that reveal the influence of fellow Hudson River School painter Sanford Gifford. The composition features a light-filled sky reflected in smooth water, creating a metaphor for spiritual and physical harmony that aligns with the Hudson River School's pantheistic beliefs about divine presence in nature. At the center of the lake, a small boat creates rippling wakes in an arrow-shaped pattern, symbolically representing humanity's spiritual aspirations within the natural world. Painted in 1863, this work exemplifies the Hudson River School's romantic approach to American landscape painting and their philosophical connection between natural beauty and spiritual meaning.

Title: Polling Landscape
Artwork Description: Duveneck opened a school in Polling, Bavaria where he trained Americans who became known as the "Duveneck Boys." Polling Landscape exhibits principles of the Munich Academy's teaching and the French Barbizon artists—strong brushwork, the manipulation of dark tonalities, and a sketch-like quality. Duveneck absorbed the basic principles of the Munich Academy's teaching – strong brushwork and the manipulation of dark color tonalities, - but he later developed his own ideas, drawn from the practices of French Barbizon artists. This influence appears in Polling Landscape in the simple composition with its sketch-like quality. The brighter tonalities in this work have also been attributed to Duveneck's travel and work in Florence and Venice.
Artist Biography: Born in Covington, Kentucky, Frank Duveneck began his art training as an apprentice to a church decorator in Cincinnati before traveling to Munich to study at the Royal Academy. While there Duveneck shared a studio with William Merritt Chase. After returning to Cincinnati, he painted portraits, decorated churches and taught art classes. He returned to Europe and opened an art school in Munich and Polling in Bavaria where he trained Americans who became known as the "Duveneck Boys." He also opened a studio in Italy and spent winters in Florence and summers in Venice. His painting began to change from the dark interiors of his Munich style to the brighter palette of Impressionism, but much of his work continued to exhibit the style of his Munich training. At the turn of the century Duveneck returned to Cincinnati and taught at the Cincinnati Art Academy, spending summers in Gloucester, Massachusetts between trips to Italy, France, and Germany.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Michael Quick. American Painter Abroad: Frank Duveneck's European Years, Cincinnati: Cincinnati Art Museum, 1887. ISBN-13: 978-0931537073
Micro Summary: "Polling Landscape" by Frank Duveneck reflects the artistic principles he taught at his school in Polling, Bavaria, where he trained American students known as the "Duveneck Boys." The work demonstrates Munich Academy techniques through strong brushwork and dark tonalities, combined with French Barbizon influences evident in its simple composition and sketch-like quality. The painting's brighter tones reveal the impact of Duveneck's later travels and work in Florence and Venice. This piece exemplifies Duveneck's evolution from traditional Munich training toward his own distinctive artistic approach.

Title: U.S.A.
Artwork Description: Trompe l'oeil or 'trick the eye' is extremely detailed. Illusion is aided by shallow spatial format with clarity and precision. Produced about forty extremely detailed pieces between the mid-1880's and late 1890's. Investigated by the Secret Service for supposed counterfeiting. Use of wood grain paint on canvas to appear to be wood. Haberle's deteriorating eyesight forced him to give up painting.
Artist Biography: John Haberle was an American painter and lithographer, born in New Haven, Connecticut in 1856. He was the son of German immigrants and was apprenticed to a lithographer at the age of 14 and earned his livelihood in that field. His only formal training was at the National Academy of Design in 1884. He then founded the New Haven Sketch Club, gave art lessons and was active in art circles until about 1910. In the 1880's he worked for the Peabody Museum at Yale University, drawing illustrations for its publications. Haberle began to practice trompe l'oeil painting, a popular art form in America after the Civil War. He was unique in the precision of his trompe l'oeil in their subtle irony and wit. His work was so precise that one Chicago art critic accused Haberle of deception-of gluing objects to the canvas instead of painting them. Haberle's paintings are highly personal, with subtle meanings and visual puns. His work was ignored by the artistic establishment who thought his subject matter too commonplace. Haberle died in obscurity but his work was rediscovered in the 1950's by A. Frankenstein.
Tour Guidance: Compare to still lifes of the Dutch and Flemish masters for the use of vanitas. Discuss the use of visual puns in his work. Discuss technical skills and influence of engraving background.
Micro Summary: John Haberle's "U.S.A." exemplifies the trompe l'oeil technique, using extraordinary detail and precision to create visual illusions that trick the eye. The artwork demonstrates Haberle's mastery of shallow spatial formats and his ability to paint wood grain effects on canvas so convincingly that his work was investigated by the Secret Service for suspected counterfeiting. Created during Haberle's most productive period between the mid-1880s and late 1890s, this piece represents one of approximately forty extremely detailed works he completed before deteriorating eyesight forced him to abandon painting.

Title: Portrait of Mrs. Addison C. Harris
Artwork Description: Portrait painting depicting Mrs. Addison C. Harris. The work demonstrates Beaux's sophisticated handling of paint, her ability to capture both physical likeness and psychological presence, and her mastery of the society portrait format. Beaux's portraits often showed her subjects in moments of thoughtful repose.
Artist Biography: Cecilia Beaux (1855-1942) was one of the most successful American portrait painters of her generation. She studied at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts and in Paris. Beaux was the first woman to teach at the Pennsylvania Academy and received numerous prestigious commissions. She was highly respected in her time and compared favorably to John Singer Sargent.
Tour Guidance: Beaux was one of the most successful women artists of her era, breaking barriers to teach at the Pennsylvania Academy. Her portraits were sought after by prominent families and she received commissions comparable to those given to male artists like Sargent. She combined technical mastery with psychological insight in her portraiture.
Connections: Compare with other society portraits. Discuss Beaux's achievement as a woman artist in a male-dominated field. Note similarities and differences with Sargent's approach to portraiture. Connect to other portraits by women artists like Taggart.
Sources/Bibliography: Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts records. Documentation of Beaux's career and commissions.
Micro Summary: Beaux's portrait of Mrs. Addison C. Harris showcases the sophisticated technique that made her one of America's most successful portrait painters, often compared to John Singer Sargent. As the first woman instructor at Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, Beaux broke gender barriers while securing prestigious commissions from prominent families. Her work combines technical mastery learned in Paris with psychological insight, capturing subjects in moments of thoughtful repose.

Title: Afternoon – Yellow Room
Artwork Description: This painting focuses on a single female, and the play of light suggests calmness and serenity despite the 'busyness' of the surroundings – fabric patterns and dappled light. You get the feeling that you're looking in on a quiet, intimate, reflective moment. This is one of two versions of the same subject. The other painting is entitled Morning – Yellow Room, and it is at the Cincinnati Art Museum. Frieseke maintained that the light in the same location was always discernibly different depending on the time of day and the season of the year. The model used here is his wife. In later paintings his daughter, Frances – the light of his life – was often his subject.
Artist Biography: Frederick Carl Frieseke was born in Owosso, Michigan, in 1874. Evidence of his early interest in art was noted in that he often drew in the margins of his school books. Although he studied for short periods at the Art Institute of Chicago, the Art Students League in New York, and Academie Julian in Paris, Frieseke called himself a self-taught artist. He made no preparatory sketches of his work and took his inspiration for the picture straight to the canvas. In France he lived next door to Claude Monet, and he was considered the founder of the Giverny Group. Other members of the group were Richard E. Miller, Lawton Parker, Guy Rose, Edmund Greacen and Karl Anderson. They were sometimes referred to as the Giverny Luminists, and they found their Impressionist approach a liberation from the academic restraints of subject and style which was prevalent at the time. Frieseke's work is identified by his signature style: a single, voluptuous female figure (often nude) in colorful, intimate setting of dappled sunlight. He also had a strong predilection for decorative pattern, texture and accessories. His large, rounded women show the influence of Auguste Renoir. There are three identifiable periods of Frieseke's work: Early Period (Paris to Giverny – 1897 – 1905): Academic style and tonal approach show the influence of James McNeill Whistler. Giverny Period (1905 – 1920): Looser brushstrokes and lighter palette celebrating light, color and the female form evidence the Impressionist style. Normandy Period (1920 – 1939): His final stage shows a return to tonalist style with a more realistic approach and more restrained use of decorative pattern.
Tour Guidance: For Primary Tours: Women – Look at artists' depictions featuring a lone women in an intimate or isolated setting such as Afternoon Tea by Richard Miller, Dorothy by William Merritt Chase, Sunlight by Frank Benson, Red Kimono on the Roof by John Sloan, Tidying Up by Isabel Bishop, and Preparing for the Matinee by Edward Charles Tarbell. Sunlight – Look at treatment of sunlight in works such as The House of the Deaf Woman and the Belfry at Eragny by Camille Pissarro, Afternoon Tea by Richard Miller, and Sunlight by Frank Benson. For other tours: Compare Frieseke's rounded women with other similar renderings – Young Girls by Mary Cassatt or Tidying Up by Isabel Bishop. Contrast this setting with other renderings of women from other painting styles such as the unadorned background of Dorothy by William Merritt Chase, the loneliness of Hotel Lobby by Edward Hopper, or the candor of Mrs. MacDowell by Henry Raeburn.
Connections: Afternoon Tea by Richard Miller – This painting was done by one of Frieseke's contemporaries in the Giverny Group. Sunlight by Frank Benson – This painting too is distinguished by the artist's interpretation of sunlight and its play both on the landscape and on the subject.
Sources/Bibliography: Vogue, March 15, 1912; News Releases and Exhibit Catalog – Telfair Museum of Art, Savannah, Georgia, January 31, 2001; Artist File – Indianapolis Museum of Art; Ask Art
Micro Summary: Frederick C. Frieseke's "Afternoon – Yellow Room" depicts a serene female figure, modeled by his wife, in an intimate domestic setting filled with patterned fabrics and dappled light. The painting captures a quiet, reflective moment that conveys calmness despite the visual complexity of the surroundings. This work is one of two versions exploring the same subject, with its companion piece "Morning – Yellow Room" housed at the Cincinnati Art Museum. Frieseke was particularly interested in how light changed throughout different times of day and seasons, demonstrating this fascination through these paired paintings.

Title: Portrait of Dr. Lewis D. Lyons
The Bacidae
Artwork Description: The Bacidae was part of a series of salon pictures. It shows two priestesses of Baccis, a noted soothsayer, who studied the entrails of birds to make his predictions. Haruspices, or haruspex in singular form, are people seasoned to carry out a type of divination known as Haruspicy. Haruspicy is a divination that uses natural phenomenon such as lightning and this practice also uses the internal organs or innards of animal sacrifices. Haruspices examine intestines and livers of, mostly but not restricted to, sheep and poultry. Another term for Haruspicy is Extispicy. The painting represents an old priestess initiating a new (and alarmed) member of the order. This large canvas was exhibited at the 1883 Paris Salon. Dodson received praise for her technique, which was described as "virile in color and draftsmanship, powerful without exaggeration, masculine without straining." The Bacidae became the artist's best-known work.
Artist Biography: Sarah Dodson started drawing at the age of three, making pictures of stories told to her by her family. Her father, who himself was an illustrator an engraver and portraitist, did not approve of this hobby. So, she did not study art until after his death in 1872. She attended the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts but spent most of her life in Europe, painting religious and historical subjects as well as landscapes. It was difficult for women to establish themselves as professional painters, but Dodson exhibited several times in the Salons of Paris and Munich as well as in her hometown of Philadelphia.
Tour Guidance: Q1: When you think of Greece and the contributions of the Greeks to the arts, literature, and science do you think of divination as a major Greek culture contribution? Why do you think Sarah Dodson chose this subject? Q2: Today with 24/7 news cycle who would some say are the soothsayers? Q3: Sarah Dodson was devoted to her art; she did not marry and have a family. As you look at the young woman in the painting do you get the sense that SD is projecting herself as a woman artist in the late 1800's?
Connections: The masterworks of the Clowes Collection.
Sources/Bibliography:
Gallati, "Paintings of Sarah Paxton Ball Dodson," The American Art Journal, Winter 1983
http://collection.imamuseum.org/artwork/55841/
Micro Summary: Sarah Paxton Ball Dodson (1847-1906) was a Philadelphia-born painter who overcame her father's disapproval to study at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts after his death, eventually establishing herself in European art circles. "The Bacidae" (1883), her most celebrated work, depicts an ancient Greek divination ritual where an elder priestess initiates a younger woman into the practice of haruspicy—reading omens from bird entrails. Exhibited at the 1883 Paris Salon to critical acclaim, this ambitious historical painting showcases Dodson's ability to navigate the male-dominated art world of the late 19th century while exploring themes of female knowledge transmission and ancient spiritual practices.

Title: Landscape with Covered Wagon
Artwork Description: The path, covered wagon and pioneers, suggest the future cultivation of this landscape. The unspoiled wilderness becomes both a haven for spiritual contemplation and a Promised Land to be settled by the pioneers. Durand was a leader of the Hudson River School. Landscape with Covered Wagon displays a compositional type favored by Thomas Cole in his more allegorical works. Despite its obvious emphasis on nature, the painting is a metaphor for the young nation, illustrating the popular theme of immigrants confronting the New World. On the left is the primeval forest, often interpreted as both an untamed realm and a haven for contemplation by American philosophers and poets such as William Cullen Bryant. The right side shows the New Eden, the proverbial Promised Land, the place for future pioneer settlement.
Artist Biography: Asher Brown Durand was born in Maplewood, New Jersey (known then as Jefferson Village). He was apprenticed to an engraver, eventually becoming part owner of the firm. He engraved Declaration of Independence for John Trumbull in 1823, which established Durand's reputation as a printmaker. Durand was a founding member of the National Academy of Design. His interest in oil painting began around 1830 with the encouragement of his patron, Luman Reed. In 1837, Durand accompanied his friend and colleague Thomas Cole on a sketching expedition to Schroon Lake in the Adirondacks, which increased his interest in becoming a landscape painter. He spent summers sketching in the Catskills, Adirondacks, and the White Mountains of New Hampshire. Durand was a strong advocate for drawing directly from nature in a truthful manner. He became the leader of the Hudson River School after the death of its founder Thomas Cole.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Durand, John. The Life and Times of Asher B. Durand. Hensonville, NY: Black Dome Press Corporation, 2006. Ferber, Linda. Kindred Spirits: Asher B. Durand and the American Landscape. South Humberside, England: D. Giles, Ltd., 2007
Micro Summary: Asher Brown Durand's "Landscape with Covered Wagon" depicts pioneers with their wagon traversing between a primeval forest on the left and an open, promising landscape on the right. As a leader of the Hudson River School, Durand creates a metaphor for America's westward expansion, showing the transition from untamed wilderness to future settlement. The composition contrasts the dark, contemplative forest with the bright "New Eden" of the Promised Land. The painting embodies the 19th-century American theme of pioneers confronting and transforming the New World landscape.

Title: Scene on the Wabash (Winter)
Artwork Description: Winter's winter landscapes often convey both harshness and serenity. 'Scene on the Wabash (Winter)' captures the frozen river and stark trees of Indiana with subtle tonal variations and soft brushwork. The composition evokes stillness, emphasizing Winter’s romantic appreciation of the regional landscape while preserving documentary accuracy.
Artist Biography: George Winter was born in Portsea, England, in 1810, and studied art at the Royal Academy before immigrating to the United States in 1830. Settling in Logansport, Indiana, he became one of the earliest painters to document the life of Native Americans in the Great Lakes region. His depictions of the Miami and Potawatomi tribes provide invaluable visual records of their lives before forced removal. Winter is recognized as one of the foremost early Indiana artists, bridging topographical precision with painterly atmosphere.
Tour Guidance: Use this painting to discuss early Indiana landscape painting and the artist’s documentary work of the Wabash region. Ask visitors to consider how Winter’s environment influenced his technique and palette. Compare to later American landscapes that emphasize emotion over documentation.
Connections: Compare with Worthington Whittredge’s 'Summer Pastorale' for Hudson River School influence, and with Thomas Cole’s works for early American romanticism.
Sources/Bibliography: IMA Stout Library Artist Files; Judith Vale Newton & Carol Ann Weiss, 'Skirting the Issue: Stories of Indiana’s Historical Women Artists', Indiana Historical Society, 2004.
Micro Summary: George Winter’s 'Scene on the Wabash (Winter)' portrays the frozen Indiana landscape in quiet naturalism. It combines documentary realism with romantic restraint, revealing his fascination with regional life and nature.

Title: Temptation
Artwork Description: Temptation exemplifies Guy's command of dramatic lighting effects and varied textures. It tells the simple story of a young girl teasing an infant by dangling a strawberry in front of the baby, who eagerly reaches for the sumptuous treasure. Guy deftly renders the baby's playfulness, soft skin, and the intricate details of the Victorian rattle, as well as the mischievous character of the little girl. From the powdery green color of the girl's dress to the velvet pillow, Guy created for his viewers a soothing, reassuring environment devoid of a single sharp angle or harsh contrast.
Artist Biography: Seymour Guy was born and raised in England where he studied art before immigrating to New York City in 1854. When Guy arrived in America, he was already a mature painter specializing in everyday scenes of children. The Victorian art-buying public favored works depicting children, especially those that celebrated middle-class life. His work has a smooth, glossy surface, rich colors, and crisp details. Guy may have acquired his polished style by copying the paintings of seventeenth-century Dutch masters in London. Guy described his method: "I paint up a simple story, trying to get into it as much beauty as possible from color, light, and shade."
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Edwards, Lee M. Domestic Bliss: Family Life in American Painting 1840-1910. Yonkers, New York: Hudson River Museum, 1986. Lubin, David M. Picturing a Nation: Art and Social Change in Nineteenth-Century America. New Haven, Connecticut: Yale University Press, 1994.
Micro Summary: "Temptation" by Seymour Joseph Guy depicts a playful scene of a young girl teasingly dangling a strawberry before an eager infant who reaches for it. The artist demonstrates masterful use of dramatic lighting and texture rendering, capturing the baby's soft skin and playful nature alongside the girl's mischievous character. Guy creates a soothing Victorian domestic environment through careful attention to details like the intricate rattle and velvet pillow. The composition features gentle colors and soft forms, avoiding harsh contrasts to maintain a reassuring atmosphere.

Title: Portrait of Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes
Portrait of Booth Tarkington
Artwork Description: James Montgomery Flagg created this painting of Hoosier author Booth Tarkington in just one day--August 19, 1916-- during a visit to Tarkington's summer home in Kennebunkport, Maine. Tarkington discussed the "zip-bang portrait" in a letter (transcribed below) to his friend Julian Street written the day after the portrait session. Tarkington was impressed with Flagg's lyrical use of color and his ability to capture Tarkington's spirit-- his "almost vicious mental energy"-- in such a brief sitting. Tarkington lightly pokes fun at "critic stuff" in the letter to Street, but his interest in art was deep. He was an art collector himself, and he was a trustee and supporter of the John Herron Art Institute, forerunner of the Indianapolis Museum of Art. Tarkington and Street worked together with producer George C. Tyler from 1915 to 1917 on their co-authored play "The Country Cousin," which Tarkington discusses toward the end of the letter (where he refers to Tyler as "G.C.T."). Their play finally opened at the Gaiety Theater in New York in September 1917.
Artist Biography: James Montgomery Flagg – American 1877-1960. Flagg was a renowned illustrator in addition to his activities as a portraitist. He created the famous "I Want You" image used as a recruitment poster in World War I.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Booth Tarkingto's letter to Julian Street (from the Julian Street Papers, Princeton University Library) Aug 20 '16 Dear Julian: – Flagg came over yesterday and painted the most zip-bang portrait of a Nawthur—me. Darn ugly messy-faced chap sitting in great concentration at littered desk—summer clothes—author's body slouching down inside 'em—lazy body with almost vicious mental energy showing in the eyes. Homely as the feller is, the picture is beautiful—color managed so that a "lyric" (critic stuff) quality is there as much as if it were the portrait of some lovely woman. It's one of these things you stand before & say, "Holy Mike, but he has done it!" Altogether Flagg's too as distinctively as his house, his car and his nose. He beats the devil—here's a one-day job that's ready for any gallery— Did G.C.T. send you new script? He seems altogether pleased—thinks plum right; peruse his note after reading & deduce. Be careful to read it as a thing played—The new type "Nancy" is to be just the least bit puzzling in earlier scenes with "George"—perhaps she affects her naïveté: She does, in fact. N.B.T.
Micro Summary: James Montgomery Flagg painted this portrait of acclaimed Hoosier author Booth Tarkington in a single day during a 1916 visit to Tarkington's Maine summer home. Tarkington was impressed by Flagg's rapid yet skillful execution, praising the artist's "lyrical use of color" and ability to capture his subject's "almost vicious mental energy" in one brief sitting. The author, who was himself an art collector and supporter of the Indianapolis Museum of Art, documented his enthusiasm for this "zip-bang portrait" in a letter to his friend and collaborator Julian Street. This artwork represents a meeting of two prominent American creative figures at the height of their careers.

Title: The Robe
Artwork Description: Frieseke is known for his juxtaposition of varied colors and patterns. Here floral motifs and stripes are combined with the freely brushed design of the lingerie. The solid blue carpet, brown floor and white window frame act as foils for the patterned interior. Painted five years after Afternoon – Yellow Room, The Robe still exhibits the strong patterning that defines Frieseke's work. Here, floral motifs and stripes are combined with the design of the figure's lingerie. The solid blue carpet, brown floor, and white window frame act as foils for the patterned interior.
Artist Biography: Frieseke was born in Michigan, yet he spent most of his time in France. He studied in more conservative Parisian academies before turning to the progressive Impressionist idiom. Frieseke was the leader of the Giverny Group, which included American Impressionists, who lived in close proximity to Claude Monet. His garden villa at Giverny is the setting for most of his works depicting women at leisure, either seated in gardens or in sun rooms. According to Frieseke's own statement, he painted directly on the canvas without the aid of preliminary sketches.

Micro Summary: "The Robe" by Frederick Carl Frieseke showcases the artist's signature use of contrasting colors and patterns through a masterful combination of floral motifs, stripes, and decorative lingerie design. The composition features a patterned interior balanced against solid elements including a blue carpet, brown floor, and white window frame that serve as visual anchors. Painted five years after his notable work "Afternoon – Yellow Room," this piece demonstrates Frieseke's continued exploration of bold patterning and color juxtaposition. The artwork exemplifies his skill in harmonizing diverse decorative elements while maintaining visual coherence through careful placement of solid-colored surfaces.

Title: The Rainbow
Artwork Description: Strong use of light for drama. Religious undertones including passing storm, renewal, danger of nature vs. rainbow. Swedenborgianism – belief that objects exist in both the realm of the spiritual and the realm of the physical. Use of cows in paintings also is effect of Swedenborgianism. Man's struggle with nature. Affect of technology on landscape noted in the sense of industry in the background. Birds on the clearing side. Romantic and dramatic feel. Uses white as a way for the viewer to travel around the painting.
Artist Biography: Born in Newburgh, NY in 1825, died while traveling in Scotland, 1894. George Inness was born in Newburgh, NY into a successful family where his father was a grocer. The fifth of 13 children, Inness received his first artistic training with an itinerant artist, John Jesse Barker. Later, he apprenticed to work as an engraver in New York. More significant was his study with Regis-Francois Gignoux, a landscape painter, who introduced him to the works of the European master, specifically, Claude Lorrain. Inness traveled to Europe where he was greatly influenced by the Barbizon painters during his travels to France. Upon returning to America, Inness moved from New York, home of Hudson River School, to Medfield, MA where he could live in isolation and practice the loosely structured composition and rustic themes along with the sketch-like brushwork of the Barbizon. In the mid-1860s, he was introduced to the teachings of Emanuel Swedenborg. Swedenborgianism believes that all material objects are spiritually charged and that everything exists in both the earthly and spiritual realm. His belief in the Swedenborgianism ideals are evident in his painting, that, unlike the Hudson River School, do not imitate nature, but are infused with soft vibrating colors and gauzy paint surfaces. Inness was a member of the Society of American Artists and was widely exhibited in his life.
Tour Guidance: Compare/Contrast with Hudson River School: Compare use of light, Contrast subject matter, Contrast brushstrokes. Animals in Art: Cows, birds.
Connections: George Inness, Orange Road, Tarpen Springs. Alfred Bricher, Morning at Grand Manan. Compare with Dutch landscapes and seascapes in European such as the Cuyp and Pissarro.
Micro Summary: "The Rainbow" by George Inness (1825-1894) depicts a dramatic landscape scene following a storm, with religious and spiritual undertones reflecting the artist's Swedenborgian beliefs that objects exist in both physical and spiritual realms. The painting contrasts the danger and renewal of nature through the juxtaposition of dark storm clouds and the hopeful rainbow, while incorporating symbolic elements like cows and birds that align with his spiritual philosophy. Inness uses dramatic lighting and strategic placement of white to guide the viewer's eye through the composition, creating a romantic atmosphere that explores humanity's relationship with nature. The work also subtly addresses the impact of industrialization on the natural landscape, visible through hints of industry in the background.

Title: November Morning
Artwork Description: This painting's introspective mood, harmonious colors and peaceful, open scene are prime examples of American Tonalism. The artist wanted his lanscapes to be evocations of states of mind.Tryon's favorite subject was a stand of trees in a barren field at twilight. Tryon's favorite subject was a stand of trees in a barren field at twilight or just after sunrise. November Morning is lighter in color and freer in execution than most of his treatments of this motif. While it may be reminiscent of Impressionist landscapes, such as Monet's scenes of poplar trees, the intentions of the two artists were radically different. Tryon despised the naturalism of the Impressionists, as his landscapes are evocations of states of mind rather than depictions of nature. Such landscapes are examples of Tonalism, a style in which muted colors and peaceful, open scenes create introspective moods. In keeping with this attitude, Tryon composed his paintings in his studio from memory. With their subtle color harmonies and sense of gentle melancholy, Tryon's works are prime examples of American Tonalism. After 1890, Impressionism began to displace the Barbizon aesthetic in America, and it was inevitable that the two schools should eventually affect each other. Whether intentional or not, November Morning reflects the influence of Impressionism
Artist Biography: Dwight Tryon was born in Hartford, Connecticut, and displayed his artistic talent at an early age. He was forced to defer an art career to support his widowed mother. While working in a bookstore, he began painting scenes along the Connecticut River. He went to France with his wife in 1876 to study art at the École des Beaux Arts and spent the summer in the village of Barbizon, where he was inspired by the area's quiet pastoral landscape. After returning to America, Tryon opened a summer studio in Dartmouth, Massachusetts, in 1883. His paintings from this period are twilight and evening scenes executed in a manner that was influenced by the Barbizon School. His palette changed in the 1890s, as he employed soft, luminous, and bright colors. Tryon became director of the Art School at Smith College and was instrumental in developing their art collection.

Sources/Bibliography: Caffin, Charles H. The Art of Dwight W. Tryon: An Appreciation.
Micro Summary: "November Morning" by Dwight William Tryon exemplifies American Tonalism through its muted colors, peaceful open scene, and introspective mood designed to evoke states of mind rather than depict nature realistically. The painting features Tryon's favorite motif of trees in a barren field, but is lighter in color and freer in execution than his typical treatments of this subject. While the work may appear reminiscent of Impressionist landscapes like Monet's poplar scenes, Tryon despised Impressionist naturalism and composed his paintings from memory in his studio to create gentle melancholy rather than natural observation. The piece reflects the inevitable influence of Impressionism on American art after 1890, even as it maintains the subtle color harmonies characteristic of Tonalist philosophy.

Title: Orange Road, Tarpon Springs
Artwork Description: In the hazy, vaporous atmosphere of this painting, Inness tried to meld the natural and spiritual worlds. Inness followed the teachings of the Swedish mystic Emanuel Swedenborg, who theorized that objects in the material world exist in a parallel spiritual realm. In his late paintings, such as Orange Road, Tarpon Springs, painted a year before his death, Inness achieved the melding of natural and spiritual realms that he sought. A stand of three trees seems to limit the composition's recession into space, enhancing the rich surface texture and the sense of hazy, vaporous atmosphere that is unique to Inness. While no human presence intrudes upon his mystical landscape, the setting is charged with the artist's reverence for nature.
Artist Biography: Born in Orange County, New York, near Newburgh on the Hudson, Inness loved the countryside. During his years of self-training, Inness followed the Hudson River School style of landscape painting, but when he reached the age of thirty, he went to Paris and encountered the work of the French Barbizon painters. His style changed from the panoramic landscapes of his youth to the "controlled atmospheres" of his mature work. A deeply religious man, Inness followed the teachings of the Swedish mystic Emanuel Swedenborg, who theorized that objects in the material world have correspondences in a parallel realm of the spirit. In the latter part of his life, Inness spent much time at Tarpon Springs, Florida, where he maintained a winter home, Rose Villa, and a studio, which he spoke of as a "loft."
