Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Bell, Adrienne Baxter. George Inness and the Visionary Landscape. New York: George Braziller Inc., 2007. DeLue, Rachel Ziady. George Inness and the Science of Landscape Painting. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2007.
Micro Summary: In this late work painted a year before his death, George Inness creates a hazy, atmospheric landscape that reflects his spiritual beliefs influenced by Swedish mystic Emanuel Swedenborg. The painting depicts Orange Road in Tarpon Springs through a vaporous atmosphere where Inness sought to merge the natural and spiritual worlds. A stand of three trees limits the spatial recession, emphasizing the rich surface texture and mystical quality of the scene. Though devoid of human figures, the landscape is imbued with Inness's deep reverence for nature and represents his successful achievement of blending material and spiritual realms.

Title: Brook in Summer
Artwork Description: This elaborate pastoral landscape with its background mountains shows the artist's skill at depicting a variety of foliage touched by autumn colors and bright sunlight. Brook in Summer is probably a composite of sketches of the Indianapolis countryside and views invented by Cox. Brook in Summer reflects Cox's high regard for traditional, pastoral landscapes filled with lush scenery and soft light. Cox varies the format of the traditional landscape by placing the trees, bushes and fallen branches randomly, as they appear in nature, rather than in an idealized order. This setting is probably a composite of sketches of the Indianapolis countryside and views invented by Cox.
Artist Biography: Jacob Cox was born in Burlington New Jersey, the first of ten children born to a Quaker couple who died in separate ferry accidents. Cox's grandfather and aunt in Washington, Pennsylvania became his guardians. By that time the young Cox was already interested in art. He was apprenticed to a tinsmith at the age of sixteen. In 1830, Cox and his brother established a tinsmith shop, first in Pittsburgh and later in Indianapolis. The business prospered forcing Cox to pursue his painting during his spare time. By 1835 painting portraits was added to Cox's business. Cox closed his shop and traveled to Cincinnati to study with John Dunn, returning to Indianapolis to paint portraits of such local notables as Senator Oliver Smith, Governors David Wallace and Noah Noble, State Treasurer Samuel Merrill, and numerous prominent businessmen and their families. His success enabled Cox to travel to New York City to study briefly at the National Academy of Design. Upon his return, he found time to add landscapes and still life to his repertoire. When the Indiana School of Art was established in Indianapolis in 1877, Cox became one of its teachers. He continued to paint and exhibit until his death at eighty one.

Micro Summary: "Brook in Summer" by Jacob Cox is an elaborate pastoral landscape that showcases the artist's mastery in depicting varied foliage with autumn colors and bright sunlight against a mountainous background. The work reflects Cox's appreciation for traditional pastoral scenes filled with lush scenery and soft lighting. Rather than idealizing nature, Cox presents trees, bushes, and fallen branches in their natural, random arrangement. The landscape is likely a composite creation combining sketches from the Indianapolis countryside with the artist's invented scenic elements.

Title: Portrait of William Merritt Chase
Artwork Description: Full-length oil on canvas portrait, 1881-1882, 78 x 38 inches. Depicts fellow artist William Merritt Chase in an imposing standing pose. The portrait demonstrates Beckwith's training in the French academic tradition and his skill at capturing both physical likeness and personality. Gift of the Artist.
Artist Biography: James Carroll Beckwith (1852-1917) was born in Hannibal, Missouri, and moved with his parents to Chicago, where he enrolled at the Chicago Academy of Design. The family moved to New York City in 1871, and he enrolled in the antique class at the National Academy of Design. In 1873, he sailed to England and spent the next five years living primarily in Paris, studying in the studio of portraitist Emile Carolus-Duran. He also enrolled in the Académie Suisse.
Tour Guidance: This portrait represents the close relationships within the American art community studying in Europe during the late 19th century. Both Beckwith and Chase were part of the circle of American artists training in Paris and Munich. The full-length format and confident pose reflect European portrait traditions adapted to American subjects.
Connections: Compare with Hendricks' Dr. Kool for full-length portrait format across different eras. Connect to other portraits of artists by artists. Note the influence of French academic training on American portraiture. Examine relationship between American artists abroad.
Sources/Bibliography: Gift of the Artist. National Academy of Design records. Documentation of American artists in Paris.
Micro Summary: Beckwith's full-length portrait of fellow artist William Merritt Chase demonstrates the French academic training both painters received in Paris during the 1870s-80s. Studying under portraitist Emile Carolus-Duran and at the Académie Suisse, Beckwith captures Chase's confident personality in the 78-inch canvas. The work reflects the close-knit community of American artists training abroad and adapting European portrait traditions to American subjects.

Title: Eleanor
Artwork Description: Eleanor, 1921, oil on canvas. Painted in NY 1921 when Lucy part of active artist community in East. Cecilia Beaux's influence shown in bright colors of dress and fan and pensive quality associated with Boston School Impressionism in Eleanor's face. Subject unknown if friend, family or model.
Artist Biography: Lucy Taggart, American (1880-1960). Born Indianapolis 1880, second of six children of Thomas and Eva Taggart. Father's fortune grew with career including county, state, national chairman posts Democratic Party, three terms mayor Indianapolis, appointed U.S. Senator, ownership of at least four hotels including French Lick Springs Hotel. Enrolled William Forsythe's classes John Herron Art School 1906-1909. Age 19 moved to NYC to study with William Merritt Chase. Also studied under Charles W. Hawthorne, Cecilia Beaux and sculptor Harriet Frishmuth. Working career 1905-1929.
Tour Guidance: Creative Hoosiers tour. Her Story: Women Artists of the IMA tour. American Art Spotlight Tour.
Connections: How mirror is used in Eleanor compared to Edmund Tarbell's Preparing for the Matinee, Isabella Bishop's Tidying Up, Jacob Lawrence's The Birth.
Sources/Bibliography: Judith Vale Newton. Skirting the Issue: Stories of Indiana's Historical Women Artists, 2004: 244-248. James Philip Fadely "Subtle Grace, Radiant Color: The Life of Hoosier Artist Lucy Taggart," Traces of Indiana and Midwestern History 9, no. 3 (summer 1997):18.
Micro Summary: Lucy Taggart (1880-1960), Indianapolis-born American artist and daughter of prominent Democratic Party leader and French Lick Springs Hotel owner Thomas Taggart, painted Eleanor in 1921 in New York during her active period within the eastern artist community. Taggart, who studied under William Forsyth at John Herron Art School and with William Merritt Chase, Charles W. Hawthorne, and Cecilia Beaux, demonstrates Beaux's influence through the bright colors of the dress and fan and the pensive quality associated with Boston School Impressionism. This oil on canvas portrait, which won the Merit Award for figure composition at the inaugural 1925 Hoosier Salon exhibition, showcases Taggart's "subtle grace and wealth of radiant color" that earned her recognition beyond her prominent family connections, exemplifying her proficiency in portraiture that established her as a respected artist who worked from studios in Indianapolis, Hyannis Port, French Lick, and Gloucester before becoming a teacher and influential board member at John Herron Art School.

Title: Joan of Arc
Artwork Description: In Joan of Arc, Melchers chooses a peasant girl to become the martyred saint. In her simple dress, the young girl is surrounded by a field of sheep. A delicate halo refers to her spiritual calling, while her staff and blanket suggest a more earthly profession.
Artist Biography: Painter and muralist Gari Melchers was born in Detroit. He was the son of a wood carver and sculptor, who gave him his first drawing lessons. At seventeen, his father sent him abroad to study at the Dusseldorf Academy. He also studied at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris. He became an expatriate when he lived in Egmond, Holland, for sixteen years, sharing a studio with the American artist George Hitchcock. The people of Holland inspired his work and were his primary subjects. In 1909, he settled in Weimer, Germany, but returned to America at the start of World War I. Melchers made his home at "Belmont," near Fredericksburg, Virginia, where he continued to paint in a naturalist style mingled with Impressionism, using thick impasto, a bright palette, and strong colors. Melchers was interested in depicting the ordinary lives of average people, but he also painted peasants as biblical figures in contemporary settings.

Sources/Bibliography: Melchers, Gari, Diane Lesko, and Esther Persson. Gari Melchers: A Retrospective Exhibition. University of Washington Press, 1991.
Micro Summary: In Gari Melchers' "Joan of Arc," the artist depicts the famous saint as a humble peasant girl in simple clothing, surrounded by sheep in a pastoral setting. The composition balances earthly and divine elements, with a delicate halo symbolizing her spiritual calling while her staff and blanket reference her mundane shepherding duties. This portrayal emphasizes Joan's humble origins before her transformation into a religious and military leader. The work captures the moment between her ordinary life as a country girl and her extraordinary destiny as a martyred saint.

Title: Our Flag
Artwork Description: Our Flag is a striking example of Church's work and represents his ardent belief in the eventual triumph of the Union in the American Civil War. The flag of the Union remains intact and firmly in place on a craggy mountain peak far above the smoke of battle.
Artist Biography: Frederic Edwin Church is known as one of America's great landscape painters, bridging the era of the pioneering Hudson River Romantics and the late nineteenth century painters of the American West. The only pupil of Thomas Cole, with whom he studied from 1844-1846, the precocious Church was immediately successful and a full member of the National Academy of Design by the age of 24. He acquired an interest in the importance of nature as a force in itself, abandoning his teacher's allegories for a transcendentalist vision of both the North and the South American landscape. The writings and example of the great naturalist Baron von Humboldt helped direct Church both to new world subjects and a dramatic but naturalistic view of nature. Church later traveled through Europe, the Middle East and even to the Arctic, and his large-scale depictions of exotic locales made him one of the most successful artists in the country in the third quarter of the century. He lived in New York until his beloved Hudson River castle, Olana, was completed in the mid-70s and the majority of his later paintings are based on the scenery of that area and Northern New England. The artist's brushstroke also evolved through the years: an early painterliness was gradually replaced by a smoother surface, and the contours and edges assumed a more pronounced definition. Nevertheless, many of Church's landscapes retain all the emotional quality of Cole at his most dramatic and heroic.

Micro Summary: "Our Flag" by Frederic Edwin Church depicts the Union flag standing resolutely on a rocky mountain peak, positioned high above the smoke and chaos of Civil War battlefields below. The painting serves as a powerful symbol of Church's unwavering faith in the Union's ultimate victory during the American Civil War. Through this dramatic composition, Church presents the flag as an enduring beacon of hope and determination, suggesting that the Union cause will prevail despite the ongoing conflict.

Title: Poppies
Artwork Description: Poppies gives the effect of having been painted quickly and directly before the subject. At a distance, the choppy strokes and daubs of color resolve into a luminous floral landscape. Painted in France in 1888, this canvas is one of the earliest American responses to French Impressionism. During his second stay in France, Vonnoh painted Poppies, which is related to a large canvas of poppy fields in Flanders from the same year. Because of their intense hues, poppies were a favorite subject of the French Impressionists. Vonnoh's depiction of a poppy field in France gives the effect of having been painted quickly and directly before the subject. With no horizon or path for the eye to follow out of the foreground, Vonnoh's landscape seems to pitch forward, emphasizing the two-dimensional surface of the canvas. At a distance, the choppy strokes and daubs of pigment resolve into a luminous picture that incorporates the Impressionist techniques of broken brushwork and complementary colors. Poppies is one of the earliest paintings by an American Impressionist to rival the work of the French Impressionists.
Artist Biography: Robert Vonnoh may not be one of America's best-known Impressionist painters, but he was the first American artist to bring Impressionism to this country. Born in Hartford, Connecticut, in 1858, Vonnoh moved to Boston in his youth. He taught William Glackens, Robert Henri, and John Sloan, who became part of the group known as the Ashcan School. Vonnoh made numerous trips to France, first to study at the Académie Julian and later to settle in the area of Grèz-sur-Loing, near the Forest of Fontainebleau. Numerous paintings created in France were displayed at the Paris Salon. He also had a one-man show at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts and he was principal instructor in portrait and landscape painting at the Academy from 1891 to 1894. During his career, Vonnoh was considered one of the foremost landscape and portrait painters in America. For twenty-five years, he was part of the artists' colony at Old Lyme, Connecticut.

Micro Summary: Robert William Vonnoh's "Poppies" (1888) is one of the earliest American responses to French Impressionism, painted during the artist's second stay in France. The work depicts a poppy field using quick, choppy brushstrokes and daubs of color that resolve into a luminous floral landscape when viewed from a distance. With no horizon line or clear path for the eye, the composition emphasizes the two-dimensional surface of the canvas and creates a sense that the landscape pitches forward. The painting successfully incorporates key Impressionist techniques including broken brushwork and complementary colors, making it one of the first American Impressionist works to rival French examples of the movement.

Title: Still Life
Artwork Description: With thick strokes of the brush, Weir suggested the textures of porcelain, fabric, and food. This assemblage of fruit, vegetables, and tableware is unusual for Weir, who preferred landscapes. Weir helped form The Ten, a diverse group identified with American Impressionism. This still life, an ambitious assemblage of fruit, vegetables, and tableware, is unusual in Weir's oeuvre. With thick strokes of the brush, Weir suggested the textures of porcelain, fabric, and food and created a straightforward composition remarkably close in spirit to works of 19th-century French realists. However, the loose handling of the paint reflects a less formal interest in the subject than the earlier French painters had.
Artist Biography: J. Alden Weir was the youngest of 16 children of the artist Robert W. Weir. The younger Weir's art education began with training from his father. At 18, he enrolled at the National Academy School in New York and then studied in Paris at the Ecole des Beaux Arts. Weir began working directly from nature and soon came under the influence of French Impressionism. In the 1880s Weir focused on still-life painting along with landscape. He favored floral studies painted with a dark palette, which did not reflect his interest in Impressionism. Weir was also a portrait painter and married one of his models. He had a New York studio and supported himself with portrait painting and teaching. Weir became associated with the American Impressionists Childe Hassam and John Twachtman and was a founding member of the Society of American Artists, who rebelled against the strict academic standards of the National Academy of Design. Weir joined with his colleagues to form the Ten American Painters, a stylistically diverse organization usually identified with American Impressionism. Weir was one of the organizers of the 1913 Armory show in New York, which introduced avant-garde European art to the American public.

Micro Summary: James Alden Weir's "Still Life" depicts an assemblage of fruit, vegetables, and tableware using thick brushstrokes to suggest various textures of porcelain, fabric, and food. This work is unusual for Weir, who typically preferred landscapes over still life subjects. The composition reflects the spirit of 19th-century French realists but with looser paint handling characteristic of American Impressionism. Weir was a founding member of The Ten, a group associated with American Impressionism.

Title: Rondout, New York
Artwork Description: Twinkling lights on the distant shore mixed with dark tonal harmonies create a moody twilight landscape. The expressive, linear brushwork may have been derived from the study of Asian painting. Dabo described his landscapes as "pretexts for beautiful color arrangements." Dabo described his landscapes as "pretexts for beautiful color arrangements." In Rondout, New York, the dark tonal harmonies and subject matter recall Whistler's paintings of the Thames. Dabo's calligraphic brushwork of the trees, boats, and figures may have their source in his study of Asian painting. In this moody twilight view, Dabo took full advantage of the steely gray expanse of the Hudson River at Rondout Creek near Kingston, New York. Lights on the distant shore begin to twinkle, as daylight surrenders to nightfall.
Artist Biography: Leon Dabo was born in France to Ignace Schott, who was an artist, collector, and instructor of aesthetics. He grew up in Detroit, Michigan, trained under his father, and then relocated to New York City, where he met painter and muralist John La Farge. Dabo studied at the École des Arts Décoratifs, Académie Julian, and the École des Beaux Arts. He made numerous visits to James Abbott McNeill Whistler in his London studio. Many of his paintings reflect Whistler's influence in their Tonalist style and in the use of a monogram signature. Dabo became an authority on Whistler. When he returned to New York City, Dabo painted decorative works and murals. He also painted Whistlerian landscapes and seascapes.

Sources/Bibliography: Sessions, Ralph. A Poetic Vision: American Tonalism. New York: Spanierman Gallery, 2006
Micro Summary: Leon Dabo's "Rondout, New York" depicts a moody twilight scene along the Hudson River at Rondout Creek near Kingston, capturing the transition from day to night with twinkling lights on the distant shore. The artist employs dark tonal harmonies and expressive, calligraphic brushwork that reflects his study of Asian painting techniques. Dabo viewed his landscapes as "pretexts for beautiful color arrangements," and this work demonstrates his ability to transform the steely gray expanse of the river into an atmospheric composition reminiscent of Whistler's Thames paintings. The linear brushwork defining trees, boats, and figures enhances the contemplative quality of this nightfall scene.

Title: A June Idyll
Artwork Description: The tonal harmonies are reminiscent of French Barbizon landscapes. Areas of strong sunlight peek through the dense forest illuminating the rocks and the girl's dress. While summering in Vermont in 1887, Steele painted a series of forest interiors similar to this work. A June Idyll was painted during Steele's summer sojourn as a guest of Allen M. Fletcher, secretary-treasurer of the Indianapolis Natural Gas Company, at the Fletcher family home in Vermont. The artist divided his summer work in Vermont between expansive views of the Green Mountains and a series of small forest interiors, several of which included the artist's family. In this painting Steele's daughter Daisy is reading to her brother Shirley beneath a shade tree. The tonal harmonies reflect the artist's interest in French Barbizon landscapes. Areas of strong sunlight peek through the dense forest, illuminating the rocks and the girl's dress. Daisy's bright red hat offers a dramatic dash of color amid the lush green grass.
Artist Biography: T. C. Steele was born in Gosport Indiana. His family later moved to Waveland where Steele began taking art classes at age twelve. By the time he was eighteen, Steele was teaching drawing and painting at Waveland Collegiate Institute. In 1873 Steele moved to Indianapolis, where he painted portraits and exhibited paintings at an art supply store owned by Herman Lieber, who became an important friend and patron. Lieber headed efforts to send Steele and his family to Europe, gathering twelve subscribers to sponsor the artist's study in exchange for paintings. Following a precedent set by James Gookins and William M. Chase from Indiana and Frank Duveneck of Cincinnati, Steele went to Germany to study at Royal Academy of Art in Munich, a city with the added benefit of being more affordable than Paris. Steele studied in Munich 1880-1885 and after returning to Indianapolis, established the Indiana School of Art, where William Forsyth taught. The Art Association of Indianapolis (precursor to the IMA) took control of the school in 1891. Steele painted portraits and landscapes, many of them dark and dramatic, in the style known as the Munich School. As he began to explore the Indiana countryside, Steele turned almost completely to landscape painting. His work became more colorful and gradually more impressionistic, particularly after he saw European Impressionist paintings at the 1893 Chicago World Columbian Exposition. Steele emerged as the leader and spokesman for a group of Indiana artists known as The Hoosier Group, which included Indiana's most important Impressionist painters, including William Forsyth, J. Ottis Adams, Otto Stark, and Richard Gruelle. In 1902 and 1903, Steele toured the American West, painting in Oregon and around San Francisco. In 1906, he settled in Brown County in a home that became known as the House of the Singing Winds. For the remainder of his life, he painted the surrounding landscape in his personal variation on Impressionism.

Micro Summary: "A June Idyll" by T.C. Steele depicts the artist's children, Daisy and Shirley, in a peaceful forest scene where Daisy reads to her brother beneath a shade tree. Painted during Steele's 1887 summer stay in Vermont, the work showcases tonal harmonies reminiscent of French Barbizon landscapes. Strong sunlight filters through the dense forest canopy, illuminating rocks and the girl's dress, while Daisy's bright red hat provides a striking color accent against the lush green surroundings. The painting is part of a series of intimate forest interiors that Steele created during his Vermont sojourn as a guest of the Fletcher family.

Title: Margaret McKittrick
Artwork Description: Oil painting created in 1903, depicting 15-year-old Margaret MacKittrick, a friend of Thayer's children. The model recalled posing while Mrs. Thayer read to her to alleviate boredom. The idealized portrait shows a young woman, part innocence and part sensuality, inspired by Whistler's series of similar subjects. Features an elaborate Renaissance frame possibly inspired by architect Stanford White, which elevates the portrait from ordinary to exceptional.
Artist Biography: Abbott Handerson Thayer (1849-1921) was an American artist known for idealized portraits and his scientific work on animal camouflage. He suffered from bipolar disorder with continuous manic manifestations and deep depressions. Living with him became increasingly difficult, and when his wife Emma moved into a hotel, he came close to suicide. He died in 1921 after suffering a series of strokes.
Tour Guidance: Tour uses: Women in Art tour, tour showing impact and importance framing has on artwork, Idealized Portrait tour, tour about Artists Inspired by Spirituality and Nature. Note soft blurred loose brushwork and relationship with Impressionists. Note muted, restrained palette similar to Tonalists. The sitter could be imagined as a princess due to the presentation.
Connections: Compare idealized femininity with Whistler's Harmony in Pink and Gray: Lady Meux, Melchers' Joan of Arc, Hitchcock's Calypso, and Saint-Gaudens' bronze sculpture Diana. Discuss the role of elaborate frames in presenting artwork. Connect to Tonalist color palette and Impressionist brushwork.
Sources/Bibliography: References: Nelson White, Abbott H. Thayer, 1951; Helen M. Betty, 'Abbott H. Thayer', American Magazine of Art, October 1921; 'The painter of Angels became the Father of Camouflage,' Smithsonian Magazine, April 1999.
Micro Summary: Thayer's 1903 idealized portrait of 15-year-old Margaret MacKittrick blends innocence and sensuality in the tradition of Whistler's series, elevated by an elaborate Renaissance frame possibly inspired by architect Stanford White. Working while Mrs. Thayer read to the model, the artist employed soft Impressionist brushwork and Tonalist palette despite struggling with bipolar disorder. The psychological complexity of Thayer's mental state contrasts with the serene idealization of his subject.

Title: Sunrise
Artwork Description: This depiction of a single figure on a tree-lined road under a purple-clouded sky is the only known Munich scene painted after Steele returned from Germany. Steele painted this landscape using sketches he made while studying abroad. Sunrise was made from sketches Steele produced while studying abroad and is the only known Munich scene painted after Steele returned from Germany. The depiction of a single figure on a tree-lined road is similar to Steele's sketches of the Road to Schleissheim in his Munich sketchbooks. The purple clouded sky in Sunrise can be seen in some of Steele's paintings of Schleissheim. Sunrise suggests nostalgia for the Munich landscape that remained with Steele after his return to Indiana.
Artist Biography: T. C. Steele was born in Gosport Indiana. His family later moved to Waveland where Steele began taking art classes at age twelve. By the time he was eighteen, Steele was teaching drawing and painting at Waveland Collegiate Institute. In 1873 Steele moved to Indianapolis, where he painted portraits and exhibited paintings at an art supply store owned by Herman Lieber, who became an important friend and patron. Lieber headed efforts to send Steele and his family to Europe, gathering twelve subscribers to sponsor the artist's study in exchange for paintings. Following a precedent set by James Gookins and William M. Chase from Indiana and Frank Duveneck of Cincinatti, Steele went to Germany to study at Royal Academy of Art in Munich, a city with the added benefit of being more affordable than Paris. Steele studied in Munich 1880-1885 and after returning to Indianapolis, established the Indiana School of Art, where William Forsyth taught. The Art Association of Indianapolis (precursor to the IMA) took control of the school in 1891. Steele painted portraits and landscapes, many of them dark and dramatic, in the style known as the Munich School. As he began to explore the Indiana countryside, Steele turned almost completely to landscape painting. His work became more colorful and gradually more impressionistic, particularly after he saw European Impressionist paintings at the 1893 Chicago World Columbian Exposition. Steele emerged as the leader and spokesman for a group of Indiana artists known as The Hoosier Group, which included Indiana's most important Impressionist painters, including William Forsyth, J. Ottis Adams, Otto Stark, and Richard Gruelle. In 1902 and 1903, Steele toured the American West, painting in Oregon and around San Francisco. In 1906, he settled in Brown County in a home that became known as the House of the Singing Winds. For the remainder of his life, he painted the surrounding landscape in his personal variation on Impressionism.

Sources/Bibliography: William H. Gerdts. Theodore Clement Steele: American Master of Light, New York: Chameleon Books, 1995. ASIN: B002J7NK4K
Micro Summary: "Sunrise" by T.C. Steele depicts a solitary figure on a tree-lined road beneath a purple-clouded sky, representing the only known Munich scene he painted after returning from his studies in Germany. Created from sketches made while studying abroad, the painting shows similarities to Steele's drawings of the Road to Schleissheim found in his Munich sketchbooks. The work suggests a lingering nostalgia for the German landscape that stayed with Steele after his return to Indiana.

Title: Early Morning Sunshine
Artwork Description: Ritman painted in a fluid, Impressionist manner often with an abundance of patterns and a degree of abstraction. Patterning is evident in the subject's robe, draperies and bedspread which contrast with the abstract appearance of the garden beyond the window. Ritman painted portraits and still lifes but his favorite subjects were often artfully posed female models in interiors illuminated with bright natural light. He often used thick, divisionistic daubs of bright paint. Early Morning Sunshine portrays a pensive young woman, possibly his favorite model, Mimi, sitting on an open window ledge with a vibrant abstract garden outside the window. The table setting of a bowl of fruit and china pieces is actually a still-life painting within the overall painting. Brilliant morning light illuminates this painting which was created using broken brushstrokes, with a harmonious balance of blues, pinks, lavenders and yellow.
Artist Biography: American Impressionist painter and professor of painting; born 1889 in Kaments-Podolsky, Russia; emigrated to America in early 1900s, settling in Chicago; died 1963, Winona, Minn. Ritman received early artistic training in Chicago and Philadelphia followed by studies beginning in 1909 at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts and the Academie Julian in Paris. In 1911 he met fellow American painter, Frederick Frieseke, who invited him to join other American painters in Giverny, France, where Ritman was greatly influenced by their work and that of Claude Monet. Ritman painted each summer in Giverny until 1930 after which time he accepted the position of Professor of Painting at the Art Institute of Chicago which he held for the next 30 years.
Tour Guidance: Use as part of American Impressionic Painting comparing works by Frederick Frieiseke, and Richard E Miller and others. Discuss the painting technique used – type of brushstrokes, use of color, patterning, abstraction, fluidity. What is the time of day portrayed in this work? What is the subject doing and what is the atmosphere of the painting? Discuss how American Impressionism is similar to and different from French Impressionism – structure, realism, subject matter, painting technique.
Connections: Compare with other American Impressionists and with other artists who use light in their works (Turrell, Irwin, Benson and others). Compare use of light in Ritman paintings with Tarbell's Preparing for the Matinee. Where is Tarbell's light emanating from? Note the Impressionistic style of brushstrokes in the woman's blouse and hair. Contrast with Red Kimono on the Roof (John Sloan) and Girl Sweeping (Paxton) - how women are portrayed, what they are doing, setting, colors, etc. Compare the Giverny Group with other American Impressionists who did not paint in France.
Sources/Bibliography: Ask Art Academic – Biography for Louis Ritman (Website – www.askart.com)
Micro Summary: Early Morning Sunshine showcases Ritman's American Impressionist style with a pensive woman illuminated by brilliant morning light from a window overlooking an abstract garden. A Russian-born artist who trained in Giverny with Frederick Frieseke and was influenced by Monet, Ritman used broken brushstrokes and divisionistic paint application. The painting demonstrates his fluid technique with abundant patterning in textiles contrasting with the abstracted garden view.

Title: Munich Girl
Artwork Description: The young woman in Steele's canvas represents a departure from the Royal Academy's preference for older models. This attractive figure, whose youthful facial features emerge from the dark shadows, is rendered in brown tonalities against an unadorned, dark background. The setting and execution exemplify the austere style espoused by Germany's Royal Academy teachers. Steele's painting instructor Ludwig Löfftz was prone to severe criticism of the "sweet color" in his students' work and praised such somber and meditative images as Munich Girl.

Micro Summary: T.C. Steele's "Munich Girl" depicts a young woman rendered in brown tones against a dark, unadorned background, representing a departure from the Royal Academy's typical preference for older models. The painting exemplifies the austere style taught at Germany's Royal Academy, where Steele studied under Ludwig Löfftz. The somber, meditative composition reflects Löfftz's teaching philosophy, which criticized "sweet color" in favor of such restrained, shadowy works. The young woman's facial features emerge from dark shadows, creating a contemplative mood characteristic of the German academic tradition.

Title: Rainy Night, Etaples
Artwork Description: Indianapolis native William Scott studied in France with the celebrated African American artist Henry O. Tanner. Etaples, Tanner's summer residence, was the subject of several of Scott's paintings. Tanner's influence is evident in the blue-green palette, subdued tonality and dramatic light. A few years later, Scott depicted the area around Tanner's home in Rainy Night, Étaples. Tanner's influence is evident in the painting's blue-green palette, subdued tonality, and dramatic lighting. The loosely brushed, spontaneous composition demonstrates the restrained impressionist technique that dominated Scott's European work. The building in the painting was identified as the town hall in Étaples, France.
Artist Biography: Indianapolis native William Edouard Scott was a graduate of Emmerich Manual Training High School and briefly attended Saturday school at the John Herron Art Institute. He became the first African American to teach in the Indianapolis Public Schools. He studied first at the Art Institute of Chicago and then, in France. Though a versatile painter, Scott was primarily known as a muralist. His murals can be found in numerous buildings, including schools, government buildings, funeral homes, and churches. He traveled to Haiti to paint the region. Shortly after Scott arrived in France in 1909, the celebrated African American expatriate artist, Henry Ossawa Tanner, invited him to stay at his summer home in Normandy.

Sources/Bibliography: Taylor, William E. and Harriet G. Warkel. A Shared Heritage: Art by Four African Americans. Indianapolis: Indianapolis Museum of Art, 1996.
Micro Summary: Indianapolis artist William Edouard Scott created this painting of Etaples, France, where he studied with renowned African American artist Henry O. Tanner. The work depicts the town hall in Etaples on a rainy night, showcasing Tanner's influence through its blue-green palette, subdued tones, and dramatic lighting effects. Scott employed a loosely brushed, spontaneous impressionist technique that characterized his European period. The painting captures the atmospheric mood of the French town where his mentor Tanner had his summer residence.

Title: Souvenir of the Columbian Exposition
Artwork Description: Souvenir of the Columbian Exposition is only one of two known works by Atkinson. It exemplifies the illusionism of trompe l'oeil (French for "Fool-the-eye") paintings, using oil on canvas to create the effect of wood grain or a paper postcard. This kind of still life subject, sometimes called a "letter rack" picture, originated in seventeenth century Holland and was revived by several nineteenth century artists working in Philadelphia, including William Harnett, James Peto, and several members of the Peale family. This painting is a document of one of the most important events in the history of American culture, the World's Columbian Exposition, which was held in Chicago in 1893. The stamp and letters, apt subject matter for a mail carrier, all relate to this exposition. An envelope addressed to "Mr. John Smith Philada Pa" is stamped "Due 1¢" and bears the commemorative stamp of "Columbus in Sight of Land" (one cent) mailed from Kensington Station, Philadelphia. This is pasted over an embossed Columbian envelope, which reads "Columbia Station October 4 2PM Philadelphia." Beneath these are two postcards: an "Official Souvenir Postal" of the fair and posted from "World's Fair Station October 24." Fascinated by the Exposition and influenced by his job, Atkinson created a skillful souvenir of this important event.
Artist Biography: Jacob Atkinson, a Philadelphia letter carrier, painted more as a hobby than a profession. He chose to depict still life subjects of mail and money for amusement. Atkinson was a veteran of the Civil War. After the war, jobs in the postal service were often given to veterans. It is not known how many works Atkinson painted or whether he exhibited or sold any of his paintings during his lifetime.

Micro Summary: Jacob Atkinson's "Souvenir of the Columbian Exposition" is a trompe l'oeil oil painting that creates the illusion of actual paper items through masterful technique. The work depicts stamps, letters, and postcards all related to the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago, arranged in the "letter rack" style popularized by 17th-century Dutch artists and revived by 19th-century Philadelphia painters. As one of only two known works by Atkinson, who worked as a mail carrier, this painting serves as both a skillful artistic achievement and a historical document of one of America's most important cultural events. The realistic rendering includes details like a commemorative Columbus stamp and official fair postcards, reflecting the artist's fascination with the Exposition and his postal profession.

Title: First Touch of Autumn
Artwork Description: The artist captures the low and rolling, flat terrain of the Shinnecock countryside, with its occasional tree, sand dunes, and dwarfed bushes. Chase established America's first summer school of art at Shinnecock Hills, Long Island, where he painted some of his most Impressionist landscapes. Although Chase often included his family in his tranquil Shinnecock scenes, First Touch of Autumn presents an expansive view of an unpeopled landscape, which is soft and rolling. Chase captures the vastness of this lowland country as it stretches toward the sea under a clear blue sky.
Artist Biography: Hoosier native William Merritt Chase trained at the Royal Academy in Munich before settling in New York City. He maintained a summer home and studio at Shinnecock Hills on the eastern end of Long Island, where he established America's first summer school of art in 1891. In his classes and in his own artistic production of this period, Chase focused primarily on painting en plein air. Some of Chase's finest and most impressionistic landscapes were painted during his summer sojourns at Shinnecock.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Pisano, Ronald G. and Carol K Lane. William Merritt Chase: Landscapes in Oil. New Haven: Yale University Press, 2009.
Micro Summary: William Merritt Chase's "First Touch of Autumn" depicts the expansive, rolling countryside of Shinnecock Hills on Long Island, where he established America's first summer art school. The painting showcases the flat terrain characteristic of the area, featuring scattered trees, sand dunes, and low bushes under a clear blue sky. Unlike many of his other Shinnecock works that included family members, this landscape presents an unpeopled view that emphasizes the vastness of the lowland stretching toward the sea. The work exemplifies Chase's Impressionist approach to capturing the tranquil beauty of the Long Island landscape.

Title: Portrait of a Family
Artwork Description: In this painting, the woman and children are posed against a drawn drape in the style of British portraiture. The similarity of the colors used in the sash, chair, curtain and trim on the young boy's jacket move the viewer's eye around the canvas to encompass all the figures. The woman is wearing a simple, elegant, robe à l'anglaise, a gown favored by portrait painters of the period. The woman's hair is lightly powdered and fashionably styled in the coiffure à l'hérisson, or "hedgehog," in which the hair was cut short in the front, frizzed to the ends and then brushed up away from the face.
Artist Biography: Debt resulting from an inability to manage money kept Gilbert Stuart on the move much of his life. Born in North Kingston, Rhode Island and raised in Newport, Stuart was taught by a local Scottish painter who took him to Scotland, but his mentor's death forced Stuart back to America. During the Revolutionary War, he returned to England to study with the American expatriate Benjamin West. As success came, so did debt which forced Stuart to Dublin, Ireland and then to America, where he eventually became the most highly regarded portraitist of his day. A skillful master of his craft, Stuart painted directly on the canvas, without using any preliminary drawing. By the end of his career, Stuart had painted over a thousand portraits of important political figures. One of his most famous portraits of George Washington was the "Athenaeum Head" currently on the dollar bill.

Micro Summary: Gilbert Stuart's "Portrait of a Family" depicts a woman and children arranged against a draped backdrop in the British portraiture tradition. The composition uses a unified color palette of similar tones in the sash, chair, curtain, and boy's jacket trim to guide the viewer's eye across all figures. The woman wears an elegant robe à l'anglaise gown popular with portrait painters of the era, while her hair is styled in the fashionable coiffure à l'hérisson or "hedgehog" style, featuring lightly powdered hair that is cut short in front, frizzed, and brushed upward from the face.

Title: Girl at the Piano: Recording Sound
Tidying Up
Artwork Description: Painting is oil on masonite; preparing masonite requires many coats of gesso and is a laborious process. Bishop and Reginald Marsh, known as the Fourteenth Street School, sought to capture contemporary life in New York City in the 1930s and '40s. Bishop concentrated on the subtleties of fleeting moments of people who lived in and around Union Square- secretaries, sales clerks, blue-collar workers, derelicts. This gave these simple occasions a sense of timelessness—ex. shop girls seated at a lunch counter, talking, putting on makeup. Her subject matter was frequently women, showing them in a positive light of strength. She saw working women as participants in an American tradition of social advancement. Considered an American Scene and Realist painter and also referred to as a humanist painter. The woman, perhaps a secretary or salesperson, uses a pocket mirror to check her teeth for lipstick smudges. It is not posed, more like an informal snapshot. She uses active brushwork and a sense of the figure's physical movement as metaphors for this social advancement. Bishop's sepia tones achieve a transparency that results in a sense of vibration and thus of motion. This warm brown also recalls old master drawings of the Italian Renaissance.
Artist Biography: American born in 1902 in Cincinnati; died 1988 New York City. She was an American painter, draftsman and etcher. Bishop moved to New York in 1918 to study at the New York School of Applied Design for Women. After reading about the exciting development in modern art, she transferred to the Art Students League in 1920 and studied under Guy Pene du Bois and Kenneth Hayes Miller. During these years she developed lifelong friendship with Reginald Marsh, Edwin Dickinson and other figurative painters who lived and worked on 14th Street. She was influenced by Dutch and Flemish painters such as Adriaen Brouwer and Peter Paul Rubens, whose work she saw in Europe in 1931. She chose to emulate Rubens because the technique and composition of his work expressed the quality of movement she sought. Her mother had worked to secure the vote for women in 1920 and urged Bishop and her sisters toward the independence she had lost once she started her family. While Bishop desired independence it was a wealthy male relative that made it possible for her to attend these schools. He supplied her economic needs for many years. She saw, in this instance, being a woman was to her advantage as he probably would not have subsidized a boy. Bishop worked out of her studio on Union Square in New York City for at least 50 years. Throughout her long career Bishop concentrated on the subtleties of fleeting moments in the daily routine of people who lived and worked around Union Square, giving these simple occasions a sense of timelessness: shop girls seated at a lunch counter, travelers waiting on a subway platform, tramps gathered under the horse's tail of the equestrian statue of George Washington, students walking quietly through the park, and children at play. Her favorite subject matter was women going about their everyday lives, eating, talking, putting on makeup, taking off their coats. These ordinary motions produced facial expressions that Bishop felt revealed the personality of the people she portrayed. She was described as a Urban Realist and an American Scene painter, also one of America's leading humanist painters. Although women figured prominently in the work of both Miller and Marsh, Bishop's work is unique in its sensitivity to women's strength. Bishop saw women as participants in an American tradition of upward mobility, and she used active brushwork and a sense of the figure's physical movement as metaphors for this social advancement. She was friends with many women artists of her century, Louise Nevelson for one, but her fellow male students would be the major influences. Bishop worked in a cautious and painstaking manner, often spending a year or more on a single picture and thus producing fewer than 175 paintings over a period of nearly 60 years. She was compulsive to 'get it right'. Her work has always been widely admired by other artists.
Tour Guidance: Women Artists Tour - History Tour - Highlights: Discuss what is happening in the world (WWII) and how it is affecting the art. (working women). Discuss the subject matter the artist chose. Discuss the style or technique used in painting the picture. Discuss the visual elements of art—line, shape, color, texture, space. What is the story? Visual Thinking Strategies: What is going on in the picture? Paraphrase the responses. What more can we find?
Connections: Edmund Charles Tarbell: Preparing for the Matinee, 1907 - Both everyday subjects, one is of an upper-class young woman, the other is a working woman. The world situation WWII brings social advancement for women. Both Impressionist style. John Sloan: Red Kimono on the Roof, 1912 - Compare Ash Can School with American Scene painting. Compare with any portrait in the American or European Galleries. Compare with works by Mary Cassatt. Compare with Renoir portrait. Compare with other portraits in European collection for style and subject.
Micro Summary: "Tidying Up" by Isabel Bishop depicts a working woman, likely a secretary or salesperson, checking her teeth for lipstick smudges using a pocket mirror in what appears to be a candid, snapshot-like moment. Bishop, part of the Fourteenth Street School, focused on capturing contemporary life around New York's Union Square in the 1930s and '40s, particularly portraying working women as symbols of strength and social advancement. The painting is executed in warm sepia tones on masonite with active brushwork that creates a sense of vibration and movement, reflecting both the physical motion of the subject and the broader social mobility she represents. Bishop's style, considered American Scene Realism with humanist qualities, transforms this simple everyday moment into something timeless while paying homage to Italian Renaissance drawing traditions.

Title: Bacchante and Infant Faun
Artwork Description: Bacchante is a priestess of the God of Wine. A faun normally is a human with the legs and horns of a goat. Fashioned after the Greco-Roman style, which Americans would have seen as tourists in Europe. In 1894 MacMonnies, created a three-quarter life-size female nude statute for architect McKim to put in the garden of the Boston Public library, which McKim designed as a memorial to his deceased wife. The French government was so impressed that it asked to buy it for the Luxembourg Museum, a unique honor for an American. Since MacMonnies had promised it to McKim, he made reductions, one of which is owned by the IMA. In late 1890s Boston consisted of two main classes, those with "proper" social status and the immigrants (Irish). The social elite attempted to retain control through organizations such as the Public Library, whose mission was to teach the immigrants the "socially accepted" values and morals. This group worked with the religious and Anti-vice groups of the day (Watch and Ward and Women's Christian Temperance Union) to convince the library to refuse the statute. They felt the statute honored vice since she has unruly hair, is smiling and dancing and showing inappropriate influence on an infant by feeding him grapes. Her light-hearted air is not what was acceptable for a proper Victorian woman, and would convince "others" to behave in the manner of Bacchante. After a year of debate, McKim withdrew his offer and donated the statute to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City, even though the general public approved of the statute. Saint-Gaudens stated that Bacchante had a grace and a life to it that had never been done better. Bacchante shows MacMonnies attention to details, with the life-like expression on her face and the infants, as well as the muscles of the legs as they move up and forward.
Artist Biography: Sculptor and Painter, born in Brooklyn, died in New York City. Started sculpting with dough at age 3, believed sculptors should paint. Most of his works are Portraitures, in paint or sculpture. Apprenticed to Augustus Saint-Gaudens, studied at Cooper Union and National Academy of Design. Architects Stanford White and Charles McKim loaned him money in 1884 to study in Paris. (supposedly $50) Won three prizes at Paris Salons/exhibitions which lead to MacMonnies opening his own studio and receiving many American commissions. These were often mythical creatures in the Art Nouveau style for fountains, creating a new genre for American sculptures, inspiring a new generation of sculptors. Late 1890s returned to painting, taught drawing with Whistler at Académie Carmen and for two decades was popular teacher at his Giverny estate, which was near Monet's. Among his most famous statutes is the Marne battle Memorial given to France in return for the Statue of Liberty. He was at the head of the American Beaux-Arts movement. MacMonnies was praised as one of first sculptors to acknowledge work of others to achieve end result. Loved reality and concerned with details. Returned to New York in 1915, because wanted Anglo-Saxon models not available in France.
Tour Guidance: American Spotlight - How French sculptors influenced American sculptors. How art was viewed by various groups in America at the turn of the century. Painting and Poetry – A New York paper published the following Poem, as if it were written by the Bacchante: "Although I have a joyous air I'm feeling rather sad, When I am so divinely fair, How can they call me bad?" Outdoor Sculpture – though this sculpture is indoors, the original was made to be outside. What is acceptable for Public sculpture; who is to decide?
Connections: Diana, by Augustus Saint-Gaudens: MacMonnies' mentor. Also nude woman, on one foot, in act of movement, created at the same time as Bacchante was being refused by Boston Library. Portrait of Robert Louis Stevenson, August Saint-Gaudens, mentor. Compare relief to sculpture. The Negress by Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux, MacMonnies was considered a follower of his style. Notice the hair style and attention to details. Frog Fountain by Janet Scudder, student of MacMonnies. Also a happy young child, notice similarities to infant's face. Concave or Standing Woman by Alexander Archipenko. Bronze sculpture of woman, totally abstract, compare to MacMonnies details. Harmony in Pink and Gray: Lady Meux, by James Whistler. MacMonnies taught painting with his friend Whistler. Compare the two women, one joyous, dancing, and natural, the other formal, more like the social elite of Boston that rejected Bacchante. Bronco Buster by Frederic Remington, a contemporary of MacMonnies. Also a painter, but not formally trained. Portrait of a Young Woman, by Edward August Bell, a realistic view of woman, that varies greatly from Bacchante.

Micro Summary: Frederick William MacMonnies (1863-1937) was a prominent American Beaux-Arts sculptor who trained under Augustus Saint-Gaudens and studied in Paris, where he won critical acclaim that launched his career creating mythological fountain sculptures. His "Bacchante and Infant Faun" (1893-1894), a joyous bronze of a dancing priestess of wine holding an infant faun, sparked major controversy when Victorian Boston's social and religious elite rejected it for the Boston Public Library, deeming its exuberant nudity and unrestrained expression morally corrupting despite popular support and praise from fellow sculptors. The IMA's version is a reduction of the original, which now resides at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, representing a pivotal moment in American cultural history when art challenged Victorian moral standards.

Title: Pleasant Run
Artwork Description: Oil on canvas landscape painting created in 1885, soon after Steele returned to Indianapolis from Munich. Depicts a rural scene along Pleasant Run, which was actually within Indianapolis city limits at the time. The painting shows dark drama and back lighting characteristic of German period paintings, with concentration on tone rather than hues. Features varied brushwork - loose for trees, tighter for water - and a stream that leads the viewer into the picture.
Artist Biography: Theodore Clement Steele (1847-1926) was an American Impressionist painter and one of Indiana's most famous artists. He studied at the Munich Academy of Fine Arts from 1880-1885 with fellow Hoosiers William Forsyth and Otto Adams. Steele was a founding member of the Hoosier Group, formed in 1894. In 1907, he purchased 211 acres in Brown County, Indiana, which became the T.C. Steele State Historic Site.
Tour Guidance: This was Steele's first Hoosier landscape painting upon returning from Munich, marking the transition between his German training and his development as an American Impressionist. The painting demonstrates more luminosity than typical German landscapes while retaining the tonal approach learned abroad. Steele worked as a visiting professor at Indiana University and his Brown County estate was bequeathed to Indiana.
Connections: Tour connections: landscapes, Impressionism, paths/streams as compositional device, use of tones to set mood. Compare with other Hoosier Group works. Note the influence of Munich training on early American Impressionism.
Sources/Bibliography: Hoosier Group exhibition history, Chicago 1894. T.C. Steele State Historic Site documentation.
Micro Summary: Steele's first landscape after returning from Munich Academy training depicts Pleasant Run within Indianapolis city limits, demonstrating the transition from German tonal painting to American Impressionism. The 1885 work features characteristic back lighting and varied brushwork, with loose strokes for foliage contrasting tighter rendering of water. As a founding member of the Hoosier Group, Steele later established his famous Brown County studio, now a state historic site.

Title: Reflections
Artwork Description: Painted during period when Dove was abandoning representation altogether. Contains all the elements characteristic of his work. whimsical elements, circular shapes, organic forms, feathered brushstrokes. Interpreted as landscape with sun, clouds, grass, and trees. In a note written by Dove, he implies a more playful interpretation. Referring to the piece, he writes: "Reflections from headlights on windshield of a car. After image created by the headlights of a passing automobile".
Artist Biography: Dove graduated from Cornell University and worked as an illustrator for various magazines in New York. (1903-1907). In 1907, he traveled to Paris and southern France and was influenced by the work of Cezanne and Matisse. On his return to the United States in 1909, he began his association with Alfred Stieglitz. His first abstract work appeared in 1910, similar to Kandinsky's and around the same time. He is credited as being the first innovative abstract painter in America. Two years later, he held his first solo exhibition at Stieglitz's 291 Gallery. In 1913, he exhibited in the Armory Show. Dove developed his abstract works, which he called "extractions" by refining and simplifying objects and scenes until color and rhythmic forms took on "a life of their own". He believed that objects are not discrete, isolated entities, but active forces whose rhythms are in constant interplay with their environment. The origins in his abstract forms often can be recognized. In 1921, Dove separated from his wife and moved to a houseboat with painter Helen Torr, whom he married in 1924. During this time, he experimented with a variety of materials and found objects which he organized into assemblages, often with great inventiveness and wit. In 1927, he developed a characteristic imagery of irregular, circular shapes swelling outward with haloes of modulated color. (Fog Horns, 1929). This work represents the vital, generative forces of nature. He continued to develop this style on his return to Geneva, New York to settle his family's estate in 1933. In 1938, Dove suffered a heart attack and relocated to Long Island. His later paintings became increasingly more abstract and often restricted to geometric forms. From 1930, he was supported by regular payments from his patron Duncan Phillips. He died in November, 1946 on Long Island.
Tour Guidance: Could be used for VTS. Discuss what's going on in this picture. Can you pick out recognizable objects? What more do you see? Can you recognize parts of the landscape? Discuss characteristics of abstract art. Describe Dove's connection with Stieglitz and the 291 Gallery.
Connections: John Marin, Hurricane, 61.42; Georgia O'Keeffe, Jimson Weed, 1997.131
Micro Summary: "Reflections" by Arthur Garfield Dove exemplifies the American artist's transition away from representational art, featuring his characteristic whimsical elements, circular shapes, organic forms, and feathered brushstrokes. While the abstract composition can be interpreted as a landscape with sun, clouds, grass, and trees, Dove himself offered a more playful explanation in his notes. He described the work as depicting "reflections from headlights on windshield of a car" and the "after image created by the headlights of a passing automobile," revealing his interest in capturing fleeting, modern visual experiences through abstraction.

Title: Gamin
Artwork Description: Sculpture in plaster depicting a young street child (gamin). The work demonstrates Savage's skill at capturing personality and character in three-dimensional form, as well as her commitment to representing African American subjects with dignity and humanity during the Harlem Renaissance.
Artist Biography: Augusta Savage (1892-1962) was an African American sculptor associated with the Harlem Renaissance. Born in Florida, she moved to New York City and studied sculpture, eventually opening the Savage Studio of Arts and Crafts in Harlem. She was both an accomplished artist and influential teacher who mentored many younger African American artists. Savage faced significant racial discrimination throughout her career, including being denied entry to a summer art program in France due to her race.
Tour Guidance: Gamin represents Savage's focus on Black subjects and everyday life in Harlem. The term 'gamin' refers to a street child or urchin. Savage's sculptures challenged stereotypical representations and asserted the humanity and individuality of African American subjects. Despite facing racial barriers, she became an influential teacher and advocate for African American artists.
Connections: Connect to Harlem Renaissance cultural movement, African American representation in sculpture, Norman Lewis and other Harlem artists. Discuss barriers faced by African American and women artists. Compare approaches to depicting everyday subjects across different media.
Sources/Bibliography: Harlem Renaissance documentation, Savage Studio of Arts and Crafts records.
Micro Summary: Savage's plaster sculpture of a street child exemplifies her Harlem Renaissance commitment to representing African American subjects with dignity and psychological depth. Despite facing racial discrimination that barred her from European study programs, Savage established her influential studio in Harlem where she mentored younger Black artists. The work challenges stereotypical representations while capturing the individual humanity of everyday Harlem life.

Title: The Canal Morning Effect
Artwork Description: The subject of this work is the canal that runs through downtown Indianapolis. The focal points of this canvas are the state capitol and the Civil War monument then under construction. In this painting Gruelle alludes to both Indiana's history and its future. The Canal – Morning Effect is Gruelle's acknowledge masterpiece. With his innate sense of the dramatic, Gruelle alluded to both Indiana's history and its future while painting the reality of contemporary Indianapolis. In 1836 a canal was dug as part of an ill-fated undertaking to connect landlocked Indianapolis with the great Lakes and the Ohio River. The junction was one block from the west side of State House Square; where in 1888 a new state capitol arose, casting its shadow on the waters of this failed project. Working from a vantage point in Military Park, Gruelle also painted the "monument" to the left of the capitol. The Indianapolis landmark, erected to commemorate the Civil War, was actually only in the middle of the construction in 1894. Igniting the subtle harmonies of Gruelle's cityscape is the bright red hat worn by the woman crossing the bridge. The small, solitary figure is a perfect foil for the manifestations of civic pride that stand against the rising sun. In this painting by Hoosier Group member Richard Gruelle—his masterpiece—the artist combined observation and invention to depict downtown Indianapolis at the end of the 1800s. Unlike most Hoosier Group scenes, which evoke a general sense of the Indiana landscape, the image in this canvas is an identifiable location. The Indiana capitol building, constructed a few years earlier, rises in the center of the composition and casts its reflection in the waters of the canal. Behind and to the left of the capitol is a monument in the shape of an obelisk that commemorates the Civil War and the victory of the Union over the Confederacy. The obelisk was under construction while this canvas was being painted, so Gruelle used his imagination to complete the structure. The tiny figure of a woman in a red hat crossing the bridge over the canal creates a striking focal point that draws the viewer into this serene morning landscape.
Artist Biography: Richard Gruelle was born in Kentucky and raised in Illinois. He began drawing as a child. When he was a teenager Gruelle worked as a sign and house painter to gain the knowledge needed to mix and use paints. The budding artist began his career painting portraits. In 1882 he moved to Indianapolis where he painted landscapes in oil and watercolor. Gruelle's efforts were so successful that he was included in an exhibition whose artist's became known as the Hoosier Group. Gruelle traveled to Washington where he saw the Walters collection in Baltimore. He wrote an article on the collection for Modern Art that was read by William T. Walters who commissioned Gruelle to write a catalog of his collection. The intimate study of the Walters collection was the closest Gruelle came to a formal art education. Gruelle maintained a studio in New York and spent his summers at Gloucester on Cape Ann, painting numerous land and seascapes. In 1910 Gruelle and his family moved to Norwalk Connecticut where he died a few years later. His youngest son John (Johnny Gruelle) created Raggedy Ann and Andy. Besides Gruelle, the group included T.C. Steele, J. Ottis Adams, William Forsyth, and Otto Stark. Gruelle, who was largely self-taught, was the only one of the group who did not study abroad. The Hoosier Group was a circle of Indiana painters nationally recognized as among the most important regional artists who painted in the Impressionist style. The Indianapolis Museum of Art has an extensive collection of works by Indiana artists, including the Hoosier Group, who in the late 1800s and early 1900s rendered their state's landscapes in an Impressionist style.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Mary Q. Burnet. Art and Artists of Indiana, New York: The Century Company, 1921. ASIN: B00122RQVQ
Micro Summary: Richard Gruelle's acknowledged masterpiece depicts downtown Indianapolis at the end of the 1800s, featuring the canal that runs through the city with the state capitol and Civil War monument as focal points. Painted from Military Park, the work combines observation and invention, as Gruelle imaginatively completed the obelisk monument that was still under construction in 1894. The painting alludes to both Indiana's history and future, capturing the reality of contemporary Indianapolis including the failed 1836 canal project and the newly erected capitol building. A striking focal point is created by the small figure of a woman in a bright red hat crossing the bridge, serving as a perfect foil against the manifestations of civic pride rising against the morning sun.

Title: The Love Song
Artwork Description: This image was reproduced as an illustration in the December, 1926 issue of Ladies Home Journal. This work contrasts one of Rockwell's favorite themes: youth contrasted with old age. Rockwell was an avid collector of old maps and added a map to the background of this work. Rockwell portrayed "average" Americans in everyday situations. This work was done when the artist was thirty-two years of age.
Artist Biography: American painter and illustrator born February 3, 1894, New York City; died November 8, 1978 in Stockbridge, MA. Rockwell studied first at the New York School of Art, later leaving high school to study at the National Academy of Design and subsequently at the Art Student's League. Rockwell set up a studio in New Rochelle, New York in 1910, close to the Leyendecker brothers and Howard Chandler Christy. Rockwell's connection with The Saturday Evening Post for which he is best remembered began when he was 22 years old. Rockwell did 321 covers for the magazine over the next 47 years. In 1953 the Rockwell family relocated to Stockbridge, MA, now the site of the Rockwell Museum, which is the result of a trust set up by the artist in 1973. In 1963, Rockwell left The Post and began to design covers for Look Magazine and these later images are more concerned with the pressing issues of the time than previous ones had been. Rockwell was given the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1977.
Tour Guidance: Use as part of a tour on art and music. How is music used in this piece? What role does the title play in our understanding of this painting? We think of paintings as portraits, still lifes or landscapes. Does this work fall into one of these categories? What role does the map play in our interpretation of this work?
Connections: Compare and contrast this work with the interiors of the Dutch Baroque. Compare this young woman with the girl in Girl Sweeping by Paxton. Connect with other works, which involve musical instruments in the European and Asian galleries. Compare and contrast the purpose for which this image was made and the role of media in public life.
Micro Summary: "The Love Song" is a 1926 illustration by Norman Rockwell that appeared in Ladies Home Journal, created when the artist was thirty-two years old. The work exemplifies one of Rockwell's favorite themes by contrasting youth with old age, featuring his characteristic portrayal of "average" Americans in everyday situations. Rockwell incorporated a map into the background, reflecting his personal passion as an avid collector of old maps.

Title: Portrait of Mrs Robert Reid
Artwork Description: Feathered, interwoven brushstrokes in a vibrant palette of rich pastels swathe both figure and landscape, thus unifying the composition. This likeness of Reid's wife, exhibits the artist's impressionist point of view. With a keen sensitivity to the behavior of sunlight, shadow, and colored reflections, Reid used freely brushed strokes to bathe his subject in rich pastel hues. Reid displayed an Impressionist point of view in easel paintings like this portrait of his wife.
Artist Biography: Robert Reid was born in Stockbridge, Massachusetts and studied at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts School, the Art Students League in New York and at the Académie Julian in Paris. After three years in France, Reid settled in New York. During the late 1880s Reid followed his Boston classmates Frank Benson and Edmund Tarbell to Paris for study at the Académie Julian. While Benson and Tarbell began exploring Impressionist ideas in France, Reid only fell under the style's influence after returning to the US in 1889. His subjects included landscapes, figures, still-lifes and murals painted in an impressionist manner. Reid was one of the founding members of The Ten American Painters, a group of impressionists who rebelled against academic traditions. He supported himself by painting portraits until he received his first mural commission decorating one of the eight entrance pavilion domes in the Liberal Arts Building for the 1893 World's Columbian Exhibition in Chicago. He later received numerous mural commissions. Best known for murals painted in a decorative style, Reid displayed an Impressionist point of view in easel paintings. He also created stained-glass windows, another indication of his attraction to the effects of sunlight. In the early 1920s, Reid moved to Colorado Springs and taught at Broadmoor Academy during which time he concentrated on portraiture. Reid's distinctive style is best seen in his idealized figures of women which are the hallmark of his easel painting.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: William Gerdts. Ten American Painters, New York: Spanierman Gallery, 1990. ISBN-13: 978-0945936077
Micro Summary: Robert Reid's "Portrait of Mrs Robert Reid" showcases the artist's Impressionist approach through feathered, interwoven brushstrokes that unify the figure and landscape in a vibrant palette of rich pastels. The painting demonstrates Reid's keen sensitivity to sunlight, shadow, and colored reflections as he uses freely brushed strokes to bathe his wife in luminous pastel hues. This intimate portrait exemplifies how Reid applied Impressionist techniques to capture both the likeness and atmospheric qualities of his subject.

Title: Morning—Old Schofield's Mill
Artwork Description: The recent gift of Morning—Old Schofield's Mill bolsters the IMA's collection of pivotal works by beloved Indiana painter T.C. Steele. The year after completing this 1889 painting, Steele asked an exceptionally high $400 for it in an exhibition and self-published a reproduction in The Steele Portfolio. Although these activities alerted art historians to the work's importance, Morning—Old Schofield's Mill lay hidden in private hands until its donation in 2011. This 1889 painting bridges the artist's moody Munich style and the regional Impressionism that marks his later career. In Morning—Old Schofield's Mill, Steele lightened his palette considerably and used a looser brushstroke and palette knife to apply paint. The new brighter color choice and freed paint application peaked in the later The Bloom of the Grape, considered the first example of Steele's Impressionism. Combining strong technical skill with a more personal painting style, the intermediate period of Morning—Old Schofield's Mill is often considered Steele's strongest. The painting depicts Schofield's Mill, a water-powered grist mill that stood from 1836 until 1967 on Fall Creek, near the present-day site of the Indiana State Fairground. The mill was a landmark along the creek, which marked Indianapolis's north boundary. At the time of its acquisition, Morning—Old Schofield's Mill appeared dark and tonal, typical of Steele's post-Munich landscapes. Treatment undertaken by the IMA conservation department revealed the painting's original atmospheric color, confirming the work as a transitional keystone between Steele's Munich and Impressionist periods. The conservation treatment allows today's viewers to see Morning—Old Schofield's Mill as it was first exhibited in 1890 by the Art Association of Indianapolis, precursor to the IMA, and will ensure a longer life for this important work.
Artist Biography: Born in Owen County, Steele sought to become a professional artist when few existed in the Midwest and in 1880 traveled to Germany for training at Munich's Royal Academy of Fine Arts. In 1885, Steele returned to Indiana. Pleasant Run, painted just months after Steele's return to Indiana, shows the technical skill and strong modeling mastered in Munich. In 1889 Steele lived and worked near the business center of Indianapolis. When he could not travel to the countryside, he painted rural scenes along the city's outskirts. Steele's eloquent advocacy for Indiana art earned him the title 'Dean of the Hoosier Group.' Around the time he painted Morning—Old Schofield's Mill, Steele wrote his first major art treatise. 'The Development of the Connoisseur in Art' asserted his romantic view that art should reflect 'fine appreciation of the beauty of nature.' Steele devoted the rest of his life to promoting regard for Indiana's culture and native landscape.

Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: THIS INFORMATION IS TAKEN FROM THE IMA WEBSITE. For the complete write-up, please copy this address to your browser: http://www.imamuseum.org/collections/artwork/morning-old-schofields-mill-tc-steele
Micro Summary: T.C. Steele's 1889 painting "Morning—Old Schofield's Mill" represents a pivotal transitional work between the artist's dark Munich style and his later regional Impressionism. The painting depicts a historic water-powered grist mill that operated on Fall Creek near Indianapolis from 1836 to 1967, serving as a local landmark along the city's northern boundary. Steele valued this work highly, asking $400 for it in exhibition and self-publishing a reproduction, though it remained in private hands until donated to the IMA in 2011. Recent conservation treatment revealed the painting's original bright, atmospheric colors that had been obscured over time, confirming its importance as a bridge between Steele's artistic periods. This intermediate work is often considered among Steele's strongest, combining technical skill with a more personal painting style featuring a lightened palette and looser brushwork.

Title: Robert Louis Stevenson
Artwork Description: Bronze portrait relief medallion of Scottish author Robert Louis Stevenson, modeled 1887-88, cast 1910. Shows Stevenson reclining in bed with manuscript in one hand and cigarette in the other. Background features text from Stevenson's poem 'To Will H. Low' from his Underwoods collection. The relief captures a speaking likeness with lively naturalist details contrasting the smooth pillowcase with rougher blanket textures. IMA's cast is inscribed 'Replica, made for the Art Association of Indianapolis, Indiana.'
Artist Biography: Augustus Saint-Gaudens (1848-1907) was an American sculptor of Irish and French descent. Born in Dublin, his family emigrated to America when he was six months old. He became the leading American sculptor of the Beaux-Arts generation, known for his public monuments and portrait reliefs. Saint-Gaudens studied at Cooper Union and the National Academy of Design in New York, then at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris. He maintained studios in New York, Paris, and Cornish, New Hampshire.
Tour Guidance: Modeling sessions took place at Hotel Albert on East 11th Street in New York over 5 sittings of 2-3 hours each while Stevenson was receiving tuberculosis treatment. The relief was exhibited in Indianapolis and seen by 60,000 visitors before being acquired by John Herron Art Institute in 1912. Stevenson himself pronounced it a 'speaking likeness.' Dimensions: H. 17 9/16 x W. 17 3/16 x Th. 1/2 in.
Connections: Connection to Poetry and Art Theme Tour. Compare with other portrait reliefs and medallions. Note the integration of text and image.
Sources/Bibliography: Gift of Norman and Judith Topper.
Micro Summary: Saint-Gaudens' bronze portrait relief captures Scottish author Robert Louis Stevenson reclining in bed during tuberculosis treatment in New York, with Stevenson's own poetry inscribed in the background. Modeled over five sittings in 1887-88, this intimate portrayal contrasts smooth and textured surfaces while commemorating the friendship between sculptor and writer. The IMA's 1910 cast was exhibited to 60,000 visitors before entering the collection in 1912.

Title: Still Life with Hummingbird
Artwork Description: In 1870 Chase moved to St. Louis, where his family had relocated after losing their shoe business in Indianapolis. He hoped to support himself by satisfying the Victorian taste for still-life paintings of flowers and fruit. This early example of Chase's still-life painting suggests his awareness of other American artists. The hummingbird motif probably derives from the work of Martin Johnson Heade, and the bouquet recalls John LaFarge's floral arrangements. Chase considered flowers "the most difficult" things to paint, which may account for their scarcity in his work.
