Yet in 1872 his success in still-life painting induced a group of local patrons to allow Chase to resume this education by sponsoring his attendance at the Royal Academy in Munich.
Artist Biography: William Merritt Chase was born in Ninevah, Indiana and studied under Barton Hayes in Indianapolis and then briefly at the National Academy of Design. Due to the interest and generosity of several art patrons, Chase was able to take a five-year trip to Munich, where he studied at the city's Royal Academy. In 1878, Chase returned to New York City, opened his Tenth Street Studio and developed his signature impressionist style. He was a member of America's influential group of impressionists known as The Ten, but was also an extremely influential teacher. Chase opened the first summer school of landscape painting at his summer home in Shinnecock, Long Island. He also taught at the Chase School in New York, which he founded, and the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. His students included such famous artists as Marsden Hartley, Charles Demuth, Edward Hopper, Georgia O'Keeffe and Charles Sheeler.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Ronald G. Pisano. William Merritt Chase: The Complete Catalogue of Known and Documents Work by William Merritt Chase (1849-1916), Vol. 2: Portraits in Oil, New Haven Connecticut: Yale University Press, 2007. ISBN-13: 978-0300110210
Micro Summary: William Merritt Chase created this still life painting in the early 1870s while living in St. Louis, hoping to support himself by catering to Victorian tastes for floral and fruit paintings. The work shows influences from other American artists, particularly Martin Johnson Heade's hummingbird motifs and John LaFarge's floral arrangements. Despite Chase considering flowers "the most difficult" subjects to paint, his success with still lifes like this one impressed local patrons enough that they sponsored his artistic education at the Royal Academy in Munich in 1872.

Title: Summer Pastorale
Artwork Description: Also known as the View of Kallenfels the painting is in the naturalistic vein. The story it tells is that of a peasant family wading through a stream to take the path up to their home in the distant mountains. The peasants' path seems to lead into the forest and their village is pictured as being further up the mountain near the peak of Kallenfels (the mountain). I wonder how long it will take them to reach their home. Where did they come from? Where have they been? Whittredge's landscapes are close to nature and carefully composed. Always modest and serene. Summer Pastorale is a "quiet" painting. Idealistic. No surprises. There are no billowing storm clouds, nothing to indicate movement. Just a perfect summer day.
Artist Biography: Whittredge was born in Springfield, Ohio, in 1820. He had little education but a longing to be an artist so he worked at whatever options were provided him. His first venture was to serve an apprenticeship as a sign painter to his brother-in-law. Then, in 1842, Whittredge opened a daguerreotype studio in Indianapolis and when it proved unsuccessful, he closed the business. But before he could leave Indianapolis, he became seriously ill and recuperated for a year in the home of a family friend, Henry Ward Beecher, to regain his strength. His next venture was portrait painting in Charleston, WV, and this too was a bad arrangement that soon ended. He then decided to concentrate on landscapes and was very surprised at his overnight success. His first surviving landscape is Scene near Hawk's Nest (1845, Cincinnati, Ohio) which was painted in the picturesque manner of the Hudson River School artists. He adopted the style of Thomas Doughty originally and then later on, Thomas Cole. His art work usually depicted hills with a lake or stream; distant figures and a far away village. In May, 1849, he left for Europe for further training. There he enjoyed the protection of Emanuel Gottlieb Leutze and attended the Dusseldorf Akademie. Leaving Germany, he joined a circle of friends touring the Harz Mountains and from then on, his paintings followed the naturalistic vein. The summer of 1856 was spent sketching in Switzerland and in September, he and his friends moved to Rome. He remained in Rome for three years painting scenic landscapes as souvenirs for tourists. Whittredge returned to America in 1859. The height of his career came in the mid-1870s when he served two terms as President of the National Academy of Design. Whittredge continued to paint with some regularity to the age of 83, from his home "Hillcrest" in Summit, New Jersey. He died at the age of 89.
Tour Guidance: Primary Tours: Use mountains as the theme of the tour. Ask students to find the distant figures in similar landscapes. Ask students where they think the family is going? Other Tours: Discuss the Hudson River School artists and similarities in landscapes. Discuss why the painting is called Summer Pastorale. Include other paintings on the tour with the same characteristics. The tour could be comprised of all landscapes, with that as the theme.
Connections: Alaska about 1889, by Albert Bierstadt. Compare backgrounds with Hudson River School artists and the use of vast scales and mountains. Loch Long, 1867, Robert Scott Duncanson. Scene is typical of Hudson River School artists: small figures, misty mountains, sun-dappled shore, expansive vista. Lake Shwanangunk, 1863 by Worthington Whittredge. Note the striking differences between the two works by the same artist. Landscape after Shen Zhou, 1800s. Wu Tao, Chinese 1840-1895. Ink and color on paper. Note the expansive landscape, vast scale. Trees shivering in the cold could also be small figures. Small sails on the horizon, coming home.
Sources/Bibliography: Jansen, Anthony F. "Worthington Whittredge". 1989. IMA Stout Library Files. Baur, John I.H., edited by. "Autobiography of Worthington Whittredge", 1942. IMA Stout Library Files. Grove, Volume 33. "The Dictionary of Art".
Micro Summary: Summer Pastorale depicts a peasant family wading through a stream toward their mountain home in this naturalistic Hudson River School landscape. Painted in Germany, it showcases Whittredge's serene, carefully composed style with quiet idealism and perfect summer day atmosphere. The painting exemplifies his characteristic modest treatment of nature with distant figures and expansive mountain vistas.

Title: Still Life with Fish
Artwork Description: This balanced composition set against a dark background reflects Chase's Munich training. Famous for his rapid technique, Chase claimed he could return at least one fish to market fresh enough to be sold. In 1904, Chase began a series of fish subjects, which was highly acclaimed. This canvas is a spirited example of the genre. There can be little doubt that Chase had seen similar still lifes by the French artist Édouard Manet from the mid-1860s. This broadly painted and carefully balanced composition of shiny fish set against a dark, contrasting background hearkens back to Chase's training in Munich during the 1870s. The painting was one of the artist's favorites. In a letter of 1915 to the IMA (then known as the Art Association of Indianapolis), Chase wrote, "…I am pleased to know that you care for my fish picture. I feel sure this is the best one I have painted, and I would be much pleased to have it permanently in the Art Association."
Artist Biography: William Merritt Chase was a versatile painter of landscapes, portraits, and still lifes. In fact, he was widely esteemed as the foremost American still-life painter of his era. Born in Nineveh, Indiana, Chase spent a short period as a pupil of Barton Stone Hays, an Indianapolis portrait painter. He continued his studies in New York at the National Academy. Later, he traveled extensively in Europe after studying in Munich. In 1878, he returned to New York, where he made his home. He exerted great influence upon the younger American painters through his teaching. Although his approach was realistic, he invested everything with a particular life and charm.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Pisano, Ronald. A Leading Spirit in American Art: William Merritt Chase, 1849-1916. Seattle: Henry Art Gallery, University of Washington, 1983.
Micro Summary: William Merritt Chase's "Still Life with Fish" showcases his renowned rapid painting technique and Munich training through its balanced composition of shiny fish against a dark background. Created as part of his highly acclaimed fish series that began in 1904, the work demonstrates Chase's ability to paint so quickly that he claimed he could return fish to market still fresh enough to sell. The painting reflects the influence of French artist Édouard Manet's similar still lifes from the 1860s. Chase considered this particular work his finest fish painting, expressing his pleasure that it would be permanently housed at the Indianapolis Museum of Art.

Title: The Artist's Party
Artwork Description: In this painting Delaney, with his back to the viewer, is drinking and conversing with a group of Abstract Expressionists in what resembles his apartment/studio at 26 Bond Street in New York. The person to his right is believed to be Jackson Pollock. The figures in the painting exhibit the strong influence of Thomas Hart Benton with the manner in which Delaney distorts the bone and muscular structure of their facial expressions and bodies.
Artist Biography: Joseph Delaney, was an American Expressionist painter and a Regionalist whose focus was New York City. He was born in Knoxville, Tennessee in 1904; he died November 21, 1991 in Knoxville, Tennessee. Delaney was the ninth of ten children born to a Methodist minister. He attended church regularly during his childhood and early adolescence. It was during these services that he showed an aptitude for art by drawing on Sunday School religious cards. At the age of thirteen Delaney received a fifty cent prize from his teacher for drawing a sparrow. Two years later, his father died which forced him to drop out of school after the ninth grade to help support his family. He worked as a golf caddie, hotel bellhop and dishwasher. He then began a two year period of riding the rails as a hobo in the Midwest. During those years he sketched various scenes of hobo life and did portraits of his vagabond friends. In 1930, Delaney moved to New York to study at the Art Students League where he remained a member until his death. He became a student of Thomas Hart Benton as did other fellow students, including Bruce Mitchell, Henry Stair and Jackson Pollock. Benton taught him lessons in composition and color. In addition, Benton had Delaney study Botticelli, Raphael and Michelangelo to learn to group figures in the Renaissance tradition. Delaney gave credit to his teacher, George Bridgman, for his ability to capture the human anatomy on canvas, something Delaney does not do in a similar manner. In 1931, Delaney exhibited his work at the first Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit. For over forty years that show provided the major outlet for him to exhibit his work. During those years he did drawings of many well-known people who visited the show including Eartha Kitt, Arlene Francis, Eleanor Roosevelt and Tallulah Bankhead. In 1935, Delaney began work with the W.P.A. (Works Progress Administration) Artists Project painting murals at various government sites until the W.P.A. terminated the project in 1943. In 1964, he was a sketch artist for the Ghana Exhibit at the 1964-65 New York World's Fair. In the summer of 1968, he taught for the Art Students League at a workshop sponsored by the Ford Foundation at the Vermont Academy. From 1978-80, Delaney participated in the CETA (Comprehensive Employment and Training Act) project as an "artist in residence". The CETA project was terminated in 1980 and Delaney, at the age of 76, returned full time to his studio. Delaney returned to Knoxville in 1986, where he became the University of Tennessee-Knoxville's first Artist in Residence, the position he held until his death in 1991.
Tour Guidance: Primary tours: Use as part of the theme tour "Voices and Visions: African American Artists at the IMA". Use as part of the theme tour "American Spotlight". Use as part of the theme tour "Learning to Look". For other tours: Discuss what the figures are doing. Are they laughing? Are they having an argument or a discussion? Have the visitor describe the living quarters. Is it a home or a building with several floors? How do they know? What's the dominant color(s)?
Connections: The Tie Rack by Jacob Lawrence; American Gallery. Compare this artist's painting of his apartment closet in Harlem, New York with Delaney's apartment/studio in New York. Both took advantage of their personal living space but with a different subject matter. Henry Look Unhitching by Thomas Hart Benton; American Gallery. Contrast Delaney with Benton, Delaney's teacher, a leader of the Regionalist group who favored images of the American rural Midwest. There is little resemblance in style to the The Artist's Party painting.
Sources/Bibliography: Aaron Galleries, Chicago, IL. "A Collection of Works on Paper by Joseph Delaney and other African-American Masters". Yates, Sam; Director Ewing Gallery Univ. of TN, Knoxville ©1986 "Joseph Delaney"
Micro Summary: The Artist's Party depicts Delaney (with his back to viewer) conversing with Abstract Expressionists including Jackson Pollock in his Bond Street studio. Delaney's work shows strong influence from his teacher Thomas Hart Benton in the distorted anatomical treatment of figures. The painting captures the vibrant artistic community of mid-century New York with its intimate gathering of creative minds.

Title: Afternoon Tea
Artwork Description: The artist shows women in a beautiful sunlight garden landscape. The Giverny group of artists became good friends, sharing models and props. The garden shown in the painting was probably the one in the Frieseke yard. Frieseke's wife shared a passion for gardening with Monet. The wives of these artists were friends and often used as models. Miller has used the prop of a Japanese parasol to frame his subjects in the painting. An emphasis has been placed on patterns and bold contrasts in sunlight, often used by the American Impressionists.
Artist Biography: Miller was a native of St. Louis, Missouri, born in 1875. He worked briefly as an artist reporter for the St. Louis Dispatch. Like many of the Giverny group of Midwest American artists, he studied at the Chicago Art Institute. He later received a scholarship to attend the Academie Julian in Paris and later taught at a rival school—Academie Colarossi. Miller won medals at the Paris Salon and was appointed a Knight of the French Legion of Honor. Miller arrived in Giverny in 1907, to teach the students of Mary Coleman Wheeler during their summer school art sessions. Mary was an artist and educator from Providence Rhode Island. Miller and Frieseke became good friends in Giverny and had the distinction of being known as the leaders of the American group of artists. This included Frieseke, Lawton Parker, Guy Rose, Edmund Greacen, Karl Anderson, William Buehr and Louis Ritman. These men not only painted together but socialized as well. They shared models and drew inspiration from Miller's studio that was filled with collections of fans, parasols, ceramics and other props. Their wives became good friends and they all created a bond a long way from home in America. Frieseke's garden was a favorite spot for afternoon tea, which is probably the scene of this IMA painting. In Miller's view, "art's mission was not literary, the telling of a story but decorative, the conveying of a pleasant optical sensation." He remained in Giverny until late 1914 when the dangers of WWI forced him to return to America. He eventually moved to Pasadena Ca. and taught at the Stickney School of Art, thus playing an important role in influencing the development of Impressionism in Southern California. In 1918 he moved to Provincetown, Mass. becoming a prominent member of the local artist's colony. Miller painted a series of murals in 1923 for the Missouri State Capitol building in Jefferson City, Mo. In his later years he painted marine subjects and he passed away in Florida in 1943.
Tour Guidance: Discuss the term genré and how it is applied to this everyday ritual the wives enjoyed in having afternoon tea. The formal clothing suggests a more relaxed, genteel life style of the sitters.
Connections: Norman Rockwell's genré illustration—The Love Song. Antoine Watteau—The Country Dance. Jean Honoré Fragonard—The Joys of Motherhood. Jacob Jordaens—Portrait of a Lady.
Sources/Bibliography: IMA collection information.
Micro Summary: Afternoon Tea captures the genteel lifestyle of the Giverny artist colony, depicting women in Frieseke's garden with Japanese parasols and bold sunlight patterns. As co-leader of the American Giverny group, Miller emphasized decorative beauty over narrative, creating a pleasant optical sensation. The painting exemplifies American Impressionism's focus on light, pattern, and the everyday rituals of the artist community abroad.

Title: Landscape near Dachau
Artwork Description: The subdued tones typical of the Munich School are applied with a freedom of execution unusual for the period. This broad landscape exemplifies Currier's bold, emotional response to the powers of nature. Currier studied in Munich and sometimes painted the dark moors of nearby Dachau. Currier often painted the dark moors beside the hill of nearby Dachau, recording his views with vigorous, spontaneous brushwork. He applied the subdued tones typical of the Munich School with a remarkable freedom of execution. This landscape, with its rich surface texture exemplifies Curriers emotional response to the powers of nature.
Artist Biography: Currier was born in Massachusetts, where his father owned a marble cutting establishment. He traveled to Munich and was part of the group of American students at the Royal Academy. American painters working or studying in Munich did not spend all their time indoors in the Academy studios. They also traveled to villages in the German countryside to set up their canvases in the open air. Currier helped other American students at the Royal Academy with their landscape painting during their free time. Currier married and lived for many years at Dachau, where he painted some of his best work.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: White, Nelson C. The Life and Art of J. Frank Currier. Riverside, California: Riverside Press, 1936.
Micro Summary: "Landscape near Dachau" by Joseph Frank Currier depicts the dark moors near Munich, where the artist studied. The painting exemplifies Currier's bold, emotional response to nature's power through vigorous, spontaneous brushwork and rich surface texture. While employing the subdued tones characteristic of the Munich School, Currier applied them with unusual freedom of execution for the period. The work demonstrates his ability to capture the atmospheric qualities of the German landscape with both technical skill and expressive intensity.

Title: Chinese Fishing Village, Monterey Bay, California
Artwork Description: This canvas contains the broken light and color of the Impressionists, but its modulated hues create a quiet, contemplative mood. Brown served as professor of art at Stanford University during the time this work was painted. During his tenure at Stanford University, Brown painted this view of Monterey Bay. While he never travelled abroad, Brown's art certainly came under the influence of French Impressionism, which he probably absorbed from his many artist friends. Chinese Fishing Village makes use of the broken light and color of the Impressionists, yet it remains a painting of subtly modulated hues that achieve a quiet, contemplative mood. In this sense, the landscape is close to those of Brown's contemporaries, Henry Ward Ranger, Chauncey Foster Ryder, and Dwight Tryon, whose interests were in atmosphere and tone rather than the bright colors of the Impressionists.
Artist Biography: Bolton Coit Brown was the founder of the art department at Stanford University in Palo Alto, California, and a founder of the Woodstock Art Colony in New York. Brown received his painting degrees from Syracuse University in New York. For more than a decade, he served as Professor of Art at Stanford University in California, where he became chairman of the university's department of drawing and painting. He resigned after being chastised for using nude models in his advanced life-drawing class. Brown took up mountain climbing, making maps and drawings of California's Sierra Nevada Mountains. He climbed and named Mount Ericsson and Mount Stanford. Mount Bolton Brown was named after him in 1922, and Lucy Pass was named after his wife, who was also a mountaineer. Throughout these daring exploits, Brown continued to paint.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Adams, Clinton. Crayonstone: The Life and Work of Bolton Brown. Albuquerque: University of New Mexico Press, 1993.
Micro Summary: This painting by Bolton Coit Brown depicts a serene view of Monterey Bay's Chinese fishing village, created during his tenure as art professor at Stanford University. While Brown never traveled abroad, his work shows clear influence from French Impressionism through his artist connections, employing broken light and color techniques. However, unlike typical Impressionist works, Brown uses subtly modulated hues that create a quiet, contemplative atmosphere. The painting aligns with contemporaries like Henry Ward Ranger and Dwight Tryon, who prioritized atmospheric tone over the bright colors characteristic of traditional Impressionism.

Title: Cliff Rock—Appledore
Artwork Description: Many critics thought that Hassam was most influenced by Claude Monet, but Hassam stressed his debt to John Constable and JMW Turner. However, Hassam's work was always strongly individual. He might have used the bright colors and broken brushwork used in paintings by Monet and Camille Pissaro, but he did not use these methods to dissolve his subjects. He preferred structural clarity and solidness of form that keeps objects intact and space clearly legible. Luminism was American in style, in subject and in attitude. Aspects of the style – concern for light and atmosphere as well as the clarity of form became part of American impressionistic practice. However, some of Hassam's paintings, e.g. Poppies, Isles of Shoals, are better understood not as impressionist paintings, but as related to the reactions to impressionism by such artists as Georges Seurat and Paul Signac. Childe Hassam's paintings of the Isles of Shoals are probably his best works. He met Celia Thaxter around l880 and began visiting the Isles of Shoal in l884. All his images of the isle fall into 2 groups: those between l890 and l894, (when Thaxter died) and those from l899 to l916, when Hassam visited the island often. A number of paintings are mostly outdoor scenes set in Thaxter's flower garden or nearby. One of his best paintings is the Room of Flowers which is cheerful, and gay and painted in the high-keyed palate and the wiry brush stroke for which Hassam is best known. The painting was done in the year that Mrs. Thaxter died. His work was always appreciated and he had no trouble selling his paintings. Hassam had it easy in life. He had the funds and his was not a bohemian life. He was married and he and his wife traveled to Europe and back. He had a facile style, he was prolific and industrious and his art was very popular. He won many awards, but he was not an innovator. However, he created many beautiful and individual paintings. He avoided turmoil in his work so you didn't see the harsher aspects of city life. However, in American Impressionism and Realism, by Barbara Weinberg, Doreen Bolger and David Park Curry, the argument is made that American impressionism and realism are linked: that each was derived from French models, and that nationalism, optimism and nostalgia characterized each. Particularly in Hassam's flag pictures, the nationalism comes through and the paintings become patriotic statements of the U.S. support of WWI and of U.S. technological and military superiority and the triumph of democracy over tyranny. Hassam is quoted as saying that 'I believe the thoroughfares of the great French metropolis are not one whit more interesting than the streets of New York.' The impressionists and the realists, were colored by their desire to preserve the way of life they enjoyed in the past and their fear of what the future might bring. Hassam's paintings of the Old Church at Lyme and the paintings of New England are all efforts to memorialize their lives. And these landscapes are interpretations of optimistic and nationalistic values. The impressionists chose to depict modern life. In doing this, they captured a new vision of the American countryside, city and home. They consciously chose to paint subjects that were intentionally American. Shortly before Hassam died in 1935, he arranged to leave all the paintings in his studio to the American Academy of Arts and Letters. They were to be sold to establish a fund for the purchase of American works to be donated to museums. Cliff Rock is painted in Maine. It was painted in 1903. It is almost pointelistic for one of Hassam's landscapes. It is 24 x 35 inch landscape. It is affected by the Japanese print makers because you seem to see it from above.
Artist Biography: Childe Hassam was the son of a wealthy merchant and was born in Dorchester, Massachusetts in 1859. He took drawing lessons as a child and teen and tried working as a bookkeeper in 1876. He did not last long and was soon doing woodcuts for a Boston engraver. In 1877-1878, he studied at the Boston Art Club and in 1879, he took a painting class. He opened a studio in Boston and supported himself by doing illustrations for 'Scribner's Magazine' and for 'Harper's New Magazine', and for 'The Century'. He also did landscapes of Boston and its residents. In 1883 he was in Great Britain with a fellow painter, Edmond H. Garrett. He was in Paris from 1886 to 1889 and worked in a studio in Pigalle and by 1887 was producing works that responded to contemporary paintings by the Impressionists. When he returned to the U.S., he settled in New York City, and became close friends and professional colleagues with J. Alden Weir and John H. Twachtman. During the 1890s and the next two decades, he painted during the summers in New England. His favorite spots were Old Lyme Connecticut and Appledore, on the Isles of Shoals, off the New Hampshire Coast. In l897 he helped to organize The Ten American Painters, including himself, Weir and Twachtman. They had all resigned from the Society of American Artists. Also included were Willard Metcalf, Robert Reid Edward F. Simmons and Thomas W. Dewing. Most of the painters were based in New York, but there were three based in Boston; Joseph De Camp, Frank Benson, Edmund G. Tarbell. When Twachtman died in 1902, William Merritt Chase replaced him in The Ten American Painters.
Tour Guidance: Could talk about colors and Hassam's use of colors e.g., Is rock white? What colors does he use?
Connections: Hassam could be compared with Monet. He was the most like the French impressionists of the American impressionists. He could be compared with Luminist paintings He could be compared with the Gauguin painting The Flagolet Player. It is the same kind of perspective. The painting could be compared with Georgia O'Keefe's Jimson Weed. Compare with Van Gogh and his use of colors and paints. Compare with The Green Wave by Lacomb
Micro Summary: "Cliff Rock—Appledore" is a 1903 landscape painting by American Impressionist Childe Hassam, created during his productive period visiting the Isles of Shoals in Maine. The 24 x 35 inch work demonstrates Hassam's distinctive approach to Impressionism, employing nearly pointillistic technique while maintaining his characteristic structural clarity and solid forms rather than dissolving subjects like his French contemporaries. The painting shows influence from Japanese printmakers through its elevated viewpoint, reflecting Hassam's ability to synthesize various artistic influences into his own American style. This work exemplifies Hassam's commitment to depicting distinctly American subjects with optimistic and nationalistic undertones, part of his broader effort to create a uniquely American form of Impressionism."

Title: He Is Risen
Artwork Description: This work is based on the woodcut by Albrecht Durer (see attached). Durer did several series of woodcuts with the same theme. Bearden produced a series of works, The Passion of Christ, in 1945 which was exhibited at the Koontz Gallery in New York. In the catalogue for this exhibition, Bearden wrote that the life of Christ is one of the greatest expressions of man's humanism. This cubist piece with its bold, black lines and colored planes has the appearance of stained glass. Notice the similarity in pose of the various individuals in this scene and the pose of the figure of Christ.
Artist Biography: African-American painter and illustrator born September 2, 1911, Charlotte, North Carolina; died March 12, 1988 in New York City. Bearden's parents moved to NYC while he was still a small child and he became acquainted with many of the members of the Harlem Renaissance. Bearden graduated from NYU with a degree in education, having taken extensive courses in art and working on several student publications as a cartoonist and art editor. Bearden was primarily a self-taught artist although he did attend the Art Students League and later, the Sorbonne in Paris on the GI Bill from 1950-54. In Paris he met James Baldwin, Braque and Brancusi. Bearden experimented with various styles, first American Scene and later by the mid 1940s the abstract figurative image as is seen in his depiction of the crucifixion, Golgotha. Bearden was active in the Harlem community, attending the Harlem Artist's Guild, and participating in 306 Group activities. Included in the 306 Group were Norman Lewis, Charles Alston, Ralph Ellison and Jacob Lawrence. The Passion of Christ, a series of watercolor and oil paintings, was exhibited in 1945 at the Koontz Gallery and was later purchased by the Museum of Modern Art, the first of Bearden's works to be purchased by a museum. By the late 40s, Bearden was one of the most respected modernists in America and had exhibited at the Whitney Museum Annuals several times. In 1963, Bearden and Norman Lewis helped to found the Spiral Group whose mission was to define the role of the Black artist within the context of the Civil Rights movement. Bearden's work was influenced by early European artists (such as Durer), as well as other Koontz Gallery artists such as Hans Hofmann, and Robert Motherwell, and by the works of American and European modernists such as Stuart Davies, George Braque, Fernand Leger and Constantin Brancusi. Bearden's art portrays the human image in terms of the African-American experience. Bearden's media included paint, and beginning in 1963-64, collages made from torn paper, tiles, photo enlargements, and patchwork quilts as well as other materials.
Tour Guidance: Use as part of a tour on African-American artists. Use as part of a tour on religion—compare with pieces in the European galleries of a similar subject. Use as part of a tour on modernism—compare with other cubist pieces in the European galleries.
Connections: Compare the dark lines and colored panels with the Tiffany window in the rotunda. Bearden worked as an illustrator-compare his work with other artists with a similar background such as Robert Henri. This is oil on a gessoed panel—connections can be drawn to early Renaissance pieces in the European collection which were done with tempera on panel.
Sources/Bibliography: Albrecht Durer, The Resurrection of Christ, 1510
Micro Summary: "He Is Risen" by Romare Bearden is a cubist interpretation based on Albrecht Dürer's woodcut, created as part of Bearden's 1945 series "The Passion of Christ" exhibited at the Koontz Gallery in New York. The artwork features bold black lines and colored planes that create a stained glass-like appearance. Bearden wrote that Christ's life represents one of humanity's greatest expressions of humanism. The composition shows multiple figures whose poses mirror that of the central Christ figure, emphasizing the universal nature of the resurrection theme.

Title: Portrait of James Whitcomb Riley
Artwork Description: Riley is posed in a contemplative manner holding a book to suggest his profession as a writer. In 1898 Riley delivered a poetry reading to benefit the Art Association of Indianapolis, the forerunner of the Indianapolis Museum of Art. James Whitcomb Riley's portrait was commissioned by the Art Association of Indianapolis and paid for with funds raised at an 1898 benefit performance, in which the poet read his own works. Sargent charged only one-third his normal fee because he often agreed to paint celebrities at minimal cost simply for publicity. Sargent captures the Hoosier poet's personality in this study. While the likeness was received with mixed reviews by Riley's friends, the portrait has an engaging directness befitting the poet's no-nonsense nature
Artist Biography: Sargent was born and raised in Florence, Italy, by his expatriate American parents. He moved to Paris, where he studied under the famed portraitist Carolus-Duran and attended the École des Beaux Arts, in 1874. Exhibited at the 1879 Salon, Sargent's portrait of Carolus-Duran made an impression on the public and attracted many patrons. Another work, Portrait of Madame X (1884), brought him even more attention due to its audacious display of the sitter's décolletage. The artist's final years were spent in London, but he made periodic visits to America for the purpose of carrying out portrait commissions. Sargent was the most fashionable portraitist in England and the United States because of his brilliant technique, which flattered his subjects.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Ormond, Richard and Elaine Kilmurray. John Singer Sargent: The Later Portraits. New Haven, Connecticut: Yale University Press, 2003.
Micro Summary: John Singer Sargent's "Portrait of James Whitcomb Riley" depicts the Hoosier poet in a contemplative pose holding a book, symbolizing his literary profession. The portrait was commissioned by the Art Association of Indianapolis in 1898 and funded through proceeds from a benefit performance where Riley read his own poetry. Sargent painted the work for only one-third of his usual fee, as he often reduced costs for celebrity subjects in exchange for publicity. The portrait captures Riley's direct, no-nonsense personality, though it received mixed reviews from the poet's friends.

Title: The Flight of Europa
Artwork Description: Europa, a Phoenician princess, was abducted by Zeus who, disguised as a bull, lured her onto his back and carried her to Crete. This sculpture depicts Europa seated on the bull's back, Cupid whispering in her ear and dolphins swimming alongside. Piece is gilded bronze with marble base. The marble base depicts the water in which the bull is swimming. Manship's pieces often are based on mythological themes.
Artist Biography: American sculptor, Born 1885 St. Paul, MN, Died 1966 New York, NY. Manship grew up in St. Paul, MN attending evening classes at the St. Paul Institute of Art from 1892 to 1903. In 1905 he went to New York where he studied at the Art Students League becoming an assistant to sculptor Solon Borglum. In 1906, Manship moved to Philadelphia where he entered the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. In 1909 he won the Prix de Rome which allowed him to travel to Rome where he studied at the American Academy. There he received technical training and traveled extensively in Italy, Greece and Egypt. He was greatly influenced by the abstract qualities of Etruscan, ancient Greek and Egyptian art. Manship returned to the United States in 1912 and became established in New York. His style was characterized by 'simplified contours' and 'bold asymmetrical design' and bronze was his medium of choice. He received many public commissions, among which is the bronze Prometheus located in the fountain of Rockefeller Center. 'It depicts a sleek, streamlined figure moving through space, and the void is treated with as much importance as the solid.' Manship was associated with the Art Deco movement. Manship always worked in a clean shirt, bow tie and a clean smock. This artist was more interested in line and rhythm ('the spirit which the artist puts into his creation.....') than in meticulous anatomical detail.
Tour Guidance: Discuss the location of the bull and the clues to his whereabouts. Discuss the opposing forces and lines which are part of this sculpture. Discuss the Art Deco movement of the 1920's and 1930's.
Connections: Connect this piece with other objects such as archaic Greek or Egyptian pieces. Connect with other objects based on classical or mythological themes in the American and European galleries such as Diana by Saint-Gaudens. Compare and contrast with Venus Anadyomene also by Manship, as well as other sculptures in the galleries with respect to materials. Compare with animals in Africa and Asia. Compare with other mythological themes. Compare with tomb guardians. Compare with mask of cow in Africa.
Micro Summary: Paul Manship's "The Flight of Europa" depicts the Greek myth where Zeus, disguised as a bull, abducts the Phoenician princess Europa by carrying her across the sea to Crete. The gilded bronze sculpture shows Europa seated on the bull's back with Cupid whispering in her ear, while dolphins swim alongside them. The marble base represents the water through which they travel, characteristic of Manship's mythologically-themed works.

Title: Calypso
Artwork Description: The elusive qualities of sunshine and breezes are captured in Calypso's flowing classical garb, the billowy clouds and brilliantly colored flowers. In Greek mythology Calypso was the sea nymph who saved Odysseus from a shipwreck. This mythological subject is unusual in Hitchcock's work. The sea nymph Calypso saved Odysseus from a shipwreck and detained him for seven years on her island with the promise of immortality. The figure of Calypso, clad in flowing classical garb, rises against a shallow backdrop of brilliantly colored flowers and billowing clouds. Capturing the elusive qualities of sunshine and gentle breezes, Hitchcock contrasts her fixed stance with the ever-changing effects of light and air.
Artist Biography: George Hitchcock was a graduate of Brown University and Harvard Law School. After an unsuccessful law career, he left the United States and spent the next decade studying in London, Paris, Dusseldorf, and The Hague. During the 1880s, Harrison settled in Holland and became one of America's more well-known expatriate painters. His subjects included landscapes, floral studies, and peasants. His impressionistic paintings of brightly colored tulip fields in Holland, with Dutch peasant women in their magnificent costumes, were his favorite scenes. Hitchcock worked in Holland and became one of America's leading expatriate painters.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Quick, Michael. American Expatriate Painters of the Late Nineteenth Century. Dayton: Dayton Art Museum, 1976.
Micro Summary: George Hitchcock's "Calypso" depicts the Greek sea nymph who saved Odysseus from shipwreck and detained him on her island for seven years. The figure of Calypso stands in flowing classical garments against a backdrop of brilliantly colored flowers and billowing clouds. Hitchcock masterfully captures the elusive qualities of sunshine and gentle breezes, contrasting Calypso's fixed stance with the ever-changing effects of light and air. This mythological subject represents an unusual departure from Hitchcock's typical artistic themes.

Title: Pool in Adirondacks
Artwork Description: Oil painting created about 1875-1878, depicting a pool in the Adirondacks. Originally working in the Hudson River School tradition, Blakelock developed a unique style of luminous, introspective, nocturnal scenes bathed in eerie moonlit atmosphere. This work shows his characteristic approach to landscape with emphasis on mood and atmosphere.
Artist Biography: Ralph Albert Blakelock (1847-1919) was born in New York City and attended the College of the City of New York, intending to become a physician. He began art education at Cooper Union but declined his father's offer for advanced training. Blakelock wandered three years through the American West on horseback, spending time with Native Americans. He was largely self-taught and became known for luminous, introspective nocturnal scenes. Tragically, he lived in poverty, suffered a mental breakdown, and was committed to an institution while his work gained recognition and value.
Tour Guidance: Blakelock was a great artist but poor businessman who lived with his wife and nine children in poverty. While he languished in a mental institution, his paintings began receiving recognition and prices rose, though none of this benefited his family. His paintings became so valuable they were extensively forged, making Blakelock the most forged artist in America. He's best known as a romantic visionary exhibiting modernist tendencies unique for his time.
Connections: Compare with Hudson River School works to see evolution toward modernism. Note luminous quality and atmospheric effects. Reference: Karen O. Janovy, Janice Drie, The Unknown Blakelock, Sheldon Memorial Art Gallery, 2008.
Sources/Bibliography: Reference: Karen O. Janovy, Janice Drie, The Unknown Blakelock, Sheldon Memorial Art Gallery, 2008.
Micro Summary: Blakelock's Adirondacks pool painting from the 1870s demonstrates his evolution from Hudson River School tradition toward unique luminous nocturnal scenes. Self-taught after brief Cooper Union training and Western travels with Native Americans, Blakelock developed modernist tendencies while suffering poverty and mental illness. Ironically, as he languished institutionalized, his work gained such value it became America's most forged, though neither artist nor family benefited.

Title: Glow of Gold, Gleam of Pearl
Loch Long
Artwork Description: This scene is typical of the Hudson River School painting in its inclusion of small figures, misty mountains, sun-dappled shore and expansive vista. Duncanson produced a series of Scottish landscapes stimulated by his travels and the literature of Sir Walter Scott. Some feel that his best work is reflected in the landscapes of his middle and late periods which define him as a Midwestern romantic realist painter. Moral messages and themes of idealism along with coded messages were sometimes included in his work. In other well-known works, Duncanson used literary subjects in depictions such as Uncle Tom and Little Eva, Lotus Eaters and Pompeii.
Artist Biography: Duncanson was born in Seneca, New York to an African American (free woman) mother and a well to do Scottish-Canadian father. Early childhood was spent in Canada and later he and his mother moved to a community near Cincinnati, Ohio. Duncanson's rise from a house painter to a recognized landscape painter occurred there around 1842 when he began exhibiting in the area. His progress as a landscape painter caught the attention of Nicholas Longworth, a real estate magnate and prominent Cincinnati Arts Patron. Around 1850 Longworth commissioned Duncanson to decorate the entry halls of his home, 'Belmont', which today is the Taft Museum in downtown Cincinnati, Ohio. It was estimated it took about 2 years to complete this ambitious project. The eight trompe-l'oeil framed murals are 9' x 6 1/2', with 3 framed floral bouquets over the doorways, also popular subjects at that time. The murals were recognized as very important and unique paintings created in the United States during the antebellum period of history. Duncanson's landscapes were influenced by the Hudson River School artists who painted romantic images of America's wilderness, untainted by man. With the help of the Freedman's Aid Society of Ohio, Duncanson made several trips to Europe. His position as a free man of color became very much a part of his consciousness and he became associated with the abolitionist leaders in the Cincinnati area. Due to his light complexion, he was sometimes confused as being a white artist. However, he was able to overcome the ordeals of racial discrimination and emerged as the first African American to rise to prominence in the International Euro-American art community. He was known for his travels and besides Cincinnati; he lived in Detroit, Michigan, and painted countless landscape scenes in North Carolina, Pennsylvania, New England, Canada and Scotland. Towards the end of his life Duncanson suffered a tragic dementia with delusions and outbursts. At the time they believed he suffered from arsenic lead poisoning that accumulated from his exposure to house paints and artist's pigments. By 1870 his psychotic behavior became public knowledge. During the installation of one of his exhibitions he suffered a seizure and collapsed. He was hospitalized and two years later passed away on December 12, 1872. A national touring retrospective exhibition of his work, "Lifting the Veil", was assembled in America to show more than 50 of his paintings after his death. This impressive exhibit gave him added recognition and respect as a talented African American artist.
Tour Guidance: Voices and Visions: African American Artists at the IMA. Use as part of a tour on Landscape paintings of the Hudson River School. Use as part of a tour comparing American landscape paintings with European landscape paintings.
Connections: Frederic Church: painter of epic landscapes (Hudson River School painters believed that landscape art could be a path to moral and spiritual transformation). Joshua Shaw: The Pioneers. Worthington Whittredge: Lake Shwanangunk. Charles Codman: The Moose Hunter. Jasper Cropsey: Summer, Lake Ontario. Asher Durand: Landscape with Covered Wagon.
Sources/Bibliography: IMA collection information. Grove Art Online.
Micro Summary: Loch Long exemplifies Duncanson's Hudson River School style with its misty mountains, sun-dappled shore, and expansive Scottish vista inspired by his travels and Sir Walter Scott's literature. As the first African American to rise to prominence in the International Euro-American art community, Duncanson overcame racial discrimination through his romantic landscape paintings. The work represents his middle period, considered by many to be his finest, defining him as a Midwestern romantic realist painter who often embedded moral messages and idealism in his compositions.

Title: Rooftops, New York City
Artwork Description: This is an example of "precisionist" style. Precisionist works are hard edged, stark and sharply portrayed and highly geometrical. These works are cityscapes which show skyscrapers and factories but usually do not include people. These works have the illusion of loneliness and isolation. The lights are on but there are no people present.
Artist Biography: American precisionist painter, born October 17, 1886, New York City; died October 8, 1944, Lexington, KY. Fisk decided by his late teens to become an artist. Starting in 1904, he took classes at the Art Students' League, later taking classes at the National Academy of Design and spending two years studying with Robert Henri at his studio at 1947 Broadway. Here, students were exposed to a very modernist point of view and here also Fisk probably met Stuart Davis, who became a lifelong friend. In 1912, Fisk traveled to Paris to study at the Academie Moderne under Fauvist painters Othon Friesz and Pierre Laprade. While in Paris, Fisk became close to Charles Demuth, who was also at the Academie, and Marsden Hartley. Also in Paris were: Stuart Davis, Elie Nadelman, Edward Steichen, Alfred Maurer, among others. Many of these artists frequented the salons hosted by Gertrude and Leo Stein. Returning to New York in 1913, Fisk remained strongly influenced by Modernist artists. He regularly visited Alfred Stieglitz's gallery known as "291". Though living with his family, Fisk spent much time in Greenwich Village, moving in circles of artists, writers and others. This cultural "avant-garde" spent summers in Provincetown, Massachusetts which Fisk did as well. Fisk was represented by the Daniels Gallery, which also represented Demuth. His work began to be included in exhibitions that included works by other Modernists such as Hartley, Davies, O'Keeffe, Man Ray, and, in 1922, an exhibition that included Matisse, Picasso, Braque, Burchfield, Pousette-Dart and others. Among other friends was Eugene O'Neill whose sister-in-law Fisk married in the early 1920's. Though his career was progressing well, by the mid-1920's Fisk was tired of city life and in September 1926 he left his wife and moved to Lexington Kentucky, accepting a teaching position at the University of Kentucky. He remained there for the rest of his life, teaching drawing and painting classes, forming new friendships, and eventually remarrying. He began to work in printmaking, later having exhibitions of his work in Lexington and New York.
Tour Guidance: Compare this piece to other cityscapes nearby including Storrs' New York. Compare to Hopper's Hotel Lobby which also has the feel of isolation. How does each artist convey that feeling? Compare to other highly geometrical works, for example Lewitt's Wall Drawing. This painting is basically about light. What are the light sources and how does the artist use them?
Connections: Compare and contrast with Estes and other photorealist works.
Sources/Bibliography: Not provided in docent materials.
Micro Summary: Rooftops, New York City exemplifies Precisionist style with hard-edged geometric cityscapes that convey isolation and loneliness through lit but unpopulated buildings. Fisk studied with modernists in Paris and New York before teaching at the University of Kentucky. The painting focuses on light sources creating stark contrasts in this urban scene devoid of human presence.

Title: Composition 1
Artwork Description: One of Lewis's first abstract paintings, using varied textures inspired by unique architectural elements found in Harlem. The work demonstrates the use of rhythms, sounds, and forms of music and nature. Lewis was very proud of this painting and had it reproduced many times.
Artist Biography: Norman Lewis (1909-1979) was an African American abstract expressionist painter from Harlem. He was influenced by Van Gogh, Kandinsky, Cubism, and Mexican mural paintings. His works are in the collections of the Museum of Modern Art, Art Institute of Chicago, and High Museum of Art. Lewis was one of the few African American artists associated with Abstract Expressionism.
Tour Guidance: Tour uses: American Art, Places, Abstract Artists, Social Realism Artists, Artists from Harlem Community. Open-ended questions: What colors, lines, shapes do you see? What elements are repeated? Where is the light source? What mood does it create? Why might the artist use 'composition' in the title? What textures and tools might have been used? Suggested activity: Drawing lines with colored pencils for 1 minute, then while listening to jazz music or water sounds to see how lines/movements change.
Connections: Connect to Abstract Expressionism movement, Harlem Renaissance cultural context, relationship between visual art and music, architectural inspiration in abstract art.
Sources/Bibliography: Museum collections: MoMA, Art Institute of Chicago, High Museum of Art.
Micro Summary: Lewis's pioneering abstract work translates Harlem's architectural rhythms into varied textures and dynamic forms, influenced by Van Gogh, Kandinsky, and Mexican muralists. As one of few African American Abstract Expressionists, Lewis created compositions that evoke music and nature through line and movement. This early abstraction, which Lewis proudly reproduced multiple times, bridges social realism with pure abstraction.

Title: Picking Cotton
Artwork Description: This piece is borrowed from IPS for one year. Woodruff gave this piece to IPS in 1970. This piece was conserved by Harriet and Ray Warkel. This piece is very typical of his style, depicting the problems of Black Americans in there daily work. This is one of his Atlanta series were he captures the working conditions, and records what he sees. The bottom is very abstract as are the trees. He also captures figures is various shapes.
Artist Biography: He was born in Cairo, IL. 8/26/1900 Died in 1980. He was an American painter, printmaker and teacher and the leading artist of the Harlem Renaissance. He studied at the John Herron Institute, Indianapolis, the school of the Fogg Art Museum, Harvard University, Cambridge. Ma, the Academie Scandinave and The Academie Moderne, Paris. While in Paris he worked with Henry Ossawa Tanner (1931) and studied mural painting with Diego Rivera in Mexico City (1936). From the European schools he learned strong composition and the narrative power of Goya. He was concerned about the problems of the Black Americans and therefore capture them in all poor their social conditions, by capturing this in his murals and his paintings. In the South, Woodruff discovered and taught several talented artists including Frederick Flemister, Robert Neal and Albert Wells, all of these used Woodruff's bold style and methods. From the 1950's his work became increasingly abstract. He taught at the Harlem Community Art Center, New York (1945), Atlantic University (1931-45) and New York University (1945).
Tour Guidance: Tour Uses: Learning to Look or Highlights - Talk about the foreground, background, middle ground. What are they doing. Could this still be a scene from today. History Tour - Explain the African influence in the painting. Explain how the piece tells a story.
Connections: Frank Benson: Sunlight, Van Gogh
Sources/Bibliography: References:
Micro Summary: "Picking Cotton" by Hale Woodruff depicts the challenging daily work conditions of Black Americans as part of his Atlanta series documenting social realities. The artwork, donated to IPS in 1970, exemplifies Woodruff's distinctive style through its combination of figurative subjects rendered in various shapes against abstract elements like trees and background. Woodruff captures and records the working conditions he witnessed, using abstraction in the lower portion and trees while maintaining recognizable human figures throughout the composition.

Title: His Majesty Receives
Artwork Description: This painting shares in the tradition of narrative purpose and humor prevalent during the first half of the 19th century in America, but Beard's humor is more cutting. This satirical tone may have been a response to an America no longer innocent in the wake of the Civil War and the social strife that accompanied it. Animals in Beard's paintings represented humans, as evident in this painting showing animals clothed in human attire and standing on two feet. Beard poked fun at the new American who was no longer a "rustic" but who seemed instead to be secure and superior in his economic, intellectual, and cultural identity. Narrative elements were important to Beard's paintings, and he sometimes illustrated well-known stories, but he transformed them for his satirical purpose rather than merely illustrating them. This painting presents animals in a realistically rendered setting, but there are obvious clues, such as human posture and clothing and the dramatic black drape hanging from the trees behind "His Majesty," the fox, to suggest the artist has in mind another purpose for the scene beyond a typical forest gathering of animals. Consider a number of narrative elements in the painting that together might suggest meaning: the natural relationship between the various animals portrayed and the fox, the royal garb of the fox, the humble poses of the rabbits and other animals, the mysterious black drape, the look on the fox's face, the looks on the faces of the other animals, perhaps even the season of the year, and the double meaning of the word "receives" in the title. Consider a number of artistic elements in the painting that together support possible interpretations of the work: the touches of red, the black drape, the drab browns and grays of the setting and the other animals' attire, the movement created by the composition for emphasis on the drama represented.
Artist Biography: Born in 1824 in Painesville, Ohio. His family could trace its American roots to the early 17th century, but Beard was "raised in modest circumstances" because of his father's death shortly after Beard was born. His only art lessons came from his older brother, James Henry Beard (1812-1893), with whom William painted in New York during the 1840s. Best known for allegorical animal and landscape paintings. These types of works were "both critically acclaimed and a source of public controversy." Beard's works pointed out flaws in human behavior in the guise of animals. Bears, squirrels, rabbits, cats, and monkeys were his best known subjects. He painted and exhibited in Ohio; Buffalo, NY; Europe and New York City over the course of his career. Beard was instrumental in helping to develop an artistic community in Buffalo, New York. These efforts culminated in the establishment of the Buffalo Fine Arts Academy in 1862. Beard moved to New York City in 1860 and rented a studio in the renowned Tenth Street Studio Building, where he came into contact with other artists, including Albert Bierstadt (a lifelong friend he had met in Europe), Frederic Edwin Church, William Merritt Chase, and Winslow Homer, all of whom are represented in the IMA collection. During his years in New York City, Beard was involved in plans for a museum to be built on Manhattan Square, land owned by Central Park. The museum was intended by Beard's patron, Henry Keep, to be a "vehicle for social improvement, free and open to all." Beard designed the museum to portray "the gradual progress of the world from barbarism to civilization." The plan was ultimately abandoned because of Keep's death. Some of Beard's most famous works included those that poked fun at the ruthlessness of Wall Street and Darwin's theory of evolution.
Tour Guidance: VTS for any age group. Children's tour of animal images. Tour of paintings for any age that suggest strong narratives. Part of a tour for secondary or college students studying satire. Part of a tour for secondary or college students studying the Civil War and post-Civil War era. Part of a tour focusing on American landscape paintings.
Connections: Aesop's Fables or other stories in which animals portray humans and teach a lesson. See references for one possible story to use. Various paintings in which animals are portrayed. Search "animals" on IMA site. One example might be Landscape with Animals by Roelandt Savery in the Early European Gallery. American Civil War images such as The Consecration, 1861 by George Lambdin and Our Flag by Frederic Church to extend discussion of the Civil War America. Paintings by Beard's contemporaries at the Tenth Street Studio Building in NYC. See the list in the biography above. Ecce Homo by Hieronymous Bosch and other paintings by his followers to compare narratives and the sinister tones of these works. Note, too, similar color palettes. Find these in the Early European Gallery.
Sources/Bibliography: Burns, Sarah, "Party Animals: Thomas Nast, William Holbrook Beard, and the Bears of Wall Street," The American Art Journal/ Volume XXX, Numbers 1 and 2 (no other publishing information). Fort, Ilene Susan, preview of an exhibit of Beard's work at the Alexander Gallery, p.p. 8-35, (no other publishing information). "The Fox's Views" from Humor in Animals, (no author or publishing information). Peck, R.M, "William Holbrook Beard [and his plans for a museum of art]." The Magazine of Antiques (1971) v. 146 (November 1994) p.p. 692-701.
Micro Summary: William Holbrook Beard's "His Majesty Receives" is a satirical 19th-century American painting that uses anthropomorphized animals to critique post-Civil War American society. The work depicts a fox dressed in royal attire receiving humble rabbits and other forest creatures, with the fox representing the newly prosperous American who has abandoned rustic simplicity for cultural superiority. Beard employs narrative elements like the animals' natural predator-prey relationships, human postures and clothing, and a dramatic black drape to create layers of meaning beyond a simple forest scene. The painting's composition uses touches of red against drab browns and grays to emphasize the dramatic tension and social commentary. This reflects Beard's response to America's loss of innocence following the Civil War and accompanying social upheaval.

Title: Harmony in Pink and Gray: Lady Meux
Artwork Description: This is a composition of color harmonies, rather than an accurate likeness. Therefore, the work fits into the Tonalism area of the American gallery. Lord Meux commissioned Whistler to paint three full-length portraits of his wife. The three portraits were commissioned by Lord Meux for 1500 guineas, although Whistler later agreed to accept 1200 guineas for the three portraits. Whistler painted two nearly identical versions of this portrait; the second is at the Frick Collection in New York. Lady Meux was a colorful, attractive figure who reputedly rode an elephant to an English hunt. The fact that she was a supremely fashionable lady undoubtedly appealed to Whistler. Even though the modern subject and modern techniques were used, a critic thought Whistler painted in the tradition of the old masters. This work is painted on very coarse canvas. Her face is painted quite thickly, but so thoroughly worked that it has a fine matte surface. It has a sultry glow which is set off by the thinner paint of her glossy bodice. Whistler painted with "bold, broad crisscross strokes on the ruffles, and short, racy touches on her hat." The hat originally extended further right. The floor beneath Lady Meux is indefinite; a horizontal line of paint seems to cross under the foot of her train, as if a carpet or stairs were originally drawn there. Whistler eliminated his original floor line or step that he had painted beneath her feet. When Lady Meux sent her maid as a substitute sitter while she went to Egypt on vacation, Whistler positioned the hat further forward than it is in the finished work. His butterfly signature was originally much lower than it appears on the finished picture; the original location of the butterfly can be seen clearly in an early photograph.
Artist Biography: American painter, printmaker, designer and collector, active in England and France. He developed from the Realism of Courbet and Manet to become, in the 1860s, one of the leading members of the Aesthetic Movement, and an important exponent of Japonisme. From the 1860s he increasingly adopted non-specific and often musical titles for his work, which emphasized his interest in the manipulation of color and mood for their own sake rather than for the convention depiction of subjects. He acted as an important link between the avent-garde artistic worlds of Europe, Britain and the U.S. and has always been acknowledged as one of the masters of etching. From his monogram "JW", Whistler evolved a butterfly signature, which he used after 1869.
Tour Guidance: All ages of visitors find the beautiful, very sensuous, young woman attractive. Since the canvas Whistler used was very rough, he worked on the face of Lady Meux at great length. His results were outstanding. He was recognized as an outstanding artist including as an expert in engraving. Very young visitors, for example, are attracted to the pastel colors, i.e., pink shades. Some young visitors might think how they would like to dress for a high school picture, say for a high school prom, as they view her full-length portrait. Adult visitors tend to want to see any works of the renown Whistler, whose portrait of his mother (Whistler: Arrangement in Gray and Black No. 1) is well known. The docent might wish to compare Lady Meux's portrait by Whistler to Dorothy's portrait by her father, William Merritt Chase. Both are full length where pastel colors prevail. Dorothy Chase is portrayed in her youth; that compares well with many of our visitors.
Connections: The atmospheric art of that side of the room – Tonalism – plus the work, Rainy Night Etaples, on the other side of the room. A large full-length figure in subdued colors on the other side of the walkway from about the same time, i.e., Beckwith's William Merritt Chase (detached from the ship floor, dandy clothing, well-known Indiana-born artist). Gruelle's Canal Morning Effect could relate due to atmosphere and the unrealistic portrayal.
Sources/Bibliography: Not provided in docent materials.
Micro Summary: Harmony in Pink and Gray: Lady Meux is a Tonalist composition prioritizing color harmonies over accurate likeness, one of three commissioned portraits of the fashionable and colorful Lady Meux. Whistler worked extensively on her face creating a sultry matte surface contrasting with her glossy bodice, using bold crisscross strokes and his signature butterfly mark. The painting exemplifies Whistler's role as a key link between European and American avant-garde art movements and his mastery of the Aesthetic Movement.

Title: Hurricane
Artwork Description: Marin discovered Maine in 1914 and made annual visits there in the summer. For Marin, art had to be connected to the outside world, and not merely in the mind. Marin's work focused on three major themes: the city (New York), the sea (Maine), and the southwest (Taos). Alfred Stieglitz exhibited and sold his work and introduced him to O'Keeffe, Hartley, and Dove among others. Marin's work was exhibited in the Armory Show of 1913. Marin was an American artist, exploring American themes and working to establish a uniquely American style of painting.
Artist Biography: American painter and printmaker, born 1870 Rutherford, NJ, died 1953 Cape Split, ME. Marin attended Stevens Institute in Hoboken NJ, working briefly as an architect before studying at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts from 1899 to 1901. Marin traveled for five years in Europe, where he learned first hand about avant-garde trends. After returning permanently to the US in 1911, Marin settled in New York where he began his long career of depicting the city and the country. His initial works showed the influence of Impressionism and PostImpressionism. During the next decade, his art moved toward a more modernist style, with Fauvist handling and color and an abstract sense of design. In the 1920's, Marin's style became more expressive and abbreviated with objects ever-more simplified. His city images underwent a major transformation in the 1930s as the figures increased in scale and became more important elements in the scenes.... The natural landscape was also important to Marin, who had a very real love of nature. He traveled often to Hew Jersey, upstate New York, New England, New Mexico, and Canada. Probably his best-known images are those of the sea along the coast of Maine which he created in the 1930's. Marin worked extensively in watercolor, only beginning to devote more of his attention to oils in the 1930s. Marin received critical praise during his lifetime, which was unusual for the early American modernists. He became a member of the artistic circle centered around Alfred Steiglitz who exhibited his works at his galleries beginning in 1909.
Tour Guidance: Discuss why artists like to portray Nature and its forces. Discuss the artist's use of color in this piece: how does he use red? white? Discuss the mood created by Marin in this work. Discuss the use of abstraction in this work.
Connections: Connect with other works which portray the coast of Maine: Morning at Grand Manan by Bricher, Cliff Rock-Appledore by Childe Hassam. Compare with Landscape at San Remy by Van Gogh for impasto and brush strokes. Connect with The Rainbow by George Inness. Connect with East Cowes Castle, the Seat of J. Nash, Esq., the Regatta Beating to Windward by J. M. W. Turner in European galleries. Compare with Turner's The Fifth Plague of Egypt
Micro Summary: John Marin's "Hurricane" reflects the artist's deep connection to Maine, which he discovered in 1914 and visited annually each summer. The work exemplifies Marin's belief that art must be connected to the outside world rather than existing solely in the mind. As part of his focus on three major themes—the city, the sea, and the southwest—this piece captures the raw power of Maine's coastal environment. Marin was dedicated to exploring distinctly American subjects and developing a uniquely American style of painting.

Title: The Pioneers
Artwork Description: The Pioneers resemble a style of British landscape painting known as "picturesque," which features images such as the shadowy valley, rugged woodcutters, twisted trees and romantic stone ruins. English-born Shaw painted the branches and leaves with a delicate touch. The Pioneers exemplifies the picturesque aesthetic popular among English artists during the late eighteenth and early nineteenth-centuries. The shadowy valley, rugged woodcutters, and twisted trees exhibit striking contrasts of light and dark, rough textures, and intricate forms. Shaw's scene may be based on the topography of Pennsylvania's Delaware Water Gap. In another allusion to the picturesque, Shaw fashioned two of the rocky features in the distant valley to resemble the ruins of European castles.
Artist Biography: Joshua Shaw was born in Bellingborough, Lincolnshire, England, where he apprenticed under a sign painter, simultaneously earning a living and studying art. He worked as a landscape painter in Bath, exhibiting occasionally at the Royal Academy and the British Institution in London. In London, he became acquainted with American expatriate artist Benjamin West. Shaw immigrated to Philadelphia in 1817 to oversee the installation of Benjamin West's painting Christ Healing the Sick at the Pennsylvania Hospital. In 1819, he traveled with his teenage son to the South to create watercolor scenes of the area that were engraved in acquaint and published as a book, Picturesque Views of American Scenery (1820-1821). After returning to Philadelphia, Shaw created over two hundred oil paintings.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Naeve, John C. et al. 150 Years of Philadelphia Painters and Paintings. Philadelphia: The Library Company of Philadelphia, 1999.
Micro Summary: "The Pioneers" by Joshua Shaw exemplifies the British "picturesque" landscape painting style popular in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. The work features characteristic elements including a shadowy valley, rugged woodcutters, twisted trees, and rocky formations that resemble European castle ruins. Shaw employed striking contrasts of light and dark with rough textures and intricate forms, painting the foliage with delicate precision. The scene appears to be based on Pennsylvania's Delaware Water Gap, demonstrating how English-born Shaw adapted the picturesque aesthetic to American landscapes.

Title: Morning at Grand Manan
Artwork Description: Example of Luminism. Luminism was a uniquely American style of painting that abandoned the romantic conventions that dominated landscape painting. Luminists were interested in rendering the light that illuminated the landscapes more so than the landscape itself. Typical luminist principles include a low horizon that dominates the painting; water as a main pictorial element; sharp, bright light that creates a hard edge; invisible brush strokes; and a panoramic view. Painted in a studio from outdoor sketches. Grand Manan, New Brunswick, Canada is a real place, but this is not a real scene. Pantheism – seeing God in nature. Optical illusion – when you travel from one side of the painting to the other, the ray of light coming from the sun travels with you.
Artist Biography: American Landscape Painter, Born 1837, Died 1908. Bricher was largely self-taught, and as an artist was known in his lifetime as a successful landscape painter in the style of the Hudson River School. Bricher was from Portsmouth, N.H. and began painting in Boston around 1851. He moved to New York City in 1870, and even though most of his time was spent there, most of all Bricher's subject matter was drawn from summer sketching trips to Massachusetts and Maine coasts, and Rhode Island. Bricher's maritime scenes are all coastal scenes, usually panoramic with a broad horizon line. With an emphasis on bright, sharp light, they carry the viewer out to a clear, crisp horizon. While boats are often in his pictures, figures are rare. Luminist principles are evident in Bricher's works and he is considered one of the last of the Luminist artists. As such, he was predominately interested in the pictorial effects of light and translucency. It is always possible to ascertain the time of day, weather conditions and geography in his work. Bricher and his comtemporaries, Fredrick Kensett, Fitz Hugh Lane, Martin Johnson Heade, Fredrick Church, and Sanford Robinson Gifford, formed this group of artists that were painting in this uniquely American style. Bricher's painting career lasted for more than 50 years.
Tour Guidance: Compare/Contrast with Impressionist: Compare light as subject, Contrast brushstrokes. History Tour: This was the second 'school' of art that was uniquely American (first was Hudson River School), Painted during the time of the Civil War. Math and Art: Creating perspective through mathematical relationships of boats, Geometrical shapes.
Connections: Compare and contrast use of light in luminism with Impressionists in the European galleries and the Turrell in the Contemporary galleries. Compare and contrast with Turner's seascapes. Richard Gruelle, Canal at Morning. Winslow Homer, The Boat Builders. George Inness, The Rainbow.
Micro Summary: Alfred Thompson Bricher's "Morning at Grand Manan" exemplifies American Luminism, a style that prioritized capturing light over landscape details. The painting features typical Luminist elements including a low horizon, water as the central focus, sharp bright light with hard edges, and invisible brushstrokes creating a panoramic view. Though depicting the real location of Grand Manan, New Brunswick, Bricher composed this idealized scene in his studio from outdoor sketches. The work embodies pantheistic beliefs by presenting God through nature, and includes an optical illusion where the sun's ray appears to follow the viewer across the composition.

Title: Untitled (The Birth)
Artwork Description: The 1938 painting is tempera on paper. The artist managed to render rich and brilliant color from the limited medium of flat tempera. Jacob Lawrence, was trained in New York City at the height of the Harlem Renaissance, and taught primarily by black artists. Lawrence was a storyteller and captured the social changes of the great migration as African-Americans moved to industrialized urban centers in the North. Many of his paintings were done as a series - ex. Great Migration Series, Harlem Series, John Brown Series, Frederick Douglas Series, and Harriet Tubman Series, which required a great deal of historical research. He used flat, geometric shapes in silhouette form, abstract, not posed, like a snapshot. The picture shows the crowded tenement housing which was part of his life. The pink drape is underneath the woman giving birth. On the right you have a lady leaving her apartment, with lipstick in hand. In the upper left-hand corner you have the palms saved from the previous Palm Sunday. The clock gives you the feeling of time passing. First African-American artist represented in a white gallery.
Artist Biography: Born 1917 in Atlantic City, New Jersey - Died 2000 in Seattle, Washington. His mother was from Virginia and his father was from South Carolina before they migrated north in search of what they thought was "The Promised Land". They found this was not the case as jobs were going to white employees. They had three children of which Jacob was the oldest. Later they moved to Philadelphia, again in search of work. After Jacob's father left, his mother moved to Harlem looking for employment. She left her children in Philadelphia for three years until she was financially able to bring them to Harlem. In Harlem his favorite pastime was exploring the bustling city streets, each window or doorway he passed told a different story - men hunched over pool tables, mothers preparing dinners, or mourners gathered in a funeral parlor. Jacob was also exposed to a number of famous musicians like Duke Ellington, Cab Calloway, and "Bojangles" Robinson. All this was a rich background for his later work. He was trained in New York at the height of the Harlem Renaissance. Mrs. Lawrence, a hardworking single mother, enrolled Jacob in WPA-sponsored, after-school art classes at Utopia House, where the painter Charles Alston was teaching. By 1935, the nineteen-year-old Lawrence began to study at Alston's Harlem Workshop and the American Artists School. There he studied with Anton Refregier, Sol Wilson, Philip Reisman, and Eugene Morely. Sculptor Augusta Savage, who had just returned from Paris, took an interest in Lawrence's work and arranged for his employment at the Federal Arts Project. For the first time, the government actively supported the arts through President Franklin Roosevelt's Federal Arts Project (FAP), part of the Works Progress Administration (WPA). Black artists were given the opportunity to practice their art full-time. Jacob Lawrence brought the history of black life to the canvas. He managed to render rich and brilliant color from the limited medium of flat tempera, and to transform formless designs into living, moving shapes. Often accompanied by text, his paintings are epic, sweeping narratives of the everyday experiences of forgotten and ordinary life. His paintings memorialize the tragedy, the aspirations, the perseverance, and the joy of everyday African Americans. The paintings of Jacob Lawrence tell stories. Stories of enslavement and freedom, of human migration and renaissance and of struggle and triumph. No artist before Jacob had developed themes from African-American history. He used historical themes from the Civil War period to the Civil Rights movement of the 1960's. In 1990 he received the National Medal of Arts Award. In 1994, he was inducted into the American Academy of Arts and Letters. He is admired for being the first black visual artist to make African-American historical traditions the subject matter of his art.
