Tour Guidance: Theme tour of African-American artists. Learning to look: shapes, lines, color. VTS
Connections: William A Johnson, Preparing for War. This is part of a series as is Lawrence's work. Both are flat with silhouettes. Both purchased by National Coalition of 100 African-American Indianapolis women. Both show realistic scenes for African-Americans during this time period. Paul Gauguin, The Flageolet Player on the Cliff. Compare with the flat colors of the Pont Aven works. Compare with other interiors in European.
Sources/Bibliography: Falk, Peter, Who Was Who In American Art. Gates, Jr., Henry Louis and Cornel West, The African-American Century, 2000. Duggleby, John, Story Painter, The Life of Jacob Lawrence, 1998. Leach, Deba Foxley, I See You I See Myself, 2001
Micro Summary: Jacob Lawrence's 1938 tempera painting "Untitled (The Birth)" depicts a crowded tenement scene using his characteristic flat, geometric shapes and brilliant colors. The work shows a woman giving birth on a pink drape while daily life continues around her, including a neighbor leaving her apartment with lipstick in hand. Lawrence, trained during the Harlem Renaissance, was known as a storyteller who documented African-American experiences, particularly the Great Migration to Northern urban centers. Details like Palm Sunday palms and a clock emphasize the passage of time and the intersection of sacred and mundane moments in urban Black life.

Title: Henry Look Unhitching
Artwork Description: Typical Benton scene of rural America depicting an ordinary person doing a simple daily task. The flat, rather simplified style of the horse and the man in the painting are typical of Benton's style. There are several common objects in the foreground that exemplify the workaday world of rural life. The undulating shapes of the ground and sky are characteristic of Benton's works and suggest the vitality of nature with relentless, energetic rhythms. The colors are very muted and seem to be typical of colors in nature on an overcast day. This painting actually depicts a farm on Martha's Vineyard, not Missouri as originally thought. Benton and his wife Rita spent 50 summers on Martha's Vineyard between 1920 and 1975, and it was there that Benton developed his Regionalist style. The subject, Henry Look, was an acquaintance of Benton's who posed for him a number of times. According to the 1940 Census, Look was a 64-year-old white male farmer with an 8th grade education who owned his home in Chilmark, MA on Martha's Vineyard. Look delivered milk to Benton until Benton saw the man straining milk through a used handkerchief. The hilly terrain depicted is characteristic of Martha's Vineyard's glacial landscape, with Chilmark having dramatic bumps with boulders. Look's wife, Eva, was part of a large deaf community on Martha's Vineyard.
Artist Biography: American painter, illustrator, lithographer. Born April 15, 1889, Neosho, Missouri. Died January 19, 1975, Kansas City, Missouri. Studied art in Washington DC (as the son of a congressman), the Art Institute of Chicago, and the Académie Julian in Paris (until 1909). Thereafter, he studied independently. In Paris he was exposed to modernist styles; focused on Impressionism and Pointillism; was influenced by Diego Rivera and a number of American artists such as John Marin and Stanton Macdonald-Wright. Returned to the US in 1912, first to Missouri and then to New York where he remained until 1935. During his early years in NYC, he painted pure abstract works. Became interested in Marxism. Joined the Navy in 1918. Became interested in drawing ordinary people and rejected modernist abstract styles. Produced his first major paintings in the 1920s, including his first large historical works such as American Historical Epic (Kansas City, MO, Nelson-Atkins Museum). He married and had two children during this time. Began teaching at the Art Students League (NYC) by 1926 and became aware of socially concerned Mexican muralists such as Diego Rivera. By 1930, he won mural commissions, including the Arts of Life in America at the Whitney Museum of American Art (1932). Was the teacher of artist Jackson Pollock between 1931 and 1935 at the Art Students League. In 1933 painted the Social History of the State of Indiana for Indiana's pavilion at the Chicago World's Fair (now in Bloomington, Indiana; Indiana University Auditorium). Painted in the realistic Regionalism style of art, along with Grant Wood and John Steuart Curry. Left NYC in 1935 to paint the anti-capitalist mural on the Social History of the State of Missouri in the State Capital at Jefferson City (completed in 1936). Late 1930s, taught at the Kansas City Art Institute; also created numerous lithographs and book illustrations, including those for John Steinbeck's The Grapes of Wrath. Continued to paint after WWII and was widely exhibited and collected in the heartland of America but was disdained by the New York art world.
Tour Guidance: Use in Animals in Art theme tour. Could use as a part of the Creative Hoosiers theme tour - although Benton was not a Hoosier, a docent could bring along pictures of the Indiana University murals and talk about the controversies relating to the murals (spurring controversy over style and politics in the '30s at the time of their painting, and causing controversy periodically over the years since they have been on display at IU). Use as part of theme tour Weather. Note that the muted colors are typical of how nature looks on overcast days. Could discuss the significance of natural light in art. Use in theme tour American Art Spotlight.
Connections: Compare Henry Look Unhitching with other IMA artworks of the same time period: Edward Hopper's Hotel Lobby (1943); Reginald Marsh's Hauptmann Must Die (1941); Isabel Bishop's Tidying Up (1941); Joseph Delaney's The Artist's Party (1941-1943). Discuss the different subjects of these other realists vs. Benton's subjects. Compare his work with the Norman Rockwell's The Love Song.
Sources/Bibliography:
Grove Art Online (article url: http://www.oxfordartonline.com:80/subscriber/article/grove/art/T007989)
Modern Painters Magazine, Spring 1992; "Like Father, Like Son" (Duncan Twedale, reviewer of Benton, Pollock and the Politics of Modernism, Erika Doss, University of Chicago Press, 1991).
Micro Summary: Thomas Hart Benton (1889-1975) was a leading American Regionalist painter who studied in Paris but rejected modernist abstraction to paint scenes of rural American life, becoming Jackson Pollock's teacher at the Art Students League and creating major murals including the controversial Social History of the State of Indiana. "Henry Look Unhitching" (1942) depicts not a Missouri farm as originally identified, but Martha's Vineyard where Benton spent 50 summers developing his signature style of undulating landscapes with muted colors and simplified forms. The painting shows 64-year-old farmer Henry Look, a Martha's Vineyard resident whose wife was part of the island's historic deaf community, captured in a typical Benton scene of everyday rural labor with characteristic energetic rhythms in the rolling glacial landscape.

Title: Angel of the Resurrection
Artwork Description: Upon the death of her husband in 1901, Mrs. Benjamin Harrison commissioned Tiffany to create a window in his memory. The window, the lower half of which appears here, was installed in 1905 at the First Presbyterian Church, 16th and Delaware Streets, Indianapolis, where the president had served as an elder for more than 40 years. Absorbed in scores of projects, Tiffany probably left the window's conception to his team of talented designers, contributing his own thought before giving final approval. The design shows Michael, the Angel of the Resurrection, signaling the dead to rise at Christ's second coming. In keeping with the romanticism of the time, Tiffany's heroic angel is dressed in the chain mail suit of a crusading knight and seems like a figure from Sir Walter Scott's novels. The deep blue inner ring behind the angel has five separate layers, creating a dark background that increases the window's drama. Angel of the Resurrection, the lower half of which appears here, was commissioned by Mary Lord Harrison, second wife and widow of President Benjamin Harrison, upon her husband's death in 1901. It was installed at the First Presbyterian Church in Indianapolis, where the president had served as an elder for more than forty years. Perhaps because he carries a trumpet, the figure is often mistaken for Gabriel, Angel of the Annunciation, but it is actually Michael, Angel of the Resurrection, who signals the dead to rise. Tiffany, who was absorbed in scores of projects, likely left the window's conception to his team of designers, contributing ideas before giving final approval. His assembly of windows was innovative-the lead does not just hold the glass, it defines the contours of the images and creates decorative patterns. Tiffany also perfected the plating technique, in which glass sheets are sandwiched on top of each other, producing mesmerizing effects of color and depth. The blue ring behind the angel, for example, consists of five layers, creating a dark background that increases the drama of the image. Window inscription: Awake thou that sleepest. Arise from the dead and Christ shall give thee light. -From Ephesians 5:14
Artist Biography: The dominant figure in American decorative arts for more than half a century, Louis Comfort Tiffany founded several firms to satisfy the strong demand for his art glass, metalwork, pottery and furniture. Tiffany's enthusiasm for sensuous materials and striking colors found full expression in his stained-glass windows. From 1877 through the 1920s, he and his craftsmen produced thousands of windows for churches, institutions and homes across the United States. Tiffany manufactured all the glass for his windows, and the Tiffany Furnaces at one time had over 5,000 different colors and varieties in stock. Mottled glass, a hallmark of Tiffany's creations, appears throughout the Harrison window. Its swirling opalescent and iridescent finishes are the result of adding chemicals to the cooling molten glass. Drapery glass, used to superb effect in Michael's robes, was a Tiffany invention achieved by manipulating hot, viscous sheets of glass until the desired cloth-like folds appeared. Another textural variation occurs in the angel's wings, where the Tiffany craftsmen ruffled the glass surface in imitation of feathers. Also innovative was Tiffany's assembly of the windows. The leading does not just hold the glass in place; it defines the contours of the windows' images and creates decorative linear patterns. Tiffany also perfected the plating technique, in which glass sheets are sandwiched on top of each other, producing extraordinary effects of color and depth. Typical of Tiffany's efficiency, he used the enormous amount of scrap glass from his window production to make the vibrantly colored lampshades for which he may be best known.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Indianapolis Museum of Art: Highlights of the Collection (2005)
Micro Summary: Mrs. Benjamin Harrison commissioned Tiffany Studios to create this memorial window for her husband President Benjamin Harrison after his death in 1901, installing it in 1905 at Indianapolis's First Presbyterian Church where he had served as an elder for over forty years. The window depicts Michael, the Angel of the Resurrection, dressed as a crusading knight and signaling the dead to rise at Christ's second coming. Tiffany employed innovative techniques including a five-layer deep blue background that creates dramatic depth and contrast behind the heroic angel figure. The window bears the inscription from Ephesians 5:14: "Awake thou that sleepest. Arise from the dead and Christ shall give thee light."

Title: Landscape
Artwork Description: The IMA owns two other landscapes by Whittredge, Summer Pastorale, produced in Germany and Lake Shawangunk, painted along the Hudson River. This third landscape was created late in Whittredge's career and maintains the theme of small figures within a larger landscape begun in Whittredge's German paintings and continued in his Hudson River scenes. Here, instead of figures crossing a body of water on foot or boat, they travel down a path surrounded by large trees and a cloud-filled blue sky in a style. The scene reflects the artist's ongoing engagement with one of the more idealistic missions of the Hudson River School--an attempt to understand humandkind's place within the vast landscape designed by their creator.
Artist Biography: Worthington Whittredge, as he called himself after 1855, was born on a farm in Springfield, Ohio. He moved to Cincinnati in 1837, worked with his brother-in-law as a house painter, and taught himself to paint portraits and landscapes. He experimented with daguerreotypes in Indianapolis, opened a portrait studio in Charlestown, West Virginia, and then returned to Cincinnati. From 1843 on, he devoted himself to landscapes. Through the efforts of wealthy Cincinnati art patron Nicholas Longworth, Whittredge was able to study for five years in Düsseldorf, Germany. He also spent five years in Rome before returning to the United States in 1859. Whittredge settled in New York City, where he opened a studio. He experienced some difficulty adapting his European skills to the American scene. The quality of light seemed different to Whittredge, who was accustomed to the frequently overcast skies of central Germany. His search for an American style was aided by the example of Sanford Gifford, whom he had known in Düsseldorf and Rome.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Cheryl A. Cibulka. Quiet Places: The American Landscapes of Worthington Whittredge, Washington, D. C.: Adams Davidson Galleries, Inc., 1982. ASIN: B000KBJREO
Micro Summary: This landscape painting by Worthington Whittredge was created late in his career and features small human figures traveling down a tree-lined path beneath a dramatic, cloud-filled sky. The work continues Whittredge's characteristic theme of depicting tiny figures within expansive natural settings, a motif he developed during his time in Germany and refined in his Hudson River paintings. The composition reflects the Hudson River School's idealistic mission to explore humanity's relationship with the divine through nature's grandeur.

Title: A Summer Day
Artwork Description: The painting's complex color harmonies and crusty interwoven strokes infused with soft light exhibit the elements that make Twachtman a key American Impressionist. This peaceful scene was painted on the artist's farm in Connecticut. The complex color harmonies and thick, interwoven strokes of pigment in A Summer Day recall the French painter Claude Monet's canvases. Twachtman was inspired by the chromatic experiments of the Impressionists. Rhythmic lines in the contour of hill and rock, the bent figure in the boat, and the curve of the water's edge form a decorative pattern, which is repetitive, yet varied. This peaceful scene of a figure on a small lake was painted on the artist's farm in Connecticut.
Artist Biography: John Twachtman was born in Cincinnati, Ohio, in 1853. His career began at age fourteen, when he helped his father decorate window shades. He studied in Munich with William Merritt Chase and Frank Duveneck. Twachtman's early paintings were in the Munich manner. In 1883, he attended the Académie Julian in Paris, where he came under the influence of French Impressionism. His paintings shifted from the dark, shadowy Munich palette to soft gray and green tones. He became one of the founding members of The Ten, a group that included America's most important Impressionist painters. Twachtman lightened his palette to the point where white dominated his canvases. He favored pure landscape, often excluding figures and buildings. When they did appear in his scenes, they were obscured by the hazy atmosphere. Twachtman's landscapes took on an abstract quality that anticipated the modernist style.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Peters, Lisa N. John Henry Twachtman: An American Impressionist. Manchester, Vermont: Hudson Hills Press, 1999.
Micro Summary: "A Summer Day" by John Henry Twachtman showcases the artist's mastery as a key American Impressionist through complex color harmonies and thick, interwoven brushstrokes infused with soft light. Painted on Twachtman's Connecticut farm, the work depicts a peaceful scene of a figure in a boat on a small lake. The painting demonstrates the influence of French Impressionist Claude Monet and reflects Twachtman's inspiration from chromatic experiments of the movement. Rhythmic lines in the landscape elements create a decorative pattern that is both repetitive and varied, contributing to the work's serene composition.

Title: The Statuette
Artwork Description: This painting is an example of Bell's soft, languid portraits of idealized upper-class women in intimate interiors. The dark background of this piece reflects Bell's training at the Royal Academy in Munich and the emphasis placed on the Dutch and Spanish masters. Although this is a full-length portrait, the sitter is placed with her back turned to the viewer.
Artist Biography: American painter of portraits, interiors, dancers, musicians, still lifes, and flowers. Born 18 December 1862, New York, New York; died 1953, Long Island, New York. Bell first studied art with his father, Edward A. Bell, later taking classes under William Merritt Chase at the Art Students League in the 1880's. Bell also attended the National Academy of Design. In 1883, Bell enrolled in the Royal Academy in Munich as a student of Ludwig von Loefftz a realist painter who stressed the Dutch and Spanish masters. Bell exhibited in many important exhibitions while in Munich, but he earned international attention with a piece shown at the Paris Exposition of 1889. "The Lady in Gray" was a very non-traditional work which incorporated a softly-patterned scrim as a background. Returning to the US in the 1889, Bell continued to achieve recognition with his delicately hued paintings of women in intimate interiors. Bell often used Japanese decorative objects in his small portraits as did both Whistler and Chase. During his lifetime, Bell exhibited and won prizes at the Royal Academy. He also exhibited at the National Academy of Design in New York, the 1893 World's Colombian Exposition and the Pan-American Exposition in 1901. He was a member of the Art Student's League and an Associate Member of the National Academy of Design.
Tour Guidance: Use as part of a tour based on portraiture. Compare and contrast subject, props and seating/position of subject. Compare and contrast works by Royal Academy (Munich) trained artists. Where does the name for this piece come from? Does it have more than one meaning?
Connections: Compare and contrast with Tarbell, Paxton, Chase and other works with female subjects. Compare and contrast with Isabel Bishop and John Sloan. How are these women different? Compare and contrast with works in the European galleries (Dutch and Spanish).
Sources/Bibliography: IMA collection information.
Micro Summary: The Statuette showcases Bell's signature style of soft, languid portraits featuring idealized upper-class women in intimate interiors, with the unusual compositional choice of placing the subject with her back to the viewer. Trained at Munich's Royal Academy under Ludwig von Loefftz, Bell's dark background reflects his emphasis on Dutch and Spanish masters. Like Whistler and Chase, Bell incorporated Japanese decorative objects in his delicately hued portraits, earning recognition at major exhibitions including the Paris Exposition of 1889 and the World's Colombian Exposition.

Title: Preparing for the Matinee
Artwork Description: The loose energetic brushwork in the woman's blouse and hair are elements of the Impressionist style. Tarbell was a leading member of the Boston School of painters, known for their pictures of young women engaged in domestic activities. This lady, concentrating on adjusting her hat with a pearl-tipped hatpin, is typical of Edmund Tarbell's refined, everyday subjects. The passages of loose, energetic brushwork in her blouse and hair display the spontaneity that Tarbell brought to his outdoor Impressionist paintings. Artists of the Boston School explored aspects of texture, which can be seen in the handling of the creases in the woman's blouse and the feathers on her hat. Tarbell's expert drawing technique is evident in the rendering of the sitter's arm and the handling of her facial features. In fact, a corner of one of Vermeer's paintings appears at the upper right of Tarbell's elegant interior as a tribute to this Dutch master.
Artist Biography: Edmund Tarbell and the Boston School - Like Frank Benson, Tarbell belonged to the Boston School, which flourished during the early decades of the 20th century. These painters were renowned for their pictures of young women engaged in sedentary and often solitary domestic activities, or posed in sunlit outdoor settings. In his interior compositions, Tarbell concentrated upon the insular world of upper-class women, depicting them in an austere but elegant manner, attired in the latest fashions. Like many painters of the Boston School, Tarbell was influenced by the paintings of the 17th-century Dutch artist Jan Vermeer, whose works were rediscovered in the mid-19th century.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Lee, Ellen Wardwell, Anne Robinson, and Alexandra Bonfante-Warren. Indianapolis Museum of Art: Highlights of the Collection. Indianapolis: Indianapolis Museum of Art, 2005, p. 143. Edmund Tarbell and the Influence of Vermeer Indianapolis Museum of Art: Highlights of the Collection (2005)
Micro Summary: "Preparing for the Matinee" by Edmund Charles Tarbell depicts a refined woman adjusting her hat with a pearl-tipped hatpin, exemplifying the Boston School's focus on elegant domestic scenes. The painting showcases Impressionist influences through loose, energetic brushwork in the woman's blouse and hair, while demonstrating Tarbell's expert drawing technique in the rendering of facial features and arms. The artist's attention to texture is evident in the detailed handling of fabric creases and hat feathers. A corner of a Vermeer painting visible in the upper right serves as a tribute to the Dutch master, emphasizing Tarbell's appreciation for classical artistic traditions.

Title: Marie Jane Andrew
Medium: oil on canvas mounted on masonite
Artwork Description: The portrait of Marie Jane Andrew, age, 7, was commissioned in memory of the girl soon after she died. She is dressed in an elaborate early Victorian costume and seated among the objects of her childhood; a sewing box, school books, treasured sea shells, and a Staffordshire pottery figure of a dog. In addition to offering a wealth of information about the decorative arts of the period, this portrait is an excellent example of a self-trained professional portrait artist working in the nineteenth century. Mason had difficulty rendering such simple objects as a book, a table top, and a chair in proper perspective. The little girl's extremities, too, are less than convincing. The artist's sense of composition and design makes up for any shortcomings in technique. The piping on the child's dress creates an interesting play of lines with the gold chain about her neck; the window encasements direct the viewer's eye to her head, the focal point of the picture. The portrait is an interesting example of a picture within a picture. The painting of a boy in the upper left is believed to be the girl's brother, James, who had also died very young. The distant landscape, seen from the window, is probably their familyl home.
Artist Biography: Joseph Mason was born in Cincinnati, Ohio and attended John James Audubon's classes in drawing in Cincinnati. He traveled with Audubon on a flatboat to New Orleans and drew at least fifty flowers for Audubon's bird paintings. Upon his return to Cincinnati and without further training, Mason became a portrait artist. In 1834, he left Cincinnati and painted portraits in Michigan and Indiana. He died of pneumonia at age thirty-four.
Sources/Bibliography: Irving T. Richards. "Audubon, Joseph R. Mason, and John Neal," American Literature, Vol.. 6, No. 2, May 1934, pp. 122-140.
Micro Summary: This memorial portrait of 7-year-old Marie Jane Andrew was commissioned after her death and shows her in elaborate Victorian dress surrounded by childhood objects including books, shells, and toys. Created by self-trained artist Joseph R. Mason, the painting demonstrates technical limitations in perspective and anatomy but compensates with strong compositional design. The portrait includes a "picture within a picture" - a painting of a boy in the upper left believed to be her deceased brother James. The work serves as both a family memorial and an excellent example of 19th-century American folk portraiture, offering valuable insights into period decorative arts and domestic life.

Title: Red Kimono on the Roof
Artwork Description: 1912, oil on canvas. Subject not wealthy woman but woman of working class doing own laundry. Red silk kimono may be one of few luxuries giving her look of style as she goes about mundane task. Represents Ashcan School – period of American art painted roughly 1908-1918 depicting gritty urban NYC street scenes of poor in everyday life. Never intended paintings to be social criticism. Simply painting slice of life, often painted from high studio window scenes he saw on rooftops below.
Artist Biography: John Sloan, American (1871-1951). Born lumber town Lock Haven, Pennsylvania. Taught himself to etch and sketch. Age 20 working as commercial illustrator, obtained job as staff artist Philadelphia Inquirer. Henri taught him at Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. Did not paint on scene; only in studio from memory. Although Socialist and ran for minor office, said did not paint subject matter to make political statement, only had natural interest in human beings. Active in organizing Society of Independent Artists. Popular teacher at Art Students League NYC. Died of cancer Hanover NH 1951.
Tour Guidance: Weather – sunny and windy with great shadows. Painting creates movement with strong verticals and diagonals crossing them. Tools – Clothespins, clotheslines, how was laundry washed.
Connections: Compare with Peasant With a Wheelbarrow by Jean Francois Millet, Tidying Up by Isabel Bishop. Compare and contrast with women portrayed in Pont Aven works for dress and chores.
Sources/Bibliography: Krause, Martin. The Passage Return of Indiana painters from Germany 1880-1905. Newton, Judith. The Hoosier Group.
Micro Summary: John Sloan (1871-1951), American artist born in Lock Haven, Pennsylvania, painted Red Kimono on the Roof in 1912 as an exemplary work of the Ashcan School movement that depicted gritty urban New York City street scenes between 1908 and 1918. Sloan, who worked as a staff artist at the Philadelphia Inquirer and studied under Robert Henri at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts where he earned Henri's gentle mockery for his slow, methodical painting style, created this oil on canvas from his high studio window overlooking city rooftops. The painting portrays a working-class woman doing laundry on a rooftop, her red silk kimono providing a touch of luxury and style to an otherwise mundane task, demonstrating Sloan's socialist sympathies while maintaining his assertion that he painted "slices of life" without intending social criticism, simply expressing his natural interest in portraying human beings with directness and capturing everyday moments of urban working-class existence with movement created through strong verticals and diagonals.

Title: The Consecration, 1861
Artwork Description: The oil painting depicts a poignant moment as a man and woman separate—the Union soldier to go to battle and the woman to stay home. The bond between them appears to be one of romantic love, reinforced by the statue of Venus de Milo painted in the background (Venus is the Roman goddess of love). Given the date in the title, 1861, the theme of separation makes sense. However, since the painting was actually completed in 1865, the final year of the Civil War, Lambdin could have been conveying a dual meaning: both the separation of a couple as a soldier goes to war and their reunion (and the re-Union of the North and South) when the soldier returns successfully. Further support for this interpretation can be found in the color of the woman's dress, gray, the uniform color of Confederate soldiers. The painting's title projects a powerful and solemn message. Consecration means the act of setting apart as holy, making or declaring something sacred for religious use. Numerous elements in the painting serve to reinforce this theme: the manner in which the light falls onto the woman and specifically illuminates her face as she kisses the sword; the darkness of the canvas except for the lighted portion where the woman's lips meet the sword; the angle and manner in which the heads of the man and woman are bowed in a reverent way. The sword is a stylized Union Army Model 1860 Staff and Field Officer Sword. Lambdin's paintings of the Civil War address human and psychological aspects of the war, rather than portray a specific military event. The Civil War officers painted by Lambdin resemble his younger brother, James Harrison (Harry) Lambdin, who was also an artist and served in the Civil War. Notice the vase of roses behind the officer and the rose the officer is holding up to his cheek. Lambdin frequently used flowers in the background of his early paintings before he turned in his later works to flowers as his central subjects.
Artist Biography: American painter, born January 6, 1830, Pittsburgh, PA; died January 28, 1896, Germantown PA. Lambdin began his art studies with his father, James Read Lambdin (1807-1889), a portrait and landscape painter who founded a museum in Pittsburgh in 1828 and directed the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia from 1845 to 1864. The younger Lambdin first exhibited at the Pennsylvania Academy in 1848 and at the National Academy of Design, NY, in 1856. In the mid-1850s he traveled in Europe; however, he spent most of his professional career in Philadelphia. He was elected an Academician by the Pennsylvania Academy in 1863 and by the National Academy of Design in 1868. During the late 1860s, Lambdin was at the Tenth Street Studio Building, NY, which was an important center of artistic activity. Lambdin's early works were primarily genre paintings, sentimental scenes of childhood, bereavement and Civil War subjects. The Consecration, 1861 was shown at the Exposition Universelle in Paris in 1867, together with The Last Sleep (also known as The Dead Wife) which received critical acclaim. In general, Lambdin's paintings were well-reviewed when exhibited and were collected at the time by leading patrons of the arts. After a short trip abroad in 1870, Lambdin returned to his home in Germantown, PA, and turned to painting primarily floral studies, especially roses from his own garden. His emphasis on floral still-life painting was practical as well, since there was a growing popular demand for such paintings. Many of Lambdin's flower paintings were reproduced as chromolithographs by Louis Prang & Co., of Boston, MA, and were widely distributed. Lambdin remained an active member in both artistic and horticultural circles until his death in 1896.
Tour Guidance: Discuss the use of light and dark areas in the painting for purposes of emphasis and mood. Use as part of an American Art Spotlight Tour. Use as part of tours on Patriotism in America (highlighting portrayals of historical events, leadership, independence and military engagement). Use for The American Experience (highlighting in broader terms some of the historical, cultural, geographical, religious and military influences and events in the development of the United States). Use for American History as Art Interprets It (highlighting the interpretation of history with the emphasis more on the art than on the historical events).
Connections: Our Flag, 1864, by Frederic Edwin Church; American Gallery. This is a painting of a 31-star flag on a rocky cliff, above the smoke of battle. This is also a Civil War-era piece, and the number of stars on the flag indicates the artist's optimism on behalf of the Union's eventual triumph. A Break: Playing Cards, 1881, by Julian Scott; American Gallery. Though painted after the Civil War ended, this portrays a scene from that era. Unlike Lambdin's painting that can be interpreted as emphasizing separation, Scott's scene shows its subjects coming together for a more light-hearted moment in the midst of war. The Boat Builders, 1873, by Winslow Homer; American Gallery. Homer and Lambdin were both in New York painting in the late 1860s, and it is believed that Homer may have had some influence on Lambdin's work.
Sources/Bibliography:
Battistini, Matilde. Symbols and Allegories in Art. Los Angeles: Getty Publications, 2005.
Blaugrand, Annette and Lee M. Edwards. "George Cochran Lambdin." Arts Magazine 61 (1986) 107.
Falk, Peter Hastings, ed. Who Was Who in American Art, 1564-1975. Madison, CT: Sound View Press, 1999.
Turner, Jane, ed. The Dictionary of Art. New York: Grove's Dictionaries, Inc., 1996.
Weidner, Ruth Irwin. "George Cochran Lambdin, 1830-1896." Exhibition essay prepared for Brandywine River Museum, Chadds Ford, PA, Sept. 6-Nov. 23, 1986.
Micro Summary: George Cochran Lambdin (1830-1896) was an American painter who trained under his father at the Pennsylvania Academy and worked at New York's prestigious Tenth Street Studio Building, initially creating sentimental genre scenes before turning to highly successful floral still-lifes that were widely reproduced as chromolithographs. "The Consecration, 1861" (1865) is a dramatically lit Civil War painting depicting a solemn moment as a woman in gray (possibly symbolizing the South) kisses a Union officer's sword while a statue of Venus suggests romantic love, with the work's dual date suggesting both wartime separation and the possibility of reunion as the war ended. Exhibited at the 1867 Paris Exposition Universelle, the painting exemplifies Lambdin's focus on the psychological and human aspects of the Civil War rather than specific military events, possibly featuring his own brother Harry who served as a Union soldier.

Title: Jimson Weed
Artwork Description: Cosmetics entrepreneur Elizabeth Arden commissioned Georgia O'Keeffe to paint Jimson Weed, originally titled Miracle Flower, to hang in the exercise room of the New York Gymnasium Moderne at Arden's Fifth Avenue Salon in New York City. During stretching exercises, clients of the salon "unfurled" like the flowers in O'Keeffe's painting on the wall behind them. Arden paid O'Keeffe $10,000, considered an astonishing amount at the time, for the largest floral composition the artist would ever create. The four blossoms are placed in an energetic design that repeats the tight rhythm of the jimson weed's pinwheel-shaped flower. About this plant, which grew near the artist's home in New Mexico, O'Keeffe said, "When I think of the delicate fragrance of the flowers, I almost feel the coolness and sweetness of the evening." She emphasized her subject's fresh beauty with a bright, simplified palette and rhythmic treatment of light and shadow. O'Keeffe, one of the first American modernists, was at the heart of the group of artists who gathered around Alfred Stieglitz, the photographer and art dealer who became her husband. The sheer size of her flowersan arresting manipulation of scale-represented a radical modernist innovation. I will make even busy New Yorkers take time to see what I see of flowers. –Georgia O'Keeffe, 1939. Commissioned by Elizabeth Arden Salon, New York, 1936. Flower enlarged to fill canvas. Bright simplified palette. Painted on linen. Four blossoms placed in energetic design, repeats this tight rhythm of pinwheel shaped flowers. Shows stages of development of flower. Close-up view of the beautiful plant (a new way to look at flowers). Draws viewers into swirling petals.
Artist Biography: Georgian O'Keeffe was born the second of seven children. She spent the first 14 years of her life on the family dairy farm in Wisconsin. She decided early in life t become an artist. From 1905 to 1906, she attended the School of the Art Institute of Chicago. In 1907, she went to New York to study at the Art Students League. In 1908 she saw the first American exhibit of the work of Matisse and Rodin at 291 Gallery run by Alfred Stieglitz, who was the noted photographer and advocate of indigenous American art. During the summer of 1912 she attended a drawing class taught by Alon Bement at the University of Virginia at Charlottesville. Through Bement she becomes interested in the anti-academic system of art education developed by Arthur Dow. For the next six years she incorporated this system in here teaching at schools and colleges in Virginia, South Carolina, and Texas. In 1915, she produced a series of large charcoal abstractions. Stieglitz saw the series in 1916 and exhibited them at his 291 Gallery. O'Keeffe moved to New York in 1918 with a promise from Stieglitz of financial support. They married in 1924 and subsequently lived and worked in New York and at Stieglitz's Lake George estate. In 1929, O'Keeffe spent her first of many summers painting in New Mexico. After Stieglitz's death in 1946, she traveled extensively internationally painting scenes from airplanes. In 1949, O'Keefe moved permanently to Abiquia, New Mexico. She continued to work in oils until her eyes failed in the mid-1970. In her old age, she learned to be a hand-held potter. In 1973 she met Juan Hamilton, a ceramic artist. He became her assistant and constant companion until her death in 1986, in Santa Fe. During her lifetime, she received many honors and awards including the American Medal of Freedom and the National Medal of Art. She is considered on of the first American Modernist. O'Keefe's paintings were inspired by the look of things in her world: Flowers, animal bones, landscapes, the in Texas and New Mexico, or the scenes of Lake George, New York, and Manhattan.
Tour Guidance: Learning to Look: Discuss elements of art, color, shape, line, texture, and how they apply to this painting.
Connections: Arthur Dove, Reflections, 2003.161. John Marin, Hurricane, 61.42. Compare with Joan Mitchell and treatment of flowers. Compare with Renoir still life. Compare with early European still lives with flowers.
Micro Summary: Georgia O'Keeffe's "Jimson Weed" was commissioned in 1936 by cosmetics entrepreneur Elizabeth Arden for $10,000 to hang in her New York salon's exercise room, where clients would "unfurl" like the flowers during stretching exercises. The painting features four jimson weed blossoms arranged in an energetic, rhythmic design that mirrors the plant's natural pinwheel shape, rendered in O'Keeffe's signature bright, simplified palette. This work represents the largest floral composition O'Keeffe ever created, showcasing her radical modernist approach of dramatically enlarging flowers to an arresting scale. The close-up view draws viewers into the swirling petals, reflecting O'Keeffe's goal to make "even busy New Yorkers take time to see what I see of flowers."

Title: Portrait of Dr. James E. B. Finley
Artwork Description: Morse painted Finley in the typical dark tonalities and plain background favored for Colonial portraits. Attention is drawn to the sitter's face through the use of light and the white shirt collar. Morse is best known as the inventor of the telegraph, but he was also an established artist. Morse's portrait of Dr. Finley is characteristic of his best canvases. Sensitively observed and firmly painted, it reveals a careful delineation of features without affectation, and with a subordination of minor details. Dr. James E. B. Finley (1758-1819) was an uncle of the artist, and it was Morse's hope to make a reputation for himself in Charleston because of his uncle's position there. Edward Lind Morse tells of Morse's arrival in Charleston in 1818 and reveals the following about the portrait: "At first, however, the promised success did not materialize, and it was not until after many weeks of waiting that the tide turned. But it did turn … around the enthusiasm of the Charlestonians, and others began to pour in, so that in a few weeks he was engaged to paint one hundred and fifty portraits at sixty dollars each."
Artist Biography: Samuel Morse, best known for his invention of the telegraph, was born in Charlestown Massachusetts and graduated from Yale College in 1810. With the American painter Washington Allston, he visited England and studied with Allston and Benjamin West in London. Returning to the States five years later, Morse established himself in New England as a portrait painter. In 1820 he became the first president of the National Academy of Design. Between his New England and New York sojourns Morse was in Charlestown, South Carolina. During the years he received many commissions to paint portraits and, at the same time, he worked experimentally in chemistry and electrical and galvanic fields. As is generally known, Morse conceived the idea of the telegraph while on broad the packet ship Sully on his way from Europe to America in 1832.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Paul J. Straiti. Samuel F. B. Morse, Washington, D. C.: Cambridge University Press, 1990. ISBN-13: 978-0521322188
Micro Summary: Samuel Morse painted this portrait of his uncle, Dr. James E. B. Finley (1758-1819), using the dark tonalities and plain background typical of Colonial portraiture. The work demonstrates Morse's artistic skill before he became famous as the inventor of the telegraph, with careful attention to facial features highlighted by strategic lighting and the white shirt collar. Morse created this portrait during his 1818 visit to Charleston, hoping to establish his reputation through his uncle's connections. The painting exemplifies Morse's best work with its sensitive observation, firm technique, and focus on essential details without affectation.

Title: Portrait of Alice Lyons
Artwork Description: The child's serious expression reflects the mid-19th century concept of children as small adults. The rugged setting is a reminder of the frontier conditions that existed in Indiana in the 1850s. Hegler received a commission from Dr. Lewis Lyons of Attica to paint his daughter Alice. While in Attica, Hegler received a commission from Dr. Lewis Lyons to paint his daughter Alice. He posed the little girl and her dog against a background of country road and woodland. Dr. Lyons was a physician and one of the town's prominent citizens. Every detail of the velvet-braided Victorian frock, the careful smoothed curls and lace-ruffled pantalets is depicted in the precise, quaint fashion of the day. Her serious expression reflects the mid-nineteenth century concept of children as small adults. The rugged landscape setting is a reminder of the frontier conditions that existed in parts of Indiana during the 1850s. Roger G. Wolcott of Indianapolis purchased this canvas from the owner of the old Lyons home, and donated it to the IMA.
Artist Biography: Jacob Hegler arrived in the Midwest around 1845 after emigrating from Switzerland. He undoubtedly studied drawing and painting before coming to America but did not turn to painting as a full-time vocation until settling in Indiana. He enjoyed great success as a portrait painting in the Wabash River town of Attica, Indiana in the mid 1850s.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Very little published information exists on Jacob Hegler. The best source for further research would be the IMA's vertical file on the artist at the museum's Stout Library.
Micro Summary: John J. Hegler painted this formal portrait of Alice Lyons in the 1850s after receiving a commission from her father, Dr. Lewis Lyons, a prominent physician in Attica, Indiana. The painting depicts the young girl in elaborate Victorian dress alongside her dog, set against a rustic landscape that reflects Indiana's frontier conditions of the era. Alice's serious expression exemplifies the mid-19th century view of children as "small adults," while Hegler's precise technique captures every detail of her velvet-braided frock and carefully arranged curls. The artwork was later donated to the Indianapolis Museum of Art after being purchased from the original family home.

Title: Above the Clouds
Artwork Description: About 1875-1878, oil paint. Above the Clouds example of early Hudson River School phase in literalism and concern for detail. Even in this painting, especially its somewhat melancholic mood, hint of later highly introspective style. The Ballard Family Memorial Fund.
Artist Biography: Ralph Albert Blakelock, American (1847-1919). Born New York City, attended College of City of New York intending to become physician. Brief art education Cooper Union. Declined father's offer for advanced training. Wandered three years through American West on horseback with Native Americans. Without additional formal training, painted Native American life and western landscapes shown at National Academy of Design. Great artist, poor businessman. Lived in poverty with wife and nine children. Forced to accept meager sums, suffered breakdown, committed to mental institution. While languished in asylum, paintings gained recognition, prices rose. Became most forged artist in America. Originally Hudson River School painter, developed unique style of luminous, introspective, nocturnal scenes bathed in eerie moonlit atmosphere. Best known as romantic visionary with modernist tendencies unique for his time.
Sources/Bibliography: Janovy, Karen O. and Janice Drie. The Unknown Blakelock. Lincoln, Nebraska: Sheldon Memorial Art Gallery, 2008.
Micro Summary: Ralph Albert Blakelock (1847-1919), self-taught American painter, created Above the Clouds around 1875-1878 during his exploration of atmospheric landscape painting. Born in New York City, Blakelock abandoned medical studies and formal art training to wander the American West for three years with Native Americans, developing a unique artistic vision that combined romantic sensibility with modernist tendencies. Despite creating paintings that would eventually become highly valued and extensively forged, Blakelock lived in poverty with his wife and nine children, suffered a mental breakdown, and spent years in an asylum while his work gained recognition he would never fully enjoy, becoming known for his luminous, introspective nocturnal scenes that established him as a romantic visionary ahead of his time.

Title: Portrait of Clara Fisher
Artwork Description: Henry Inman was the brother-in-law of Clara Fisher's sister Caroline. Clara Fisher debuted in London in 1817 at age six, and in the following ten years toured throughout Great Britain in numerous child and adult roles. Her family came to the United States in 1827, and she debuted in New York City that year. Clara Fisher was a sensation and performed in theaters in nearly every major city over the next seven years. During the "Clara Fisher Craze," her name was given to babies, stagecoaches, brands of cigars, hotels, steamboats, and racehorses; and she was generally considered to be the leading actress of the American stage. Clara Fisher was married in 1834 to James G. Maeder, a composer and vocal coach. They opened a theater in New Orleans, had seven children, and Clara continued to perform with the great actors of the time. Her popularity declined in later years but she continued to act until 1888 (she was 77 years old). She finished an autobiography in 1897, and died the following year at age 87. According to her autobiography, this portrait was done in 1828, the same year as a very similar portrait was done by a Baltimore portrait painter. Clara Fisher would have been about 17 years old at the time. Her autobiography says that she is wearing a medal which was given to her January 1, 1828, at the Park Theater in New York City. She also mentions the bracelet on her upper arm, saying she was very fond of it. "It was solid gold with a rather large medallion portrait of George Frederick Cooke, of whom my father was a great admirer." Clara's father was a librarian and well-known English amateur actor, and Cooke was an English actor (1756-1812). She further states that a Mr. Edmund Simpson owned the original miniature portrait, and loaned it to Thomas Barry to have it copied for the medallion of the bracelet.
Artist Biography: American painter. Born 28 October 1801, Whitestown (near Utica), New York; died 17 January 1846, New York City. Inman moved to New York City with his family in 1812, and two years later (at age 12 or 13) obtained an apprenticeship with John Wesley Jarvis, the city's leading portrait painter. He worked with Jarvis closely, more as a collaborator than as an apprentice. In 1823, he set up his own practice, and was instrumental in founding the National Academy of Design in 1825. As vice president of that organization and as part of the growing cultural community in New York, Inman began to receive portrait commissions from prominent families and government officials. He also painted literary, historical, and genre subjects, many of which were engraved for illustration in journals and gift books, which brought him further renown. Inman moved to Philadelphia in 1831 and became partners with the engraver Cephas G. Childs in a lithographic firm, as well as continuing to paint portraits. After three years there, he returned to New York and was at the height of his career from 1834-1839. Like Philadelphia's Thomas Sully, Inman in New York was called "the American Lawrence," in reference to the English portrait painter, Thomas Lawrence. Inman's portrait subjects included such notable figures as Supreme Court Chief Justices John Marshall and Samuel Nelson, John James Audubon, and Martin Van Buren. Inman also painted a series of North American Indian portraits. He was hired by Thomas L. McKenney to copy earlier portraits by Charles Bird King for a History of the Indian Tribes of North America, which would be illustrated with hand-colored prints based on the painted portraits. Inman continued to paint despite financial difficulties and deteriorating health. He traveled to England in 1844, which briefly revived his health and spirits. He returned to New York in 1845, and died January 17, 1846 (at the age of 44), shortly after an exhibition was held to raise money for his impoverished family. Inman painted in a romantic style with softened contours and a restrained brush, and he often gave his sitters a genial expression or glint of humor. In his portraits of women and children, he conveyed sweetness without sentimentality.
Tour Guidance: In a tour focused on portraits, point out how personal items in the painting give clues or information about the life of the sitter. As part of a tour of paintings which have other art in them, point out the portrait miniature in Clara Fisher's bracelet medallion. Use the portrait to encourage visitors to look more closely and think about the painting: Who do you think this young lady is? What do you think is around her neck? What do you observe about the other jewelry she is wearing? Can you make up a story about her?
Connections: Compare to other portraits that include clothing or personal items which help identify the person, such as George Washington at Princeton, also in the American galleries. Compare to other paintings of young women of a similar age in the American galleries: Preparing for the Matinee by Edmund Charles Tarbell, and Girl Sweeping by William M. Paxton. What might you infer from the paintings about the life and social class of the different young women? Compare to portraits in the American galleries of young women dressed in white: Portrait of Helen Miller by Rembrandt Peale, Calypso by George Hitchcock, Sunlight by Frank W. Benson, and Dorothy by William Merritt Chase.
Sources/Bibliography:
The Dictionary of Art: 34 Volumes, Jane Turner (editor), 2003.
The Art of Henry Inman, Carrie Rebora Barrett and William H. Gerdts, 1987.
Autobiography of Clara Fisher Maeder, Clara F. Maeder, 1897 (reprint 1991).
Micro Summary: Henry Inman (1801-1846) was a prominent American portrait painter who apprenticed under John Wesley Jarvis and became a founding member of the National Academy of Design, earning recognition as "the American Lawrence" for his romantic yet restrained portraits of notable figures including Supreme Court justices and John James Audubon. This 1828 portrait captures Clara Fisher, a celebrated teenage actress who had caused a sensation in America after her debut the previous year, at the height of the "Clara Fisher Craze" when her name adorned everything from cigars to steamboats. The painting exemplifies Inman's skill at conveying character through personal details, showing the 17-year-old actress wearing a commemorative medal from the Park Theater and a gold bracelet containing a miniature portrait of English actor George Frederick Cooke, revealing both her professional achievements and family connections to the theatrical world.

Title: The Harbor Light
Artwork Description: Harrison is identified with an American style called Tonalism. In Tonalist paintings a single hue dominates the composition, which evokes the nuances of light and atmosphere. The softened details and unpeopled terrain exhibit Tonalism's quiet, meditative state. In The Harbor Light, Harrison has muted contrast and softened sharp edges, suffusing the small house and shore in a somber atmosphere of shadow and dim light. He became identified with Tonalism, an American style influenced by the Barbizon painters and Whistler's landscapes. In Tonalist paintings a single hue – often blue or gray – dominates the composition and related colors create a subtle chromatic range that evokes the nuances of light and atmosphere. The softened details and windswept terrain of The Harbor Light exhibit Tonalism's quiet, meditative state.
Artist Biography: Born in Philadelphia, Birge Harrison was briefly a farmer and a businessman. He turned to painting in 1876 and studied first at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts and then spent six years in Paris, where he enrolled at the École des Beaux Arts. He returned to New York and taught landscape painting at the Art Students League. Harrison concentrated almost exclusively on landscapes executed in the evocative manner of the Barbizon artists. He was a prolific writer on art, and in 1909, Harrison published Landscape Painting, which became the standard text for many years. In addition, he founded the art colony in Woodstock, New York.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Harrison, Birge. Landscape Painting. Originally published in 1909, London: Bibliofile Ltd., 2009.
Micro Summary: "The Harbor Light" by Birge Harrison exemplifies American Tonalism, where a single dominant hue creates a subtle chromatic range that captures nuanced light and atmosphere. Harrison employs muted contrasts and softened edges to suffuse the small house and shore in a somber atmosphere of shadow and dim light. The painting's softened details and windswept, unpeopled terrain embody Tonalism's characteristic quiet, meditative quality. This American style was influenced by the Barbizon painters and Whistler's landscapes, often featuring blue or gray as the predominant color.

Title: Portrait of Charles H. Brewer
Artwork Description: Jacob Cox was trained as a tinsmith, a trade that he followed for a time even after he began painting in the early 1840s. Cox received many portrait commissions but found more personal enjoyment in painting landscapes. The carefully depicted pet and the image of leisure activity combine to create an engaging impression of the boy's personality and interests. Cox's portrait of Charles H. Brewer hung in his son Charles's home for fifty-five years before it was offered as a gift to the IMA. The family recounts that the elder Brewer was about twelve years old when Cox painted him. According to Brewer's son, the artist finished the painting in his studio, added the fishing rod and dog, which did not belong to the sitter. Such attributes, including the imaginary landscape in the background, were common practices in nineteenth century portraiture and served to enhance the sitter's status or, in this case, add to the image of a childhood.
Artist Biography: Jacob Cox was born in Burlington New Jersey, the first of ten children born to a Quaker couple who died in separate ferry accidents. Cox's grandfather and aunt in Washington, Pennsylvania became his guardians. By that time the young Cox was already interested in art. He was apprenticed to a tinsmith at the age of sixteen. In 1830, Cox and his brother established a tinsmith shop, first in Pittsburgh and later in Indianapolis. The business prospered forcing Cox to pursue his painting during his spare time. By 1835 painting portraits was added to Cox's business. Cox closed his shop and traveled to Cincinnati to study with John Dunn, returning to Indianapolis to paint portraits of such local notables as Senator Oliver Smith, Governors David Wallace and Noah Noble, State Treasurer Samuel Merrill, and numerous prominent businessmen and their families. His success enabled Cox to travel to New York City to study briefly at the National Academy of Design. Upon his return, he found time to add landscapes and still life to his repertoire. When the Indiana School of Art was established in Indianapolis in 1877, Cox became one of its teachers. He continued to paint and exhibit until his death at eighty one.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Paintings by Jacob Cox a Retrospective Exhibition of Work by an Early Indianapolis Artist, Indianapolis: John Herron Art Museum, 1941. ASIN: B001O1F2TS
Micro Summary: Jacob Cox, an American artist who transitioned from tinsmithing to painting in the 1840s, created this portrait of twelve-year-old Charles H. Brewer. Though Cox preferred landscape painting, he received many portrait commissions and enhanced this work by adding fictional elements including a fishing rod, dog, and imaginary background landscape in his studio. These added attributes were common in 19th-century portraiture to convey the subject's interests and enhance their social status. The portrait remained in the Brewer family for fifty-five years before being donated to the IMA, creating an engaging impression of the boy's personality through carefully chosen symbolic elements.

Title: Marianne Ashley Walker
Artwork Description: Stuart endows his subject with character and elegance through sheer technical facility, which is evident in Walker's exquisitely rendered flesh tones and lifelike eyes. This portrait was painted on the occasion of the sitter's marriage. The portrait of Marianne Ashley Walker exemplifies Stuart's ability to endow his sitters with character and elegance. The velvet-draped column and serene pose are standard conventions of portraiture at that time, but Stuart's particular gifts shine forth from her exquisitely rendered flesh and lifelike eyes. Stuart has seized upon the young woman's dignified beauty, drawing her poise and confidence to an expressive point that stops short of arrogance or disdain. Marianne Ashley Walker was the daughter of John Ashley of Philadelphia. In 1799, she married Simon Walker in Philadelphia. The portrait is thought to have been painted on the occasion of her wedding. The companion portrait of her husband is in the collection of the Baltimore Museum.
Artist Biography: Debt resulting from an inability to manage money kept Gilbert Stuart on the move much of his life. Born in North Kingston, Rhode Island, and raised in Newport, Stuart was taught by a local Scottish painter, who took him to Scotland. His mentor's death forced Stuart to return to America. During the Revolutionary War, Stuart traveled to England to study with the American expatriate Benjamin West. As success came, so did debt, which forced Stuart to Dublin, Ireland, and then to America, where he eventually became the most highly regarded portraitist of his day. A skillful master of his craft, Stuart painted directly on the canvas without using any preliminary drawing. Stuart was prolific – he painted over one thousand portraits of important political figures. One of his most famous portraits of George Washington was the "Athenaeum Head," which is currently on the dollar bill.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Barratt, Carrie Rebora and Ellen Gross Miles. Gilbert Stuart. New York: Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2004.
Micro Summary: Gilbert Stuart's portrait of Marianne Ashley Walker showcases his exceptional technical skill through exquisitely rendered flesh tones and lifelike eyes that bring character and elegance to his subject. Painted around 1799 to commemorate Walker's marriage to Simon Walker in Philadelphia, the work exemplifies Stuart's ability to capture dignified beauty and poise without crossing into arrogance. While employing standard portrait conventions of the era like the velvet-draped column and serene pose, Stuart's particular artistic gifts elevate the work through his masterful rendering of the young woman's confident yet graceful demeanor.

Title: Woman in White
Artwork Description: Portrait painting depicting a woman dressed in white. The work demonstrates the artist's skill with tonal painting and capturing the play of light on fabric. The monochromatic approach creates a sophisticated, elegant effect.
Artist Biography: Ruth Pratt Bobbs was an Indianapolis-based artist active in the early-to-mid 20th century. She was part of the active Indianapolis art community and contributed to the development of American art in the region.
Tour Guidance: This work represents the contributions of Indianapolis-based artists to American portraiture. The focus on white tones and the subtle gradations of light and shadow show technical sophistication and careful observation.
Connections: Connect to other monochromatic works and paintings featuring white clothing. Compare with Whistler's Symphony in White series. Discuss local Indianapolis art scene and regional contributions to American art.
Sources/Bibliography: Indianapolis Museum of Art acquisition records. Indianapolis art community documentation.
Micro Summary: Bobbs' monochromatic portrait exemplifies Indianapolis artists' contributions to American portraiture through sophisticated handling of white tones and subtle light effects. The work's elegant simplicity demonstrates careful observation and technical skill in depicting gradations of light on fabric. As part of the active Indianapolis art community, Bobbs contributed to the regional development of American art in the early-to-mid 20th century.

Title: Hotel Lobby
Artwork Description: Realistic depiction of a hotel lobby viewed from a high vantage point. (Hopper loved theatre. This work has the feeling of a stage set viewed from the balcony.) Cool colors and strong shadows contribute to the isolation of the figures. There appears to be no interaction among the figures. Hotel lobby with old-fashioned front desk, elevator and overstuffed furniture, reminiscent of the 1940s. Diagonal patterns with sharp shadows and contrasts e.g. on the floor, on the wall, the blonde woman's legs, mountain shapes in the painting. Red dress pulls the eye into the painting as well as the red carpet trim around the desk.
Artist Biography: Hopper was brought up in Nyack, NY on the Hudson River where he developed a love for the nautical life. In 1900 he enrolled in a commercial illustration class at the New York School of Art and after a year he started classes in painting and drawing with William Merritt Chase and Robert Henri. In the autumn of 1906 Hopper traveled to Paris to study European artists often working "en plein" air. He first exhibited in 1908 at a group show in NYC organized by some of Henri's students. Hopper continued to work as an illustrator (even winning a top prize for a poster Smash the Hun). He moved to Greenwich Village in 1913, which remained his permanent base. He exhibited at the Amory Show in 1913 with Sailing, the first painting he sold; he did not sell another for 10 years. In 1920 he held his first one-man show at the Whitney Studio Club. By 1923 Hopper re-established contact with Josephine Nivison whom he had known at art school. She encouraged him to take up watercolor. They married in 1924 and painted together in New England. When they returned to NYC, he had his second very successful exhibition at the Frank KM Rehn Gallery where he remained for the rest of his career. In 1925, Hopper painted House by the Railroad, which became the first painting by an artist to be acquired for MOMA. In 1933 Alfred Barr organized Hopper's first retrospective for MOMA. Hopper and his wife continued to spend their summers painting in Cape Cod where they built a home in 1934. A feeling of loneliness and detachment pervaded his works in the second half of his career. A 1950 retrospective at the Whitney was regarded as the work of an enduring realist. By 1964 when the Whitney hosted this third retrospective, he was hailed as the forefather of the new avant-garde.
Tour Guidance: Urban realist painting. Contrast between elderly couple and young woman (clothing, demeanor and activity). Emotionless or moodiness. Do you see the 4th person? Do modern hotel lobbies resemble this one? Make up a story about this picture. What's going on? VTS appropriate.
Connections: Edward Fisk, Rooftops, New York City. Reginald Marsh, Hauptmann Must Die. Norman Rockwell, The Love Song
Sources/Bibliography: The Hoosier Group Five American Painters by Judith Vale Newton, p. 139-150
Micro Summary: Edward Hopper's "Hotel Lobby" presents a theatrical view of a 1940s-style hotel interior, complete with traditional furnishings, front desk, and elevator. The composition, reminiscent of a stage set viewed from a theater balcony, features isolated figures who appear disconnected from one another despite sharing the same space. Cool colors and dramatic shadows emphasize the sense of urban loneliness, while strategic use of red in a woman's dress and carpet trim draws the viewer's eye through the scene. Sharp diagonal patterns and contrasts create visual tension throughout the realistic depiction.

Title: Hauptmann Must Die
Artwork Description: Historical Reference: On Tuesday evening, March 1, 1932, 20-month-old Charles Lindbergh, Jr., son of aviator Charles Lindbergh, was kidnapped from his crib. Two and one half years later, on September 19, 1934, a suspect, Bruno Richard Hauptmann, was arrested. A journalist at the time called the trial of Hauptmann, "the greatest story since the Resurrection." While that is an exaggeration, the public interest does make the Hauptmann trial stand with the O.J. Simpson and Scopes trials as among the most famous trials of the 20th century. Hauptmann was electrocuted. The painting is a fascinating work not only because of the American social history it documents, but also because of the basic truth expressed in its cast of characters. A middle-aged woman, dressed for cold weather while waiting in the gloom of New York's Penn Station, is absorbed in a newspaper trumpeting a Depression-era event, which riveted the nation's attention: Bruno Hauptmann has been convicted of the kidnapping and murder of aviator Charles Lindbergh's son; he must pay with his life. With an honesty that is almost painful, as well as characteristic, Marsh captures the essential isolation of individual human beings who must mark time in impersonal caverns such as Penn Station. Eight people are discernible in the picture, and each is an island unto himself. The painting is rare among Marsh works in that it depicts an interior scene. Marsh is more noted for his New York City street scenes, bustling compositions that capture the gritty flavor of jockeying for position on the crowded sidewalk or, at times, those brief moments when individuals are transfixed in the privacy of their own thoughts while a seemingly insensitive city flows about them.
Artist Biography: Born Paris, March 14, 1898; died Dorset, VT, July 30, 1954. American painter, printmaker and illustrator. He returned from France to the USA with his American parents, Fred Dana Marsh (1872–1961) and Alice (née Randall) Marsh, who were also artists, in 1900. In 1920 he graduated from Yale University, New Haven, CT, where he had been art editor and cartoonist for the Yale Record. He moved to New York and became staff artist for Vanity Fair and the New York Daily News. By 1923 he had begun painting scenes of street life in New York in oil and watercolor. His first one-man show was held at the Whitney Studio Club in 1924. In 1925 he joined the New Yorker, to which he contributed regularly until 1931. In 1925 Marsh traveled with his first wife, sculptor Betty Burroughs, to Europe where he studied and copied the works of the Old Master painters such as Peter Paul Rubens, Rembrandt and Michelangelo, whom he particularly admired for their ability to organize large figure groups. In 1927–8 he studied at the Art Students League in New York under Kenneth Hayes Miller, who encouraged him to paint the earthy vitality and social landscape of life in New York, subjects typical of American Scene Painting. Marsh painted and made prints of scenes such as Dance Marathon and Times Square, the 'El' or elevated railway, and the Bowery, often taking preparatory photographs for the painting. In 1929 Marsh was shown by Thomas Hart Benton how to use egg tempera, the medium in which most of his street scenes of the 1930s are painted. In the 1940s he experimented with the 'Maroger medium', an oil emulsion formula promoted by Jacques Maroger of the Musée du Louvre, Paris, who believed it to have been used by some Old Master painters. In the last two decades of his life Marsh continued to depict the same themes, for example The Bowery—Strokey's Bar.
Tour Guidance: American gallery tour has several paintings by artists that Marsh studied with or was influenced by their work. For example: John Sloan (Red Kimono on the Roof), Thomas Hart Benton (Henry Look Unhitching). The Hats theme tour. There are at least five hats worth pointing out on a Hats tour. VTS. The painting is crowded with people, five of whom are facing the viewer and have a story to tell from the expressions on their faces. In the same gallery, you can look at Guy Pene Du Bois' Promenade. He painted at the same time as Marsh and was also a social realist. He would often paint a witty and mocking view of New York society. He developed a style dominated by simplified and stylized figures.
Connections: Compare Henry Look Unhitching with other IMA artworks of the same time period: Edward Hopper's Hotel Lobby (1943); Reginald Marsh's Hauptmann Must Die (1941); Isabel Bishop's Tidying Up (1941); Joseph Delaney's The Artist's Party (1941-1943).
Sources/Bibliography: Collections information on the IMA website. Bernard Danenberg Galleries, Inc. catalog. July-August 1969. Madison Avenue. N.Y.C. Creative Art, April 1933. Grove Art Online. http://www.lindberghkidnappinghoax.com/fisch.html. http://www.law.umkc.edu/faculty/porjects/ftrials/Hauptmann/Hauptmann.htm. January 20, 1980, The Indianapolis Star. "Two IMA Shows Highlight Recent Gifts". News release from Gallery of Modern Art, N.Y. December 1964. Obituary by Dorothy Seiberlin. Whitney Museum publication.
Micro Summary: Hauptmann Must Die captures the Depression-era Lindbergh kidnapping trial through isolated figures in Penn Station absorbed in newspapers about Bruno Hauptmann's conviction. Marsh's social realist masterpiece documents American history while revealing the painful isolation of individuals in impersonal urban spaces. The rare interior scene showcases Marsh's characteristic honesty in depicting New York life and human psychology.

Title: The Valley in the Sea
Artwork Description: This canvas is perhaps the only panoramic underwater scene in 19th-century American art, and it is the aquatic equivalent of a Hudson River School landscape.Moran may have been inspired by underwater exploration related to the laying of the first successful telegraph cable in 1858. The Valley in the Sea is the first and perhaps only panoramic underwater view in nineteenth-century American art. It is most likely that Dr. James M. Sommerville, the original owner of Valley in the Sea, commissioned Edward Moran to create this painting, which was executed in Philadelphia. In 1859, Sommerville published Ocean Life, which included illustrations of seventy-five different species of aquatic life. In 1860, Matthew Fontaine Maury published The Physical Geography of the Sea and Its Meteorology, the first textbook on modern oceanography. There is a marked similarity between some of Maury's descriptions and Moran's paintings. A 1971 letter from Jacques Cousteau stated, "Ed Moran's painting … is a work of imagination, based on serious documentation."
Artist Biography: Born in England, Edward Moran immigrated to Maryland in 1844, where his father was a hand loom weaver. One of twelve children, Moran left home to work in a cotton factory in Philadelphia, where he also drew large sketches. He and his brother Thomas studied and shared a studio in Philadelphia before returning to England to continue their artistic training. Edward Moran is best known for his marine paintings. His style was influenced by J. M. W. Turner's seascapes and seventeenth- and eighteenth-century Dutch painting. Although his brother Thomas Moran is the more famous of the two artists, Edward Moran was unequalled during his time as a marine painter.
Tour Guidance: Not available in IMA generated documents
Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography:
Thomas, Tom. Marine Paintings: Edward Moran-Master Painter. CreateSpace, 2009. ISBN-13: 978-1442116719
Sommerville, James M. Ocean Life. Stockholm: Tryckt hos A. L. Norman, reprinted 2009
Micro Summary: Edward Moran's "The Valley in the Sea" is a groundbreaking panoramic underwater landscape that stands as the only known work of its kind in 19th-century American art. Likely commissioned by Dr. James M. Sommerville and inspired by the 1858 telegraph cable laying and emerging oceanographic studies, the painting represents an aquatic equivalent to Hudson River School landscapes. The work combines artistic imagination with scientific documentation from early oceanography texts, creating a unique underwater vista that predated modern underwater exploration by decades.

Title: Ruth Gleaning
Artwork Description:
Modeled in 1853 and carved in 1860.

Example of the neo-classical when that movement dominated American sculpture from 1825 through the Civil War.

Depicts the moment when the Old Testament's Ruth, crouching in the fields to glean wheat left behind, first sees Boaz her kinsman who becomes her future husband.

Used the motif of a single bared breast, which he again used in the sculpture Nydia, at a time when Victorians viewed nudity as suspect and equated it with eroticism.

The sculpture is noted for Ruth's elegant face and profile. Her poised bearing attains the grace and harmony of the neo-classical and its Greco-Roman prototypes, but imbues Ruth with sweetness and charm, as noted by her poignant gesture and beseeching gaze.

Composition subtly leads the viewer around an ever-changing circuit of angles and curves, light and shadows. Its detailed sheaves of wheat, plants, and costume show Rogers' interest in naturalistic and anecdotal accuracy.
Artist Biography:
American sculptor. Born July 6, 1825, Waterloo, N.Y.; died January 15, 1892.

Rogers grew up in Ann Arbor, MI when Michigan was still a territory, apprenticed as a baker, clerked in a dry goods store and occasionally did freelance illustrations for the Michigan Artists of Ann Arbor.

At age 22 he went to New York City to find employment in an engraver's office but could only find work with a dry goods firm.

Discovering his aptitude for carving, his employer subsidized a trip to Florence, Italy for proper artistic training in 1848. He apprenticed under Lorenzo Barteloni, the leading talent of Tuscan sculpture, a neo-classicist.

He modeled in clay & plaster, selected the marble and the carving was then done by studio assistants under his direction.

For 20 years he worked in the heart of the English community in Florence and in 1853 modeled one of his most successful statues, Ruth Gleaning, earning him the reputation as a skillful interpreter of biblical and literary themes.

Received his first public commission, creating a statue of John Adams for Mt. Auburn Cemetery in Cambridge.

His most prestigious work was the bronze doors for the entrance to Rotunda of US Capitol, depicting in 8 low-relief panels scenes from the life of Columbus using as inspiration Ghiberti's Gates of Paradise for the Baptistry in Florence, Italy.

He married, fathering 9 children, suffered a paralytic stroke in 1892, and died in 1892, being buried beside his wife in Rome, Italy.
Tour Guidance:
Biblical Events Tour—Old Testament examples – Carlo Maratti's Rebecca and Eliezer at the Well, Jan Victors' Jacob Seeking Forgiveness of Esau.

American Art Spotlights – add sculpture to tour & importance as an outstanding neo-classical American sculpture at IMA.
Connections:
Persephone – Ruth compared to classical Greek female sculpture.

Ruth's gaze – Frank Benson's Sunlight, George Hitchcock's Calypso, E.A. Bell's Portrait of a Young Woman, which also contrasts dark colors vs. white marble or brightness of Sunlight.

Frederick William MacMonnies' sculpture Bacchante & Infant Faun done in 1893 denounced by civic leaders of Puritanical Boston as lewd.

Louisa Fletcher by Mary Shepard Greene Blumenschein in 1912 – very different gaze – rather come-hither look.

Gari Melchers' Joan of Arc – contrast peasant dress with Ruth in classical Greek garb.

Millard F Rogers Jr. Randolph Rogers; American Sculptor in Home University of Massachusetts Press 1971
