Micro Summary: Randolph Rogers (1825-1892), American sculptor born in Waterloo, New York, created Ruth Gleaning in 1853 (modeled) and 1860 (carved in marble), depicting the biblical figure gathering grain after the harvest as told in the Book of Ruth. Rogers, who studied in Florence and Rome and maintained a highly successful studio producing works for patrons across America and Europe, shows Ruth in classical dress with idealized features characteristic of Neoclassical sculpture, her downward gaze and humble posture emphasizing her devotion and virtue. The work exemplifies mid-nineteenth-century American sculptors' preference for biblical and historical subjects rendered in white marble with smooth, refined surfaces, demonstrating Rogers's technical mastery and his ability to convey moral narratives through graceful figural composition that appealed to Victorian sensibilities.

Title: Wash Day
Artwork Description: This belongs to a smaller group of landscapes that Adams painted in 1884 and 1885. This painting is brighter than the paintings that Adams learned at the Royal Academy in Munich where they did not teach landscape painting. It can also be seen in this painting how Adams was drawn more towards the tightly painted Barbizon style. Adams handles his colors and brushstrokes with richness. The play of light on the painting gives it a soft touch. He also gives a human interest touch to the painting by adding the lady. The figure is essential to the composition which combines genre and landscape.
Artist Biography: American painter and teacher. Born July 8, 1851, Amity, Indiana; died January 28, 1927 Indianapolis, Indiana. John Ottis Adams was one of the major figures in Indiana art. A contemporary of T.C. Steele, Adams studied art at the South Kensington School in London under John Parker from 1872-1874. He lived in Muncie, Indiana from 1876-1880 painting portraits. In 1880 he traveled with T.C. Steele, Samuel Richards and others to Munich, Germany. He made many copies of old Masters while abroad and also painted both scenes including figures and landscapes outdoors. Upon his return to Muncie, Indiana in 1887 he was a key member of the "Hoosier Group" consisting of T.C. Steele, Otto Stark, William Forsyth, and Richard B. Gruelle, engaging in both portrait painting and teaching, at the same time carrying on his landscape work. In the same year he opened an art school with Mr. Forsyth in Muncie. In 1888 he established an art school in Fort Wayne, Indiana and also was active in the John Herron School of Art in Indianapolis. He was the principal instructor at the school from 1904 to 1909. He shared a house with Steele, which contained separate studios, in the town of Brookville in Franklin County, Indiana called "The Hermitage". The picturesque countryside around Brookville was a favorite painting ground for artists. It has been called the "The Indiana Barbizon". His Academic Munich work falls into three fairly equal categories. The first consists of Hoosier school pieces; second are the Academic German genre scenes of peasants in interiors; the third features scenes of peasants working in the fields. His early pictures were portraits but Adams excelled in landscapes to which he devoted his activities in the later years. He specialized in painting the rural landscapes of Indiana. Adams's paintings also include scenes from Michigan lakes where he often spent his summers and scenes from Florida, where he spent his winters.
Tour Guidance: Landscape tours - Compare landscapes by different artists and how the play of light changes the perception of a painting. Compare and contrast rural landscapes and cityscapes. Artists from Indiana – Talk about the "Hoosier Group", how they were influenced by the beauty of Indiana. Tie with how Brookville was called the "Indiana Barbizon" and explain the Barbizon School of painting. Note how both the Barbizon painters and the Hoosier Artists were inspired by nature.
Connections: An August Sunset-Prairie Dell, by Adams 1894 and how light was important to the painting. Can you tell the time of the day without looking at the title? Or the type of weather? Compare with other landscape paintings by other Hoosier artists like T.C. Steele's The Bloom of the Grape, 1893; discuss how the Steele is more luminous. Pleasant Run, T.C. Steele, 1885 – Contemporary of Adams, studied at Munich also. Compare and contrast styles.
Sources/Bibliography: Krause, Martin. "The Passage". Indiana Artists File.
Micro Summary: Wash Day showcases John Ottis Adams' transition toward the Barbizon style with bright colors and rich brushwork depicting Indiana's rural landscape. A founding member of the Hoosier Group, Adams combines genre and landscape by including a figure that adds human interest. The painting demonstrates his mastery of light and represents his work from the influential Brookville period known as the Indiana Barbizon.

Title: Quarry at Byram
Artwork Description: Garber recreated the quarry's raw, craggy features adding an Impressionist play of light across its richly textured surface. The quarries near the artist's home in Bucks County are an important theme in his work. Born in Indiana, Garber became a teacher at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. Quarry at Byram exemplifies Garber's painting of these excavations. He recreates their raw, craggy surfaces with great deliberation, devoting his Impressionist sensibilities to the play of light across the Pennsylvania soil. Garber infused the setting with his own lyrical approach to the American landscape, achieving a subtle balance between the cliff's massive volume and its rich surface properties.
Artist Biography: Daniel Garber was born in 1880 to a Mennonite farm family near North Manchester, Indiana. He eventually settled in Pennsylvania, where he studied at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts under William Merritt Chase. He was awarded a fellowship, which allowed him to study in England, France, and Italy. When he returned in 1909, he became a faculty member of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, teaching painting and drawing for the next forty-one years. Garber was known as one of the leaders of the Pennsylvania Impressionists, or the New Hope School, as the group was called. He depicted the quarries, woods, and Delaware River Valley of Bucks County, Pennsylvania. His home near Lumberville was not far from the great stone quarries at Byram, New Jersey, which he often painted. Like most Impressionists, Garber painted out of doors directly from nature. These patterned scenes were dominated by shades of blue, green, and yellow. His work earned gold medals and numerous awards and prizes.

Sources/Bibliography: Humphries, Lance. Daniel Garber: His Life and Work. New York: Hollis Taggart Galleries, 2006. Peterson, Brian H. Pennsylvania Impressionism. Philadelphia: James A Michener Art Museum and University of Pennsylvania Press, 2002.
Micro Summary: Daniel Garber's "Quarry at Byram" depicts a quarry near his Bucks County home using Impressionist techniques to capture light playing across the excavation's raw, craggy surfaces. The Indiana-born artist, who taught at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, made quarries an important recurring theme in his work. Garber applied his lyrical approach to the American landscape, skillfully balancing the massive volume of the cliff with detailed attention to its rich textural properties and the effects of light on Pennsylvania soil.

Title: At the End of the Porch
Artwork Description: The intricate network of trellis, railing and awning are woven into an ordered composition. Strokes of brilliant color are applied with a sensitivity to light and shade acquired from regular outdoor painting. Sharman's current obscurity is hard to understand considering this beautiful scene. Another article in the Boston Transcript praised At the End of the Porch as "a beautiful, luminous and joyous picture of a place where one would like to be. It represents a glassed-in porch, in the summer, and a lady sitting at her work; through the windows may be seen masses of shrubbery and white blossoms. An admirable canvas, it has the quality of reserve, but that does not prevent it from conveying with singular aptitude a most artistic impression of a lovely scene." In At the End of the Porch, Sharman used the intricate network of trellis, railing, and awning to define space and construct a well-ordered composition. Upon his framework, he has lavished broad strokes of brilliant color, applied with sensitivity to light and shade that Sharman acquired from regular painting out-of-doors (en plein air). The summer sun burns the striped awning with salmon-tinted hues, casts deep shadows on the silent porch, and bleaches vines into a wave of white blossoms.
Artist Biography: John Sharman's biography reads like the ideal formula for establishing the American artist of repute: training under Frank Benson and Edmund Tarbell at Boston's Museum School, a steady exhibition schedule, and favorable reviews of his mature work. A 1922 article discussing an exhibition of Sharman's paintings states, "Not in a long time has such a stimulating one-man show been seen in Boston as the present exhibition of John Sharman." Despite the numerous articles of praise written about Sharman, not a word about this artist or his work appears in texts on American painting, even those that specialize in artists with an impressionistic style. The IMA library's vertical files contain a folder on Sharman that includes many of the articles written about him during his lifetime. Unfortunately, few texts were published posthumously that discuss the artist or his work.

Micro Summary: "At the End of the Porch" by John Sharman depicts a glassed-in summer porch where a lady sits at her work, surrounded by an intricate composition of trellis, railing, and awning. The artist employs brilliant strokes of color with masterful sensitivity to light and shade, developed through his practice of plein air painting. Summer sunlight transforms the scene with salmon-tinted hues on the striped awning, deep shadows across the porch, and masses of white blossoms visible through the windows. The Boston Transcript praised it as "a beautiful, luminous and joyous picture of a place where one would like to be," noting its artistic reserve and ability to convey a lovely, peaceful scene.

Title: Sleep
Artwork Description: 16 1/4 x 12 in. (image) 20 1/2 x 15 1/8 in. (sheet)
Artist Biography: Diego Rivera was a talented Mexican painter associated with the muralist movement. A communist, he was often criticized for creating paintings that were too controversial. Along with José Clemente Orozco and David Alfaro Siquieros, he is considered one of the "big three," most important Mexican muralists. Today he is remembered as much for his volatile marriage to fellow artist Frida Kahlo as he is for his art. Early Years: Diego María de la Concepción Juan Nepomuceno Estanislao de la Rivera y Barrientos Acosta y Rodríguez was born in 1886 in Guanajuato, Mexico. A naturally gifted artist, he began his formal art training at a young age, but it wasn't until he went to Europe in 1907 that his talent truly began to blossom. 1907-1921 Rivera's Years in Europe: During his stay in Europe, Rivera was exposed to cutting-edge avant garde art. In Paris, he had a front row seat to the development of the cubist movement and in 1914 he met Pablo Picasso, who expressed admiration for the young Mexican's work. Leaving Paris when the First World War broke out, he went to Spain, where he helped introduce Cubism in Madrid. He would travel around Europe until 1921, visiting many regions including southern France and Italy, and would be influenced by the works of Cezanne and Renoir. Return to Mexico and Beginnings of the Muralist Movement: Returning to Mexico, Rivera soon found work for the new revolutionary government. Secretary of Public Education José Vasconcelos believed in education through public art, and commissioned several murals on government buildings from Rivera as well as fellow painters David Alfaro Siquieros and José Clemente Orozco. The beauty and artistic depth of the paintings gained Rivera and his fellow muralists international acclaim. International Work: Rivera's fame earned him commissions to paint in other countries besides Mexico. He traveled to the Soviet Union in 1927 as part of a delegation of Mexican communists. He painted murals at the California School of Fine Arts, The American Stock Exchange Luncheon Club, and the Detroit Institute of the Arts, and another was commissioned for the Rockefeller Center in New York. However, it was never completed due to controversy over Rivera's inclusion of the image of Vladimir Lenin in the work. Although his stay in the United States was short, he is considered a major influence on American art. Return to Mexico: Rivera returned to Mexico, where he resumed the life of a politically active artist. He was instrumental in the defection of Leon Trotsky from the Soviet Union to Mexico: Trotsky even lived with Rivera and Frida Kahlo for a time. He continued to court controversy: one of his murals, at the Hotel del Prado, contained the phrase "God does not exist" and was hidden from view for years. Another, this one at the Palace of Fine Arts, was removed because it included images of Stalin and Mao Tse-tung. Marriage to Frida Kahlo: Diego met Frida Kahlo a promising art student, in 1928; they married the year after. The mixture of the fiery Kahlo and the dramatic Rivera would prove to be a volatile one: they each had numerous extramarital affairs and fought often. Rivera even had a fling with Frida's sister Cristina. Diego and Frida divorced in 1940 but remarried later the same year. Rivera's Final Years: Although their relationship had been stormy, Rivera was devastated by the death of Frida Kahlo in 1954. He never really recovered, falling ill not long after. Although weak, he continued to paint and even remarried. He died of heart failure in 1957. Legacy: Rivera is considered the greatest of the Mexican muralists, an art form which was imitated around the world. His influence is greatly important in the United States: his paintings in the 1930's directly influenced Franklin Roosevelt's work programs, and hundreds of American artists began creating public art with a conscience. His smaller works are very valuable and many are on display in museums
Tour Guidance: Possible Questions to start the discussion: 1. What affect does cropping have on this scene? (Creates the image that there are many sleeping people above and beside the woman and child. Creates the image that the woman is physically supporting many others besides the child). 2. Does this scene resemble a picture of Madonna and Child, how? 3. Do you get a sense of comfort or discomfort, why? 4. What social economic class do the woman and child belong to? What makes you think this? Background information for docents to use age appropriately and sparingly, particularly if the visitors ask questions or indicate they want more information:
Connections: Manuel Alvarez Bravo (Mexican, 1902–2002), Sleeping Dogs Bark (1966)_ 79.692, Gelatin silver print 9 15/16 x 8 in.
Sources/Bibliography: Lynn Gibboney – 11 August 2013
Micro Summary: "Sleep" is a work by renowned Mexican muralist Diego Rivera (1886-1957), measuring 16 1/4 x 12 inches for the image and 20 1/2 x 15 1/8 inches for the full sheet. This intimate-scale piece represents a departure from Rivera's famous large-scale public murals that depicted Mexican history and social themes. The artwork captures a quiet, contemplative moment focused on the universal human experience of rest and repose. As with much of Rivera's work, it likely demonstrates his masterful draftsmanship and ability to imbue everyday subjects with deeper meaning and emotional resonance.

Title: An August Sunset – Prairie Dell
Artwork Description: Here the sun sets over the rich, green, prairie landscape. A bright orange orb suggests the end of a hot summer day. This painting is characteristic of the flatness and horizontality of the landscape. Prairie Dell is an area in Prairie Township, not far from Adams's home in Muncie, Indiana. Owned by Winifred Brady Adams (wife of the artist); given to the museum by sons of the artist

Micro Summary: John Ottis Adams's "An August Sunset – Prairie Dell" depicts a vibrant orange sun setting over the flat, green prairie landscape near his Muncie, Indiana home. The painting captures the end of a hot summer day with its characteristic emphasis on the horizontal expanse of the prairie. The work portrays Prairie Dell, an area in Prairie Township, showcasing Adams's connection to the local Indiana landscape. Originally owned by the artist's wife, Winifred Brady Adams, the painting was later donated to the museum by their sons.

Title: Sketch, Hyannisport
Artwork Description: With loose, fluid brushstrokes, the artist depicts the boats, cottages, and shore of this harbor, while still emphasizing the flat surface of the canvas. Paintings of Provincetown fishermen executed in a more somber palette so dominate the artist's work that this lively, vibrant painting of Hyannisport, a town 50 miles away, represents an intriguing contrast. Hawthorne is so strongly associated with Provincetown that it is something of a surprise to find that he took a painting trip to Hyannisport, about fifty miles away. What is even more unusual is that the works painted in Hyannisport are much closer to Impressionism than his normally realist Provincetown technique with its somber palette. This loose, fluid sketch has the spontaneity of a painting rendered out of doors, directly before the subject. With unhesitating strokes of the brush, Hawthorne transcribed the boats, cottages, and shore of this Cape Cod harbor. He abandoned his usual somber palette in favor of the bright blue hues common to Impressionist seascapes. His summary treatment of the figure and boats, and his subtle distinctions between sky, shore, and sea, emphasize the flat surface of the canvas. This sketch of Hyannisport's harbor is an eloquent expression of the artist's love of the Massachusetts coast.
Artist Biography: Hawthorne studied under William Merritt Chase and helped run Chase's Long Island school before founding the Cape Cod School of Art in Provincetown, Massachusetts. The town attracted many artists, and Hawthorne became known as the "father" of the art colony. A student of William Merritt Chase and a lover of the Old Masters, Hawthorne is equally known as a teacher and artist. His skill at depicting the fishermen in Provincetown is legendary, while his work in Hyannisport is much less known.

Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Hawthorne, Mrs. Charles W. Hawthorne On Painting. Mineola, New York: Dover Publications, 1960.
Micro Summary: Charles Webster Hawthorne's "Sketch, Hyannisport" depicts a Cape Cod harbor scene with loose, fluid brushstrokes that capture boats, cottages, and shoreline. This vibrant work represents a departure from Hawthorne's typical somber Provincetown paintings, instead embracing bright blue Impressionist hues and spontaneous outdoor painting techniques. The artist's summary treatment of figures and boats emphasizes the flat canvas surface while maintaining subtle distinctions between sky, shore, and sea. Created during an unusual painting trip 50 miles from his usual Provincetown subjects, this sketch demonstrates Hawthorne's versatile artistic approach and enduring love for the Massachusetts coast.

Title: After the Shower
Artwork Description: In After the Shower, Chase relies on techniques he learned at the Royal Academy in Munich and from Munich-based American painters such as Frank Duveneck. The broad brushwork and massing of lights and darks suggest his German training, although the composition and color show the impact of the French Barbizon painters. Chase painted it shortly before turning to the light-filled style on which his reputation as a landscape painter is based.
Artist Biography: William Merritt Chase was born in Ninevah, Indiana and studied under Barton Hayes in Indianapolis and then briefly at the National Academy of Design. Due to the interest and generosity of several art patrons, Chase was able to take a five-year trip to Munich, where he studied at the city's Royal Academy. In 1878, Chase returned to New York City, opened his Tenth Street Studio and developed his signature impressionist style. He was a member of America's influential group of impressionists known as The Ten, but was also an extremely influential teacher. Chase opened one of the first summer schools of landscape painting at his summer home in Shinnecock, Long Island. He also taught at the Chase School in New York, which he founded, and the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. His students included such famous artists as Marsden Hartley, Charles Demuth, Edward Hopper, Georgia O'Keeffe and Charles Sheeler.

Connections: Not available in IMA generated documents
Sources/Bibliography: Ronald G. Pisano. William Merritt Chase: The Complete Catalogue of Known and Documents Work by William Merritt Chase (1849-1916), Vol. 2: Portraits in Oil, New Haven Connecticut: Yale University Press, 2007. ISBN-13: 978-0300110210
Micro Summary: "After the Shower" by William Merritt Chase demonstrates the artist's Munich Royal Academy training through its broad brushwork and dramatic contrasts of light and dark. The composition and color palette reveal additional influence from French Barbizon painters, creating a hybrid of German and French artistic techniques. Chase created this work during a transitional period, just before he developed the lighter, more luminous landscape style that would define his later reputation.

Title: Dorothy
Artwork Description: Painted in 1902, this is one of a number of portraits of family members painted by Chase. This is one of a series of female full-length portraits painted by Chase between 1886 and 1902. Chase frequently painted his wife, Alice Gerson Chase (22 times), and their eight children. Dorothy Bremond Chase was painted at least 15 times at various ages and settings. In 1902, Chase created four full-length portraits (The Open Japanese Book, Dorothy, Mrs. Chase in Pink and Master Robert)–the scale of which indicates that they were likely exhibition pieces to attract potential clients. Chase was particularly proud of these portraits and regarded them as among his best work. Wearing a charming straw hat and a fashionable, pleated white dress rendered in confident, broad brushstrokes, Dorothy confronts the viewer with her direct, unwavering gaze and self-assured demeanor. Dorothy received numerous positive reviews. One historian praised the artist's depiction: "When Mr. Chase combines portraiture and genre painting as in Alice and Dorothy...he makes pictures that are simply bewitching. Dorothy has more of the challenge of the young miss who feels her power, but wants you to know that she feels it." Dorothy was purchased from the artist at the Exhibition of Indiana Art in Tomlinson Hall in Indianapolis in 1903 using the John Herron fund. Chase painted just over 600 known portraits--his most active period being the last ten years before he died, completing one every two weeks on average. Chase founded the Shinnecock Summer School of Art in 1891 and taught classes there in the summer. After 1902, he took his summer students on trips to study art in Europe.
Artist Biography: American painter of Impressionist landscapes, realistic still lives and memorable portraits of family members was born in Williamsburg (now Nineveh), Indiana in 1849, and died in New York City in 1916. Chase studied for five years in Munich returning to New York City in 1878. Chase was an avid teacher during his career having taught at the Art Students League, the Brooklyn Art Association, the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts and at the New York City School of Art and the Shinnecock Summer School of Art both of which he founded. Chase was a founding member of the Society of American Artists, which challenged the authority of the National Academy of Design. Chase's large, elaborately decorated studio in the Tenth Street Studio Building was the most famous artists' studio in America as well as a gathering place for New York artists. Dressed in a flowing cape and accompanied by his Russian wolfhounds, Chase presented himself as an aristocratic bohemian. Chase's prodigious output of nearly 2000 works was influenced by Tonalism, Impressionism and Realism. Among the artists taught by Chase were: Charles Demuth, Georgia O'Keeffe, Marsden Hartley, and Edward Hopper.
Tour Guidance: Use as part of a tour based on portraiture. Compare and contrast subject, age of subject, props, seating/position of subject. Discuss the use of white in the Impressionist palette. Compare and contrast with other Impressionist pieces. Discuss use of black on black in this piece. Ask young children to assume this pose. What do they think the young sitter had to do while this portrait was being painted? Compare and contrast with other works by Munich-trained artists.
Connections: Compare and contrast with other portraits in European galleries with respect to sitter, style and background. Connect with full-length portrait of Chase in American gallery by James Carroll Beckwith. Compare Dorothy and Alice (Alice—A Portrait) with Whistler's Harmony in Grey and Green: Miss Cicely Alexander for similar poses and overall composition. Compare with other paintings of young women in American galleries: Preparing for the Matinee by Edmund Charles Tarbell, Girl Sweeping by William M. Paxton. Compare to portraits of young women dressed in white: Louisa Fletcher by Mary Shepherd Greene Blumenschein, Calypso by George Hitchcock, Sunlight by Frank W. Benson, and Harmony in Pink and Gray: Lady Meux by James Abbott McNeill Whistler.

Micro Summary: William Merritt Chase (1849-1916) was an influential American Impressionist who studied in Munich and became a celebrated teacher, founding the Shinnecock Summer School of Art and instructing future masters including Georgia O'Keeffe, Marsden Hartley, and Edward Hopper. His 1902 full-length portrait "Dorothy" depicts his daughter Dorothy Bremond Chase in a fashionable white dress and straw hat, painted as an exhibition piece to attract portrait commissions during his most prolific period when he completed one portrait every two weeks. Purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1903 directly from the artist at the Exhibition of Indiana Art, the painting exemplifies Chase's masterful Impressionist technique and his ability to capture both the sophisticated charm and self-assured personality of his young subject.

Title: Alaska
Artwork Description: Alaska was probably done in the artist's studio from sketches made during his ill-fated voyage on board the Ancon. The artist's subject is the vast scale of the fog-shrouded mountains and wilderness. The group of Indian hunters and the dark forest add to the scene's mystery and must have suggested to nineteenth century viewers a place on the edge of their imagination. The canvas expresses Bierstadt's sense of wonder before the vast untamed wilderness.
Artist Biography: Born in Düsseldorf, Germany, Albert Bierstadt came to New Bedford, Massachusetts, with his family when he was a baby. He returned to Düsseldorf in 1853 to study at the Royal Academy. He traveled throughout Europe with fellow students Sanford Gifford and Worthington Whittredge. Bierstadt returned to America in 1857. One year later, he began painting the Rocky Mountains, which was a subject he would return to often. He made numerous trips to the West, painting and exhibiting in California. In 1865, he built a home on the Hudson River near New York City, but his fame lies in his landscapes of the American West. Soon after the United States occupied the Alaska territory, many artists, including Bierstadt, painted in the area. In 1889, Bierstadt traveled to Alaska on the steamer Ancon. The Ancon was wrecked and Bierstadt, along with the other passengers, stayed in Indian huts and salmon canneries for five days until the next steamer brought them back to Vancouver. During that time, Bierstadt created sixty studies and two books of drawings of Alaska.
Sources/Bibliography: Anderson, Nancy K. and Linda S. Ferber. Albert Bierstadt: Art and Enterprise. Manchester, Vermont: Hudson Hills Press, 1991.
Micro Summary: Albert Bierstadt (1830-1902), German-born American landscape painter, created Alaska around 1889 from sketches made during his ill-fated 1889 voyage when the steamer Ancon wrecked, forcing him and fellow passengers to shelter in Indian huts and salmon canneries for five days. Born in Düsseldorf and raised in New Bedford, Massachusetts, Bierstadt studied at the Royal Academy, traveled Europe with fellow Hudson River School painters, and became famous for his monumental landscapes of the American West, particularly the Rocky Mountains. This oil on canvas captures the vast scale of fog-shrouded mountains and wilderness with Indian hunters and dark forest, expressing Bierstadt's sense of wonder before untamed Alaska and suggesting to nineteenth-century viewers a place on the edge of imagination, completed after his return from Vancouver.

Title: Sunlit Window
Artwork Description: Ritman's interest in decorative patterning is evident in the mixture of floral prints with stripes that contrast with the buzzing confusion of nature seen through the open window. In Sunlit Window, the floral prints of the wallpaper, curtains, and model's blouse co-exist with the potted plant leaves and the emphatic stripes of the venetian blinds and table legs. The orderly patterns contrast abruptly with the buzzing confusion of nature seen through the open window. The striking difference between the style of Early Morning Sunshine (IMA) and Sunlit Window is due to Ritman's contact with the artist Frederick Frieseke, leader of the Giverny Group, who achieved fame with his use of strong, colorful decorative patterns.
Artist Biography: Louis Ritman enrolled in the École des Beaux Arts in the summer of 1909. Around 1911, he moved to Giverny, where he spent almost two decades. At this time, Ritman came under the influence of the American Impressionists Richard Miller and Frederick Frieseke. He was particularly inspired by their paintings of women in domestic interiors and garden settings. Their approach differed from the previous artists who resided in Giverny because they focused on figure painting over landscapes. A popular subject included women relaxing in their boudoirs or in sunlit gardens. By the summer of 1913, Ritman was producing images of nude and partially draped figures. Ritman, a Chicago artist, settled in Giverny, France near the home of Claude Monet, in 1909.

Sources/Bibliography: Love, Richard H. Louis Ritman: From Chicago to Giverny. Chicago: Haase Mumm Publishing Company.
Micro Summary: Louis Ritman's "Sunlit Window" showcases his fascination with decorative patterning through a complex interplay of floral prints, stripes, and natural elements. The artwork features floral motifs in wallpaper, curtains, and the model's blouse, alongside emphatic stripes from venetian blinds and table legs, all contrasted with potted plant leaves. These orderly interior patterns create a striking juxtaposition against the chaotic natural world visible through the open window. The painting reflects Ritman's artistic evolution influenced by Frederick Frieseke, leader of the Giverny Group, who was renowned for incorporating bold, colorful decorative patterns into his work.

Title: Ideal Head
Medium: oil on paper mounted on canvas
Artwork Description: Hunt's studies in Europe in the 1840s and '50s brought him into contact with Jean François Millet and the Barbizon School. Hunt returned to America in 1855 and settled in Boston in 1862. The Renaissance costume of this figure suggests a growing interest in that historical period, one that was also reflected in furniture and other decorative arts of the 1860s and '70s.
Artist Biography: Hunt's studies in Europe in the 1840s and '50s brought him into contact with Jean François Millet and the Barbizon School. Hunt returned to America in 1855 and settled in Boston in 1862.

Micro Summary: "Ideal Head" by William Morris Hunt reflects the artist's European training with Jean François Millet and the Barbizon School during the 1840s and '50s. Hunt returned to America in 1855 and established himself in Boston by 1862. The figure's Renaissance costume demonstrates the period's growing fascination with historical revival styles. This interest in Renaissance aesthetics was part of a broader cultural movement that influenced decorative arts and furniture design throughout the 1860s and '70s.

Title: Old Market Woman
Artwork Description: Forsyth focuses on the timeworn quality of the woman's hands and facial features. This canvas exemplifies the Munich Schools' dark tonality and bravura brushwork. In 1882 William Forsyth traveled to Munich to study at the Royal Academy. In 1883 William Forsyth entered the Technical Painting Class of Ludwig von Löfftz, where he received a full grounding the painting of portrait heads and figure studies. In this canvas painted about midway through his six-year stay in Europe, Forsyth focuses on the time-worn quality of the woman's hands and facial features. Old Market Woman exemplifies the Munich School's dark tonality and bravura brushwork, derived from the 17th-century Dutch portraits of Rembrandt and Hals.
Artist Biography: William Forsyth was born in California, Ohio, not far from Cincinnati. His early use of the family's walls as a drawing board convinced his parents that their son need a specific space to express his creativity. When he was ten, his family moved to Versaille, Indiana and then to Indianapolis. Forsyth started his art studies with Barton Hays when he was fifteen. He earned his living painting houses with his brother and used his free time to explore his artistic talents. Forsyth became on of the first student in the newly established Indiana School of Art and later worked as an assistant instructor at the school. His desire for more formal training led Forsyth to follow his friend Theodore Clement Steele to Munich to study at the Royal Academy. During the summer he traveled around Europe and sent the paintings he completed during these trips home to sell at exhibitions. When Forsyth finished his studies, he stayed in Europe for another two years then returned to Indiana and set up a school in Muncie with J. Ottis Adams. After the school closed, Forsyth joined the faculty of the newly opened John Herron Art Institute where he worked from 1906 to 1933. Well into his seventies, but not prepared emotionally or financially for retirement, Forsyth took commissions from the Public Works Administration, which had been established to help artists during the Depression. In 1934 Forsyth had a heart attack and died a year later.

Sources/Bibliography: Martin Krause. The Passage: Return of Indiana Painters from Germany, 1880-1905, Indianapolis: Indianapolis Museum of Art, 1990. ISBN 00-936260-52-1
Micro Summary: William Forsyth's "Old Market Woman" was painted during his six-year European study period, specifically while he was training at Munich's Royal Academy under Ludwig von Löfftz. The work exemplifies the Munich School's characteristic dark tonality and bold brushwork, drawing inspiration from 17th-century Dutch masters like Rembrandt and Hals. Forsyth focuses particularly on capturing the weathered, time-worn quality of the elderly woman's hands and facial features. This portrait demonstrates the technical skills and artistic approach Forsyth developed during his formal European training in figure studies and portrait painting.

Title: The Pianist (Stanley Addicks)
Artwork Description: This work shows an individual with emphasis on his personality. This person's combination of psychological attributes and physical characteristics as his own unique attributes. This concept of capturing the individual's uniqueness is pivotal to understanding Eakins. The pianist's hands aren't visible, neither is there a piano. No symbolism to show he's a pianist. The title identifies his profession. The eyes are arresting. Realism from bags under the eyes to rumpled jacket. These and other examples of his real physicality reveal his personality to the viewers. Forms are built up with a sense of light and shadow. Pigment applied in successive coats, giving depth and transparency. Critics have claimed that he is musing about music. The sitter could be our contemporary today, from haircut to shirt color and style of collar to unconstructed jacket and moustache
Artist Biography: Thomas Eakins, born 1844, attended Central High in Philadelphia, which stressed skills in drawing as well as a democratic respect for disciplined achievement. In 1862 he studied at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, then went to Paris to enroll at the École des Beaux-arts. From 1866 to the end of 1869, he worked intensely under Jean-Léon Gérôme. Eakins returned to settle in Philadelphia in July 1870. One of his more famous works, The Gross Clinic, was painted in 1875. The painting's blood-spattered figures show the realism for which Eakins would become well known. He had determined that he would make portrait painting his life's work. Eakins cultivated the broad brushwork and indirect painting techniques of Velasquez, under whom Eakins studied for about six months in Spain on his way home to Philadelphia in 1870. Eakins was also a photographer and an accomplished pianist himself. Although he ultimately painted less than three hundred works, Eakins received commissions for only about twenty-five. He died in 1916.
Tour Guidance: American Spotlight: Certainly a portraitist of Eakins' stature needs to be emphasized. Learning to Look: Discuss how Eakins is important to the idea of "looking" by explaining his own power to observe and record what he observed.
Connections: Eyes: The eyes of the pianist have an arresting and at the same time almost plaintive quality. They draw the viewer to the painting. In the same way, Mary Shepard Greene Blumenschein's Louisa Fletcher presents a young woman whose expression reveals little. Both figures present a behavior: the pianist seems pensive (perhaps with a tune he's remembering?) while the young woman seems pensive in her own way, unknown to the viewer. Finally, Henry Ossawa Tanner's The Two Disciples at the Tomb, Kneeling Disciple shows us eyes charged with emotion wide open at his vision of the light. The viewer can sense this with or without knowledge of the Bible story. The disciple seems too to have no sense that we are watching him, less even than the musician or the maiden. Realism: In The Pianist (Stanley Addicks), we see a baggy-eyed, multi-hued skin, tousled-haired musician wearing a rumpled jacket. No nips and tucks here, especially since Eakins would have been familiar with Addicks' personality. Eakins is a realist painter. Diagonally across the gallery we see gutted fish, a realistic theme painted in great detail and just as masterfully rendered. Neither work romanticizes the subject. Across from Chase's work, we find Winslow Homer's The Boat Builders. This painting is revealing in at least two ways. First, it is painted in a realistic manner, and second it realistically speaks to us of where the boys are likely to spend their lives, like their dads, on fishing boats which they've replicated. Frames: The frame of The Pianist (Stanley Addicks) contributes to its contemporary appeal. Not only does the subject seem quite contemporary in his looks and dress, with the exception of his tie perhaps, but the frame looks very simple and contemporary. To the right of Eakins' work, Augustus Saint-Gauden's representation of Robert Louis Stevenson also has a "natural" frame. It might be interesting to compare the frames of Louisa Fletcher and The Pianist (Stanley Addicks).
Sources/Bibliography: Eakins and Icons. Michael Leja. The Art Bulletin, vol 83, no. 3 (Sep., 2001), pp. 479-497. Published by College Art Association. The Revenge of Thomas Eakins. Sidney Kirkpatrick. Yale University Press, 2006. A Life in Somber Tones. Deborah Solomon. New York Times, April 2, 2006. Grove Art Online. Eakins, Thomas. http://www.oxfordartonline.com:80/subscriber/article/grove/art/T024413. Bulletin of the Association of the Art Institute of Indianapolis. JHAI. Vol. XXVII, March 1940, No. 1.
Micro Summary: Thomas Eakins' "The Pianist (Stanley Addicks)" exemplifies the artist's commitment to psychological realism through portraiture. The work focuses entirely on capturing the subject's individuality through physical details like bags under his eyes and rumpled clothing, rather than through symbolic elements or professional props. Notably, neither piano nor hands are visible, with only the title indicating Addicks' profession as a pianist. Eakins builds form through careful attention to light, shadow, and layered pigments to create depth and transparency. The timeless quality of the portrait, from the sitter's haircut to his clothing style, demonstrates Eakins' ability to capture universal human character that transcends specific historical periods.

Title: Training for War
Artwork Description: Johnson was a Harlem Renaissance Artist. Focal point: Depicting African Americans, not derogatory, but with a sense of humor. Painting the American scene with Regionalism and social realism. This one is Pochoir (stenciled and hand painted) In World War II African Americans were segregated in the military as he is showing. Most important this painting is one of a series of five, done in 1941, showing African-American soldiers assembling a machine, boarding troop ships, lying on the ground under fire and returning wounded on stretchers. This series was purchased in an open competition sponsored by the Office of Emergency Management for Inclusion in major traveling exhibition to support the war effort. About 80% of Johnson's' paintings were given to the Smithsonian Museum, seeing his art in other places is rare. This piece was given by the National Coalition of 100 Black Women of Indianapolis Chapter.
Artist Biography: African American Artist, Born March 18, 1901 Florence, SC, Died April 13, 1970 Long Island, NY. His early education was intermittent but his drawing skills were developed through cartoon work for local newspapers. At 17 he moved to New York, where he found work as a stevedore, cook and hotel porter. From 1923 to 1926 he attended the National Academy of Design in New York and Hawthorne's Cape Cod School of Art at Provincetown. His graduation funds were raised by supporters to enable him to study in Paris, where he stayed for three years, absorbing the impact of such European Expressionists as Chaim Soutine and simplifying his paintings to bold rhythmic compositions. In Paris he met Holcha Krake, a Danish textile designer, whom he married. The couple traveled through Europe, returning to the USA in 1930. Johnson received an award from the Harmon Foundation for 'Distinguished Achievement among Negroes'. He than developed a broader technique with richness of texture and color. From 1938 in New York, Johnson changed his style to produce flat designs with patterns of brilliant color, emulating stained glass, depicting religious subject and scenes from Black American history. Upon his death, his estate of 1100 works was accommodated by the Harmon Foundation until its closure, when it was dispersed among interested organizations such as the Smithsonian receiving approximately 80%.Among other friends was Eugene O'Neill whose sister-in-law Fisk married in the early 1920's.
Tour Guidance: Tour Uses: Learning to Look or Highlights: Discuss how flat the figures are and could they be cut-outs? Discuss the simplicity of the painting and how the figures are flat and the buildings have depth. Ask why are there 3 flags? History Tour: Explain the segregated army during WWII, Pres. Truman ended this. Discuss how this painting tells a strong American History Story depicting Average Americans with humor. Explain how the flag is sending the message of freedom (tongue in cheek).
Connections: Jacob Lawrence, Untitled (The Birth). Hale Woodruff, Picking Cotton. Compare with Layla Ali and use of flags and uniforms.
Micro Summary: "Training for War" by William Henry Johnson is a 1941 pochoir (stenciled and hand-painted) work depicting segregated African American soldiers during World War II. Created by the Harlem Renaissance artist, this piece is part of a five-painting series showing various aspects of Black military service, from training to combat to casualties. The series was selected through an open competition by the Office of Emergency Management for a major traveling exhibition supporting the war effort. Johnson painted African Americans with dignity and social realism rather than derogatory stereotypes, making this historically significant artwork both rare to see outside the Smithsonian and important for its authentic portrayal of segregated military service.

Title: Whaler and Fishing Vessels Near the Coast of Labrador
Artwork Description: About 1880, oil on canvas. Whaler and fishing vessels near coast of Labrador. In Bradford's day, icebergs seen as symbols of perpetual process of formation and destruction, icy equivalents of mountains. Hudson River School painters' inclination to interpret nature in spiritual sense. Whaler and fishing vessels add human presence that tempers awesome scale of nature. Gift of Delavan Smith.
Artist Biography: William Bradford, American (1823-1892). Born and raised in New Bedford, Massachusetts, son of Quaker parents. Primary job was clerk in father's dry goods store. Launched professional career early 1850s selling ship portraits for twenty-five dollars. Opened studio 1854. Dutch painter Albert Van Beest became teacher and collaborator. Painted seascapes and whaling pictures of local scenes. Beginning 1861, series of trips to Nova Scotia, Labrador, and Greenland painting and photographing the area. 1870s set up studio in San Francisco, traveled West painting Yosemite and Sierra Nevada. Became famous for seascapes, particularly Arctic region. With Frederic Edwin Church, responsible for popularizing Arctic in American art.
Sources/Bibliography: Bradford, William and Richard Kugler. William Bradford: Sailing Ships and Arctic Seas. New Bedford, Connecticut: New Bedford Whaling Museum, 2003
Micro Summary: William Bradford (1823-1892), American marine painter born in New Bedford, Massachusetts, created Whaler and Fishing Vessels near the Coast of Labrador around 1880, following his series of annual trips to Nova Scotia, Labrador, and Greenland from 1861 through 1869. Bradford, son of Quaker parents who worked in his father's dry goods store before launching his professional career painting ship portraits, became famous alongside Frederic Edwin Church for popularizing Arctic subjects in American art, capturing the Romantic era's fascination with exotic places and adventure. This oil on canvas depicts icebergs as symbols of nature's perpetual formation and destruction—viewed as icy equivalents of mountains representing physical and spiritual grandeur—with whaling and fishing vessels adding human presence that tempers the awesome scale of nature, demonstrating the Hudson River School's inclination to interpret nature in spiritual terms and showing humanity existing on equal terms with the natural world.

Title: Portrait of a German Tragedian
Artwork Description: Oil on canvas, 1907, 57 1/2 x 33 inches (63 x 40 inches framed). The sitter's expressive right hand reveals the artist had solid grounding in draftsmanship and modeling. The portly man was an actor stranded in Paris who posed for painters between acting jobs. Gift of Booth Tarkington.
Artist Biography: Ernest Leonard Blumenschein (1874-1960) was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, son of a prominent musician. Exposed early to art and music, after some success as a violinist he decided to study art in Paris at the Académie Julian. He met Joseph Henry Sharp who told him about the marvelous landscape of New Mexico. Blumenschein and artist-wife Mary Shepard Greene both taught at Pratt Institute. Eventually they moved their family to New Mexico where he became one of the more well-known Taos painters and won numerous awards.
Tour Guidance: This portrait was painted during Blumenschein's Paris years before he co-founded the Taos Art Colony. The work was exhibited in Paris in 1908 where author Booth Tarkington purchased it. Every summer Blumenschein would go to Taos to paint landscape, eventually moving his family to New Mexico permanently. The portrait demonstrates his academic training before he became known for Western landscapes.
Connections: Connect to Taos Art Colony history. Compare academic European training with later Western subject matter. Discuss the practice of struggling models posing for artists. Note Tarkington's role as collector of American art.
Sources/Bibliography: Gift of Booth Tarkington. Taos Art Colony documentation. Paris exhibition records 1908.
Micro Summary: Painted during Blumenschein's Paris period before co-founding the Taos Art Colony, this 1907 portrait captures a struggling German actor who modeled between theatrical engagements. The expressive hand demonstrates solid academic draftsmanship from his Académie Julian training, before Western landscapes became his focus. Purchased by author Booth Tarkington at the 1908 Paris exhibition, the work documents Blumenschein's European years before New Mexico inspiration transformed his career.
